div2.p: After refitting his four ships, Gylippus leaves Tarentum, and, receiving at the Epizephyrian Locri more favourable news of the situation at Syracuse, proceeds undisturbed by Attic ships through the strait to Himera. From this point he enters into communication with Selinus and Gela and various Sicel localities, and with seven hundred men of his own troops, and over two thousand who joined him from Himera and the allied places, begins his march through the interior towards Syracuse.
1. e)pei\ e)peskeu/asan: the completion of the e)peskeu/azen of vi.104.20.

punqano/menoi safe/steron: opp. to vi.104.3, w(s au)toi=s ai( a)ggeli/ai e)foi/twn . . . e)yeusme/nai. The pres. partic. here implies repeated inquiry, corresponding to w(s e)foi/twn in the passage quoted.
kata\ ta\s *)epipola/s: the high triangle-shaped plateau northwest of the city. See on vi.96.3.

labo/ntes: either labw/n or e)/xwn is usual with the verb in this connexion, when the destination is remote. See on vi.62.7. The partic. is to be supplied also in 7 with e)n a)ristera=|.— 7. diakinduneu/swsin, e)/lqwsi: deliberative subjvs., which are often retained even after an historical tense (cf. i.107.25; ii.4.28; iii.112.22), but sometimes change to the opt. (cf. i.25.4; 63. 3; iv.19.6). G. 244; II. 932, 2; Kr. Spr. 54, 7, 1.—e)spleu=sai: into the great harbour, from which point they would perhaps have been able, united with the Syracusans, to force their way into the gap in the Athenian line of circumvallation (cf. c. 2. 17 ff.). Gylippus preferred, however, the way by land because he wanted first to get allies.
au)tou/s te e)kei/nous: Schol. tou\s *(imerai/ous dhlono/ti. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 1.
stratia/n, ou(/s: rel. in pl. referring to a collective noun. G. 151, N. 2; H. 629. Cf. iii.67.11, h(liki/an, w(=n.

12. punqano/menos au)tou\s o(/mws e)n *lokroi=s ei)=nai: the reading of the Vat. Ms., instead of the vulgate o(/mws punqano/menos kte(. Nicias had paid little attention to the first report of the approach of Gylippus, kai\ lh|stikw/teron e)/doce pareskeuasme/nous plei=n (vi.104.22). He recognized, however, that Gylippus was in earnest on learning that the ships had, after all (contrary to his expectation), got so far on their voyage to Sicily (o(/mws e)n *lokroi=s ei=nai), and that, therefore, help for Syracuse was really intended. He had immediately, thereupon, sent out the four Attic ships (a)pe/steile, aor. in dependent clause); but these came too late to prevent the Peloponnesian ships from passing through the strait.

sxo/ntes *(phgi/w|: touching at; dat. after sxei=n, as in iii.29.5; 33. 5, instead of the more usual e)s with the acc. (c. 26. 7; ii.25.15; 33. 10; iii.34.1; iv.3.4; 25. 40; v.2.5; vi.52.5; 62. 8). kata/ with acc. in same const. occurs in i.110.11; iv.129.12; vi.97.3. Kr. Spr. 48, 1, 2; Kühn. 423, 5.

16. tou/s te *(imerai/ous: Vat. omits te, but it is better to follow the rest of the Mss., tou/s te *(imerai/ous, explaining, as St. does: “To these words correspond kai\ tou\s *selinounti/ous e)ke/leuon in 19, and the correlatives te kai/ show that e)kei= o)/ntes belongs to both clauses.” See App.
o(/soi...o(/pla : see App.

20. tina ou) pollh/n: cf. ii.79.16.— 23. tou= *)arxwni/dou: this Archonidas is doubtless the prince of Herbita, whom Diod. (xii. 8) mentions as ally of the powerful Sicel leader Duce
tius. After the latter's death (439 B.C.), his political course toward Syracuse and Agrigentum was doubtless continued by Archonidas, who died at an advaneed age, 415 B.C. See Holm, Geschichte Siciliens, I. p. 260; II. p. 39.

dokou=ntos proqu/mws h(/kein: (so Vat. instead of proqu/mws dokou=ntos h(/kein) referring to polu\ proqumo/teron e(toi=moi h)=san in 22. The bold example of Gylippus, report of which spread far and wide (dokou=ntos), had inspired the Sicels with courage.
kai\ o( me\n *gu/lippos...pa/ntas : sums up in a)nalabw/n the result of the efforts detailed in 15 ff.

sfete/rwn: refers to Gylippus and Pythen. Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 3. Cf. c. 4. 10; 8. 3. —tou\s w(plisme/nous: those who had been armed by the help of the Himeraeans (17, 18). Diod. (xiii. 7) gives the force of Gylippus as tou\s a(/pantas trisxili/ous me\n pezou/s, diakosi/ous d) i(ppei=s.

tou\s pa/ntas : in all, added perhaps because the Sicels were of various tribes. Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 13. Cf. viii.21.4.—e)xw/rei: commenced his march towards Syracuse (impf.), the further course of which is related c. 2. 11.

In the meantime the Corinthian Gongylus, sailing from Leucas with one ship, arrives at Syracuse, where he revives the sinking courage of the inhabitants by the news of the approach of Gylippus. The latter reaches Epipolae without opposition, ascends it on the side of Euryelus, and then immediately advances, in union with the Syracusans, against the wall of the Athenians, which had been almost completed on the side toward the great harbour.
1. oi( e)k *leuka/dos *kori/nqioi: cf. vi. 104. § 1.

w(s ei)=xon ta/xous: part. gen. depending on adv. of condition. G. 168, N. 3; 11. 757 a; Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 5. Cf. c. 57. 5; i.22.14.—kai\ *go/ggulos: as if ai( a)/llai tw=n *korinqi/wn nh=es had gone before. Acc. to Plut. Nic. 19, this Gongylus fell in the first conflict with the Athenians. On the accent, *go/ggulos, see App.

mia=|...*guli/ppon : he had let the remaining ships (which, acc. to vi. 104. § 1, were to follow Gylippus) set out before himself; but he arrived at Syracuse first of all—probably because he touched at no point on the voyage —and even a little before Gylippus.

5. au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *surakosi/ous.—
a)pallagh=s: the subst. from a)palla/ttesqai (not from the act.), as in iv.61.24.
nh=es a)/llai: which had started before him. See on 3, above.
a)/rxwn: not as commander of the ships merely, but also of the Syracusans (toi=s *surakosi/ois, vi.93.9).
10. a)panthso/menoi: the mid. form only in the fut. So also c. 80. 23.— 11. h)|sqa/nonto: cf. Plut. Nic. 19, h(=ken a)/ggelos para\ tou= *guli/ppou keleu/ontos a)panta=n.

*)ieta/s : see App.— to/te ti: (the reading of Vat.) to/te is to be taken with e)n th=| paro/dw| e(lw/n, and refers to the decision of Gylippus kata\ gh=n e)lqei=n, c. 1. 9.—tw=n *sikelw=n: belongs to tei=xos. As to these Sicels, cf. c. 32. § 1; vi. 88. § 4.— 13. e(lw\n kai\ cuntaca/menos: both partics. represent actions which follow one after the other but precede a)fiknei=tai pro\s ta\s *)epipola/s, and therefore can prop. be connected by kai/. v. H. and St. reject kai/. See App.
14. kata\ to\n *eu)ru/hlon h(=|per kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi: cf. vi.97.11.

meta\ tw=n *surakosi/wn: who had gone out to meet him, and, since the largest part of the Athenian army was occupied in building the double wall (vi. 103. § 1), had been able to pass through the incomplete fortifications of the Athenians to the western part of Epipolae. That the advance of Gylippus and his union with the Syracusans was effected without hindrance, shows how much the energy and watchfulness of Nicias had already abated since the death of Lamachus. See Grote, Hist. of Greece, VII.c.59, p. 106 f.

to\ tei/xisma: the diplou=n tei=xos of vi.103.7, the condition of which at this time is immediately explained.— e)/tuxe e)lqw/n: see App.—kata\ tou=to tou= kairou=: part. gen. depending on kata\ tou=to, as in c. 69. 16, e)n tw=| toiou/tw| tou= kairou=. G. 168; Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 3.

e(pta\ me\n h)\ o)ktw\ stadi/wn: gen. of measure with tei=xos. G. 167, 5; H. 729 d. The correlative of me/n is de/ in tw=| de\ a)/llw| in 20. Since the shortest distance from the cliff (of Epipolae) to the recess of the great harbour adjacent to the Agrigentine gate was not less than eight stadia, it seems clear that in
this measure was included only that part of the wall of circumvallation of the Athenians which was in the low ground by the sea. Leake (in Bloomf. p. 680). Cl. brackets the words without suflicient reasons. See App.
a)petete/lesto: on the form see App.

para\ braxu/ ti: so with Vat., instead of kata\ braxu/ ti, because it indicates more sharply the small remnant that was still unfinished: “the wall was finished except a small portion next to the sea.” para/ as in 23, para\ tosou=ton, by so much. But St., who reads kata/, objects that the addition of plh/n is opp. to taking para\ braxu/ ti with the force of para\ tosou=ton.
to\ pro\s th\n qa/lassan : adv., not in appos. with diplou=n tei=xos.

tou=to de/ : refers to braxu/ ti.—[tou= ku/klou pro\s to\n *trw/gilon]: St. and Cl. consider these words a gloss, added through recollection of vi.99.2; though there, as in vi.98.9; 101. 1; 102. 5, ku/klos means the ring-shaped fort (see on vi.98.9), nowhere the wall of circumvallation, as seems to be intended here acc. to the common reading. See App.— 21. li/qoi te...tw=| ple/oni h)/dh h)=san : tw=| pli/oni is in part. appos. to tw=| a)/llw|, along the greater part of the remainder. G. 137, N. 2; H. 624 d. So far the preparations for building mentioned in vi.99.2 (li/qous . . . pare/ballon) had been completed. Some parts of the wall were already quite finished or only half finished. and when Gylippus arrived were left in this condition. Hence the impf. katelei/peto, which Herbst (Gegen Cobet, p. 40) rightly defends against Cobet's conjecture katele/leipto.— 23. para\ tosou=ton kte(.: such a narrow escape had Syracuse from danger (destruction). This const., which occurs also in iii.49.18, is to be explained acc. to the analogy of para\ tosou=ton e)ge/neto or h)=lqe with the inf. (iv.106.18; viii.33.12; 76. 15) “by so much (by so slight a deficiency) it happened, it came to—” (it came so near to). Just so o(/son ou) ‘by how much not,’ i.e. by how little not, means ‘almost.’ That to which “it had almost come” stands, when expressed by a clause, in the inf.; when by a subst., in the gen., which is to be construed just as the gen. with e)ggu/s, plhsi/on, etc. G. 182, 2; II. 757.

The hostile armies are arrayed against one another, but do not come to an engagement. On the next day,
however, Gylippus with a small detachment surprises Labdalum, the fort on the northernmost height of Epipolae, and puts the Athenian garrison to the sword.

3. pareta/canto de/: Thuc. says nothing about the place where the Athenians took their position. But since the larger part of the army, acc. to vi.103.6, was engaged in building the double wall next to the great harbour, it must be supposed that the two armies confronted each other in the low ground between the abrupt declivity of Epipolae and the Anapus, near the Athenian fortifications.— qe/menos ta\ o(/pla e)ggu/s: halting under arms near by. Cf. ii.2.22; iv.44.5; 68. 10; 90. 20; viii.25.22; 93. 6.— kh/ruka prospe/mpei le/gonta: so Vat. (for prope/mpei of most of the Mss.), acc. to the usage of Thuc., iii.52.10; iv.114.5. le/gonta is pres. part. of purpose. See on c. 25. 40. In force and const. the phrase is equiv. to the simple le/gei; hence the following nom. e(toi=mos with ei)=nai. See App. on iii.52.11.
pe/nte h(merw=n: within five days. Gen. of time with e)cie/nai, as in c. 28. 19; v.14.13. G. 179, 1; 11. 759; Kr. Spr. 47, 2, 3.
6. e)n o)ligwri/a| e)poiou=nto: without expressed obj., as in iv.5.2.

ou)de\n a)pokrina/menoi: Plut. Nic. 19 adds: tw=n de\ stratiwtw=n tines katagelw=ntes h)rw/twn ei) dia\ parousi/an e(no\s tri/bwnos kai\ bakthri/as *lakwnikh=s ou(/tws i)sxura\ ta\ *surakosi/wn e)cai/fnhs ge/gonen w(s *)aqhnai/wn katafronei=n.
9. tarassome/nous: in confusion, since they had not expected a battle so soon.
e)s th\n eu)ruxwri/an: i.e. toward the east into the low ground next to the coast. From there the ascent to the a)/kra *temeni=tis, when not opposed by hostile troops, was short and easy.
tw=| e(autw=n tei/xei: the almost completed diplou=n tei=xos of c. 2. 19.
a)ph/gage: off to the side (northward).
th\n a)/kran th\n *temeni=tin: the temple of Apollo Temenites and the suburb around it, the later Neapolis. Cf. vi.75.2.

15. a)/gwn: contrasted with pe/myas
in 17; here he commanded in person. —th\n plei/sthn th=s stratia=s: assimilation of the articular adj. to the gender of the part. gen. G. 168, N. 1; 11. 730 e; Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 9; Kühn. 405, 5 c. Cf. i.2.13; 5. 8; 30. 10; vi.7.5; 105. 3; viii.3.5.
mh\...a)/llose : esp. not to the defence of Labdalum.

ou)k e)pifane\s toi=s *)aqhnai/ois: since the Athenians were now on the southern declivity of Epipolae, and the fort lay on the extreme northern edge of the plateau (e)p' a)/krois toi=s krhmnoi=s; see on vi.97.24), the place could be surprised without their knowing it. The loss was the more serious because Labdalum was, acc. to vi.97.27, toi=s te skeu/esi kai\ toi=s xrh/masin a)poqh/kh.

21. e)formou=sa tw=| mega/lw| lime/ni: (mega/lw| from Vat. only) the Att. fleet, which had sailed down into the great harbour (vi.102.17), lay now in its innermost recess near the shore (e)n muxw=| tou= lime/nos, c. 4. 21). Guardships were sent out to the entrance of the harbour, which was a considerable distance off; and one of these fell into the hands of the Syracusans, who from their side could overlook every movement of the Athenians.

The Syracusans undertake to build a third counter-wall against the northern part of the Athenian wall of circumvallation, and make an unsuccessful attack on a weak point of the southern part of their wall. Nicias determines to fortify Plemmyrium at the entrance to the great harbour, and to unite there the fleet and the main body of the land army. But the removal of the army exposes the foragers to the Syracusan cavalry. Twenty triremes are sent to intercept the Corinthian ships which had sailed from Leucas after Gylippus.

2. dia\ tw=n *)epipolw=n...tei=xos a(plou=n : the cross-wall described in vi. 99. § 3 had been taken and destroyed by the Athenians (vi. 100), and the second Syracusan counterwall in the low ground (vi.101.6) had immediately thereafter (vi.101.16) fallen into their hands. The Syracusans now make the third attempt to hinder the Athenian circumvallation by means of a cross-wall, and as in vi.99.14, a)po\ th=s(sfete/ras)po/lews a)rca/menoi. It did notrun, however, as there, ka/twqen tou= ku/klou tw=n *)aqhnai/wn, but a)/nw, i.e. along the northern height of Epipolae (to\ pro\s bore/an tou= ku/klou, vi.99.1), where the Athenians li/qous kai\
cu/la cumforou=ntes pare/balon. In vi.99.16, moreover, the direction of the wall to be built was indicated by the adj. e)gka/rsion; here it is expressed adv., pro\s to\ e)gka/rsion, cross-wise, the wall itself being defined as tei=xos a(plou=n, as also in the letter of Nicias, c. 11. 14. The wall here begun is continued, c. 5. 1, dia\ tw=n *)epipolw=n, and finished in c. 7. 4, cunetei/xisan to\ loipo\n tou= e)gkarsi/ou tei/xous. See on c. 7. 4.
a)poteixi/sai: to complete the circumvallation (aor.).

5. oi(/ te *)aqhnai=oi...e)ph/|ei : vivid effect of the paratactic structure: “scareely had the Athenians, after finishing the lower part of the wall of circumvallation, again occupied their former position on Epipolae, when Gylippus advanced against a weak point of the wall.” Notice also the parallelism of the members in this and the next sent.: the parenthetical insertion of both causal clauses with ga/r, and the corresponding form of the main clauses, e)ph/|ei, a)nteph/|esan.
toi=s *)aqhnai/ois : intentionally added to avoid a misunderstanding; therefore wrongly suspected by v. H.
9. e)/tuxon...au)lizo/menoi : they happened to be in bivouac outside (of the walls).
tou\s sfete/rous: see on c. 1. 27.

e)poikodomh/santes au)to/: sc. to\ a)sqene\s tou= tei/xous, they made the wall higher at this weak point. The pred. adj. u(yhlo/teron indicates the effect. G. 166, N. 3; Kr. Spr. 57, 4, 2. Cf. i.37.21; 71. 27; 90. 21; ii.75.22; vi.92.23. —au)toi\ me/n: the Athenian main body, since experience had shown that here the danger of a breach was greatest.
tou\s de\ a)/llous cumma/xous: the rest (viz.) allies, not opp. to any preceding cu/mmaxoi. G. 142, 2, N. 3; H. 705; Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 11. Cf. i.2.12; 128. 21; ii.14.3; 77. 12; iii.19.8; iv.100.12.
to\ a)/llo tei/xisma: the wall running across Epipolae, on both sides of the ku/klos.

15. to\ *plhmmu/rion: this place, the
situation of which Thuc. describes so exactly, becomes henceforth the critical point in the siege of Syracuse. “The loss of Plemmyrium had for the Athenians the same consequences as that of Fort L'Eguillette for the English, when General Dugommier (with Bonaparte's assistance) drove them from the heights (Siege of Toulon, 1793).” Niebuhr, Ancient History, H. p. 155.
to\ sto/ma steno\n poiei=: cf. c. 59. 6, to\ sto/ma o)ktw\ stadi/wn ma/lista.
kai\ ei) teixisqei/h : acc. to Greek usage the influence of the rel. pron. (h(/per) is more strongly felt in the second clause than in English. We should begin an independent sent. with these words.

r(a=|on...e)/sesqai : the unusual adv. for the adj. is in accordance with the usage of Thuc. Cf. c. 28. 3, qa=sson ou)=sa; iv.10.13, mh\ r(a|di/ws au)tw=| pa/lin ou)/shs th=s a)naxwrh/sews. The adv. is to be const. as if we had r(a=|on au)tw=| e)fai/neto ta\ e)pith/deia e)skomisqh/sesqai. Kr. Spr. 62, 2, 3.

di) e)la/ssonos ga\r pro\s tw=| lime/ni tw=| tw=n *surakosi/wn e)formh/sein sfa=s: sc. tou=s *)aqhnai/ous, they themselves would keep watch upon the harbour of the Syracusans at a less distance (i.e. from the Syracusan ships) than before. di) e)la/ssonos also in vi.75.3. pro\s tw=| lime/ni tw=| tw=n *surakosi/wn refers to the part of the great harbour near the city where the Syracusan fleet lay. Kr. and St. strike out tw=| tw=n *surakosi/wn. Cl. wrongly takes e)formh/sein to mean “lie on watch” (of ships esp. detailed for this purpose), as in c. 3. 21. The main point here is the blockade which the whole Athenian fleet would be able to make from this nearer point, not being obliged, as heretofore, to put out from the further corner of the great harbour, whenever the enemy moved. The Schol. apparently understands it thus: teixisqe/ntos de\ tou= *plhmmuri/ou th\n e)fo/rmhsin au)to/qen di) o)li/gou xwri/ou e)/sesqai.

e)panagwga\s poih/sesqai : (with Vat., as in c. 34. 26, instead of e)pagwga/s) = e)pana/cesqai (viii.42.8), put to sea against an advancing squadron of hostile ships.—h)/n ti nautikw=| kinw=ntai: sc. oi( *surako/sioi, if they should bestir themselves with the fleet. On this medio-pass. use, see Kr. Spr. 52, 6, 1. Cf. c. 50. 33.

prosei=xe/ te h)/dh...pole/mw| : and in general, from now on, he devoted himself more to naval warfare. prose/xein in same sense in c. 75. 44. te gives the effect of a natural result, as in i.67.2; 76. 16, etc.
a)nelpisto/tera: cf. c. 47. 9; v.102.3.

stratia/n: some troops, i.e. those that were not necessary for guarding the
fortifications on Epipolae and in the low ground near the great harbour. The main camp of the Athenians continued to be along their walls.— 25. e)cetei/xise: the aor. to express speedy completion; cf. c. 26. 17; iv.4.4.—tri/a frou/ria: these forts were to supply the place of the arsenal on Labdalum, which had been captured (c. 3. § 4), and under their protection lay most of the fleet.

27. tw=n plhrwma/twn ka/kwsis e)ge/neto: = ta\ plhrw/mata e)kakw/qh (cf. the use of kakou=n in c. 24. 12; iii.87.6; vi.18.25). plhrw/mata signifies here the whole ship's crew, nau=tai as well as e)piba/tai. Cf. c. 12. 10; 13. 6.

tw=| te...oi( nau=tai : the causal partic. (xrw/menoi) and the temporal clause (o(po/te e)ce/lqoien), forming together the prot., are co-ordinated by te kai/. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3. With the principal verb diefqei/ronto, in the impf., they portray the gradual increase of the trouble.—kratou/ntwn th=s gh=s: since they were masters of the (adjacent) country. Cf. i.111.5; vi.23.7.
toi=s *surakosi/ois: the socalled dat. of the agent with the pass., really implying interest, as in v.29.3.

e)pi\ th=|...poli/xnh| : at the fort built at the Olympieium, as mentioned vi.75.5.—e)teta/xato: such Ion. forms of the pf. and plpf., otherwise unusual in Att., occur also in iii.13.16, 18; iv.31.7; v.6.23. Kr. Spr. 30, 2, 7.
35. ta\s loipa/s: cf. c. 2. § 1.— 36. e)s fulakh\n au)tw=n: i.e. in order to watch for them.
th\n prosbolh\n th=s *sikeli/as: the approach to Sicily. Cf. iv.1.5; vi.48.8.

nauloxei=n au)ta/s: this unusual word is explained by Photius, nauloxei=n: nau=s loxa=n kai\ e)nedreu/ein. *qoukudi/dhs e(bdo/mw|. au)ta/s is obj. of nauloxei=n. Cf. Appian, Bell. Civ. iv. 82, *mou=rkos e)n *peloponnh/sw| nauloxw=n *kleopa/tran.

Gylippus carries forward the counter-wall, and ventures to attack the Athenians between the two walls, but, not being able to use his cavalry in the confined space, is repulsed. By taking the blame of the failure on himself, however, he keeps the confidence of the Syracusans in future success unimpaired.

1. to\ dia\ tw=n *)epipolw=n tei=xos: see on c. 4. 2.—a(/ma me\n e)tei/xize...a(/ma de\ pare/tassen : significant expression for the restless activity of Gylippus in training his men for battle, and at the same time keeping the enemy occupied.

ou(\s oi( *)aqhnai=oi propareba/lonto sfi/sin: cf. c. 2. 21; vi.99.2. sfi/sin is added to the mid not without irony; they had dragged up the stones for their own wall, and saw them now used by their enemies. For sfi/si referring to the nearest subj., see Kühn. 455, note 9.

tou= teixi/smatos: the sing. refers to the crosswall (more exactly h( e)kei/nwn tei/xisis in c. 6. 5), which was still in process of erection, and before which Gylippus drew up his troops. tw=n teixisma/twn in 7 and tw=n teixw=n in 14 refer to the unfinished wall of circumvallation of the Athenians and the crosswall of the Syracusans that was advancing against it.
7. h(=|: more comprehensive than ou(=, “in a place where.”
ou)demi/a xrh=sis h)=n: pregnant use of ei)=nai = u(pa/rxein. Cf. c. 36. 28; 70. 25; i.2.5; 49. 11; 52. 10; ii.89.35; viii.96.6.

nekrou/s: among these was the Corinthian Gongylus, mentioned in c. 2. 2. Cf. Plut. Nic. 19.—u(pospo/ndous a)nelome/nwn: an acknowledgment of defeat, since they were obliged to beg for the spondai/. But in ii.22.15, the words a)nei/lonto tou\s nekrou\s a)spo/ndous show that the defeat was not decisive. See on i.63.17.— 11. o( me\n *gu/lippos: me/n from Vat. referring to o( de\ *niki/as in c. 6. 1.

th=| ta/cei: by his line of battle; instrumental dat. explained by the clause e)nto\s . . . poih/sas, “since he had placed it too far in between the
walls.” With e)nto\s . . . poih/sas cf. i.62.13; 109. 16; v.2.13. See App.

14. nu=n...e)pa/cein : nu=n is not temporal, but, as in nu=n de/, refers to the present case, the experience gained, and is to be closely connected with au)=qis, “he would after this experience again lead them out.” e)pa/gein here and in 20 not “lead to battle,” but = e)ca/gonta parata/ssein (3), “draw up in battle array.”
kai\ dianoei=sqai ou(/tws e)ke/leuen: and he urged them to have this conviction.

w(s...e(/contas : supplementary partic. with w(s. GMT. 113, N. 10 c.—th=| me\n paraskeuh=|: in point of preparation; th=| de\ gnw/mh|, as regarded their determination; the former he himself would attend to, the latter he expected from them.

ou)k a)nekto\n e)so/menon: acc. abs. with w(s, just as above the regular acc. ou)k e)/lasson e(/contas. GMT. 113, N. 10 b, c; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 7, and 14, 2.—ei) mh\ a)ciw/sousi...e)cela/s asqai : “if they should not make it a point of honour to drive them out.” e)cela/sasqai also in iv.35.14. Vat. has e)cela/sesqai, but there is no example of the fut. inf. after a)ciou=n. For the aor. inf., cf. also c. 63. 20; i.74.14; 132. 11; iii.39.20; 40. 24.— *peloponnh/sioi...nhsiwtw=n : chiastic arrangement, since *peloponnh/sioi has almost the force of h)peirw=tai. Cf. vi.77.11, where *dwrih=s e)leu/qeroi a)p' au)tono/mou th=s *peloponnh/sou th\n *sikeli/an oi)kou=ntes are disdainfully contrasted with *)/iwnes kai\ *(ellhspo/ntioi kai\ nhsiw=tai. Here cugklu/dwn is added as more contemptuous than the usual cummi/ktwn (iv.106.4; 109. 10; vi.4.36; 17. 8).

e)peidh\ kairo\s h)=n: the very next day as is proved by th=| u(sterai/a|(ma/xh|), c. 11. 8.—au)=qis e)ph=gen au)tou/s: he led them out again, to show that he was ready for battle, but did not make an attack (hence the impf.). He accepted battle immediately, however, when it was offered by the Athenians.

In the next conflict Gylippus succeeds, by a better arrangement of his troops, in driving the Athenians back behind their fortifications, and immediately thereupon pushes the cross-wall past the wall of the Athenians, so that from this time on the investment of the city is impossible.
1. kai\ ei)...mh\ e)qe/loien : “even if they should not have the courage.”— 2. ma/xhs a)/rxein: as in c. 5. 6, a)/rxein th=s e)fo/dou.

periora=n paroikodo-
mou/menon: the pres. partic. with periora=n indicates continued action, as in i.24.17; 25. 10; 86. 8; the aor. partic. a completed fact. GMT. 112, 1. See on ii.18.21.—to\ tei=xos: = pro\s to\ e)gka/rsion tei=xos a(plou=n of c. 4. 3.— 4. th\n...teleuth/n : the unfinished northern part of the wall of eireumvallation, begun in the direction of Trogilus (vi.99.1), but stopped (vi.101.1) in order first to complete the other side toward the great harbour. Cf. c. 2. 17 ff.

ei) pare/lqoi: so Cl. and St. instead of the vulgate proe/lqoi, as it was not the advance of the cross-wall, but its passing the Athenian wall, that was to be feared. But the change seems to be hardly necessary, for as the cross-wall had already all but passed the Athenian wall (h)/dh . . . o(/son ou) parelhlu/qei), if it moved forward at all, it would pass, and hence it is quite the same whether we have proe/lqoi or pare/lqoi. For the mood, see GMT. 77, 1 c.—tau)to\n h)/dh e)poi/ei...mhde\ ma/xesqai : “in that case (h)/dh) it amounted to the same whether they conquered in every battle or did not fight at all”; for only the completion of the wall of circumvallation could bring about the fall of the city. poiei=n = valere, effect, amount to, as in ii.89.9, and like du/nasqai in i.141.6. The impf. expresses the enduring result of the cond. ei) pare/lqoi.
dia\ panto/s : continually, always of time in Thuc. See on i.38.2.
ma/xesqai: Vat. has a)mu/nesqai with ma/xesqai as marginal reading; but, as St. says, the repetition of ma/xesqai adds force. — ou)=n: after a long parenthesis, as in vi.64.13. See also on iii.95.9.
8. tw=n teixw=n: = tw=n teixisma/twn (c. 5. 7).—h)\ pro/teron: than in the former battle (c. 5. 7).
cune/misgen: prepared for the conflict, impf., as i.62.21.
e)k plagi/ou: so that they might at the favourable moment fall upon the flank of the Athenians.

h(=|...e)/lhgon : Cl. thinks the eu)ruxwri/a means the space between the teleutai/ of the advancing walls. St. adopts Arn.'s view: “The Syracusans front toward the west; their cavalry therefore, being on the right, was on the north of their line. And it was the northern side of Epipolae which presented the greatest extent of clear ground, the finished part of the Athenian line being the southern side towards the cliffs looking to the south.”
13. kat' au)tou/s: opposite them; cf. i.62.24; v.71.22.
kathra/xqh: (Vat.; most of the Mss. katerra/xqh) was driven back, from katara/ssein and corresponding to a)para/chte, c. 63. 4.

kai\...e)/fqasan : immediate result of the victory, “and the very next night the Syracusans accomplished what the Athenians had so much feared” (cf. 5). The important result is stated with esp. emphasis. Cl. does not agree with St. and Bk. in objecting to the more exact explanation of paroikodomh/santes by kai\ parelqo/ntes th\n tw=n *)aqhnai/wn oi)kodomi/an, esp. since parelqei=n was emphasized above (4, 5).

mh/te au)toi\ kwlu/esqai...a)poteixi/sai : their intercourse with the interior could no longer be hindered, and they had deprived the Athenians of all possibility of investing the city. mh/ after a)pesterhke/nai, as i.10.3; ii.101.3; iv.40.5 after a)pistei=n; v.25.11 after a)pe/xesqai; iii.32.14 after e)lpi/da ou)k e)/xein. See Rehdantz on Xen. Anab. iii.5.11. GMT. 95, 2; H. 1029; Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 3; Kühn. 516, 3a. For a)/n, see GMT. 41, 4, N. 4.

Immediately thereafter the expected Corinthian, Ambraciot, and Leucadian ships reach the great harbour of Syracuse, unobserved by the Athenians, and the cross-wall is finished. Gylippus displays the greatest activity in getting reinforcements from all quarters, and the Syracusans are zealously occupied in fitting out their fleet.

1. ai(/ te tw=n *korinqi/wn nh=es kte(.: cf. c. 4. 35, where also h( tw=n *)aqhnai/wn fulakh/ is mentioned. tw=n expressed but once as in i.7.7, etc. The two circumstances so important for the Syracusans, the arrival of the long-expected ships and the activity of Gylippus, are connected by te kai/.

cunetei/xisan : the men from these ships, who now helped to finish the rest of the cross-wall, which had just been carried past the Athenian wall. This sense, which is required by the whole context, is best gained
by following Holm's clear explanation (Sic. H. 392-395) and striking out me/xri, which may have sprung from a misunderstanding of pro\s to\ e)gka/rsion tei=xos a(plou=n (c. 4. 3). to\ loipo/n is to be connected with tou= e)gkarsi/ou tei/xous, just as in c. 71. 34, to\ loipo\n tou= tei/xous; iv.116.13, to\ loipo\n tou= xeimw=nos. The first Syracusan crosswall was also called e)gka/rsion tei=xos (vi.99.16). St., with the approval of Philippi, strikes out me/xri tou= e)gkarsi/ou tei/xous in order to get the same sense. See App.
6. e)pi\ stratia/n: concise expression of purpose (cf. c. 12. 1), which is more definitely explained by kai\ nautikh\n . . . culle/cwn.
te : refers to kai\ tw=n po/lewn below, and should not be struck out, as v. H. thinks.—w)/|xeto: as often, to indicate departure without delay. Cf. i.90.26; 116. 15.

pezikh/n: retained with most of the Mss., instead of pezh/n. See on vi.33.9.—tw=n po/lewn: part. gen. depending on ei)/ tis. Kr. Spr. 60, 10, 1.— 8. prosaco/menos: to bring over, used in same sense in i.99.8; ii.30.7; iii.91.7; iv.86.3.
a)festh/kei: had stood aloof, as in vi.88.22.
a)/lloi: opp. to Gylippus (6); has no reference to the former ambassadors mentioned vi. 75. § 3.
Korinqi/wn: i.e. from the lately arrived ships, who could work the more effectively in their native city.

tro/pw| w(=| a)\n...proxwrh=| : in whatever way might be available, in merchant ships, or small craft, or in any other way that might be convenient. e)n o(lka/sin . . . o(/pws a)/n is to be taken as explanatory of tro/pw| w(=| a)\n proxwrh=|, and proxwrh=| is understood with o(/pws a)/n. See App.

w(s...e)pimetapempome/nwn : since also the Athenians were sending for fresh troops. The direct statement of this is not made till the following chap., but it is here taken for granted as already known.
14. e)plh/roun kai\ a)nepeirw=nto: same phrase in c. 51. 9, and a)napeira=sqai, practise manæuvering, again, c. 12. 16.
e)pe/rrwnto: were encouraged; also c. 17. 10. Cf. c. 2. 9, e)perrw/sqhsan, plucked up courage.

p.hi: Nicias, fully aware of his difficult position, turns with urgent appeals for help to Athens, and in order to leare no ground for a misunderstanding, sets forth his views in detail in a letter.

div2.p: 3. sfete/ran: see on c. 1. 27.

kai\ au)to/s: as the Syracusans had sent to Lacedaemon, which may have happened as well after as before.— e)/pempe...to/te : Cl. takes polla/kis me\n kai\ a)/llote with a)gge/llwn only, ma/lista de\ kai\ to/te with a)gge/llwn e)/pempe; but St.'s view is better: “e)/pempe, imperfectum quod ad polla/kis me\n kai\ a)/llote relatum notionem rei repititae habet, apud ma/lista de\ kai\ to/te sonat mittere parabat.”
kaq' e(/kasta: singula quaeque, taken together, obj. of a)gge/llwn. Cf. i.3.6, kata\ e)/qnh, singulas gentes; i.3.9, kaq' e(ka/stous, singulos quosque; also iv.47.10.

ei) mh\...metape/myousin : Vat. has metape/mywsin, and since Thuc. has one sure example of ei) with the subjv. without a)/n in a case of great uncertainty of the supposition (vi.21.5, possibly i.72.14), perhaps it should not here be unconditionally rejected. See on vi.21.5. Cl. says a)postelou=sin would then indicate that which was more to be desired; but cf. Dem. XVIII. 176.— 8. ou)demi/an ei)=nai swthri/an: the fut. indic. in the prot. and the simple inf. pres. in the apod. correspond to the firm conviction and categorical expression of Nicias. In dir. disc. it would be, ei) mh\ a)postelei=te, ou)demi/a e)sti\ swthri/a. v. H.'s conjecture, ou)demi/an a)\n ei)=nai swthri/an, would weaken the force. Cf. vi.6.19; 91. 13.

9. kata\ th\n tou= le/gein a)dunasi/an: so Vat.; the other Mss. omit th/n; but even if the art. of the governing subst. is often omitted when a gen. goes before (see on vi.88.23), still the omission here would be so strange as to cause obscurity. The unusual form a)dunasi/a for a)dunami/a occurs also viii.8.19.

mnh/mhs e)llipei=s gigno/menoi: so Vat. for gnw/mhs of all the rest of the Mss.: “from defect of memory.” This might very naturally have happened if they had had had to retain everything in memory; for in addition to the letter he told them certain things to be delivered by word of mouth, o(/sa e)/dei au)tou\s ei)pei=n, 16, and o(/sa te a)po\ glw/sshs ei)/rhto au)toi=s, c. 10. 2.

ou(/tws a)
 ma/lista: Cl. says ou(/tws is explained by th
 . . . maqo/ntas, a)
 ma/lista belonging to bouleu/sasqai; better ou(/tws a)
 ma/lista maqo/ntas bouleu/sasqai.

e)n tw=| a)gge/lw| :
belongs with a)fanisqei=san; his view might be obscured “in the messenger” (by his inaccurate comprehension or delivery). Cf. ii.35.7, e)n e(ni\ a)ndri\ pollw=n a)reta\s kinduneu/esqai. On this use of e)n with persons, see Kühn. 431, 1, 3) a.
15. ou(\s a)pe/steile: inserted epexegetically. See App.

o( de\ ta\ kata\ to\ strato/pedon...e)peme/leto : “keeping his army from this time rather on the defensive than on the offensive, he attended to his duties.” ta\ kata\ to\ strato/pedon is obj. of e)/xwn, which must be taken by zeugma also with di) e(kousi/wn kindu/nwn. e)peme/leto (not e)pemelei=to; see on vi.54.26) is used abs. The const. is similar to h(gou=nto with limiting partic. in i.19.2. to\ strato/pedon refers no doubt to the army, not to the camp esp., and so would include the troops in the fortifications on Plemmyrium, as well as those in the main camp. See App.
Attempt of the Athenians to win back Amphipolis.
1. teleutw=nti; when it was near the end, pred. Cf. i.30.13.—*eu)eti/wn: not elsewhere mentioned.

meta\ *perdi/kkou: as the help of Thracian Chalcidians held out to him by the Lacedaemonians had not come, Perdiccas had no doubt, though no mention is made of it, made peace and alliance with the Athenians, in order that his country might no longer be exposed to hostilities from them (cf. vi. 7. § 3, 4). See Weissenborn, Hellen. Beitr. p. 173, and Introd. to Book V. p. 19 ff.
*qra|ci polloi=s: without doubt mercenaries from the surrounding regions. Cf. c. 27. § 1; v. 6. § 2.
perikomi/sas: doubtless out of the port Eion. Cf. iv.106.17; v.6.2; 10. 16.—e)k tou= potamou=: belongs to e)polio/rkei.
*(imerai/ou : not otherwise known. Weissenborn says, “Probably on the right bank of the river above the bridge.”
The letter of Nicias reaches Athens and is read in the Popular Assembly.
2. a)po\ glw/sshs: orally; just so Hdt. i.123.20.

ei)/ ti/s ti e)phrw/ta:
(Vat. for h)rw/ta) if any one asked further questions. To the impf. of the prot. corresponds also in the apod. a)pekri/nonto (Vat., for a)pekri/nanto of most of the Mss.).
o( grammateu\s o( th=s po/lews: cf. Poll. viii. 98, o( u(po\ tou= dh/mon ai(reqei\s grammateu\s a)nagignw/skei tw=| dh/mw| kai\ th=| boulh=|. v. H. and St. omit o( th=s po/lews.
dhlou=san : of the contents of a letter. Cf. c. 16. 1; i.129.1; 137. 22.

div2.head: LETTER OF NICIAS TO THE DEMOS AT ATHENS.
div2.p: Although we were very successful at first, a change has taken place since the arrival of Gylippus. Having lost the last battle we have had to withdraw behind our fortifications, and are now rather in the condition of besieged than of besiegers.

1. e)n a)/llais pollai=s e)pistolai=s i)/ste: e)n, where we expect e)k, is due possibly to the original pf. meaning of ei)de/nai: “you have seen (read) in many letters.” Kühn. 431, 1, 3) a. Kr. compares Dem. XLIV. 60, memaqh/kate e)n toi=s e)n a)rxh=| ei)rhme/nois. Cf. Cic. de Nat. D. i.26.72, ut videmus in scriptis. Compare also the use of e)n in expressions of decisive authority, as iii.53.3. pollai=s (which Vat. omits no doubt only in consequence of the similar endings) helps to give point to the following ou)x h(=sson = ma/lista: “you have frequently had information; now, however, it is more important than ever that you learn the truth and determine accordingly.” Cf. c. 8. 4.
e)n w(=| e)sme/n: in what condition we are. Cf. c. 14. 12; vi.6.30. For neut. of pron. to indicate condition, measure, degree, etc., see Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 4 and 22.
4. ma/xais tai=s plei/osi: order as in 8, ma/xh| th=| prw/th|, i.1.6, paraskeuh=| th=| pa/sh|, and i.11.13, me/rei tw=| a)ei\ paro/nti.

*surakosi/ous : Thuc. construes kratei=n, when connected with ma/xh| (i.108.18; vi.2.26) or maxo/menon (ii.39.14; iv.67.29), with the acc.; so also sometimes when ma/xh| is not expressed, but the whole context points to it (as ii.39.18; iii.99.3); otherwise always with the gen.

ta\ tei/xh: taken strictly in point of time (oi)kodomhsame/nwn . . . h)=lqe *gu/lippos), it would refer only to the wall of circumvallation, so far as it was finished, and to the round fort on Epipolae; but e)n oi(=sper nu=n e)sme/n and the following a)nexwrh/samen e)s ta\ tei/xh show that also the three forts built on Plemmyrium after the arrival of Gylippus are included.
th=| u(sterai/a|: “in the battle on the next day.” See on c. 5. 20, and Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 34. Cf. Plut. Nic. 19, ei)s th\n e)piou=san h(me/ran kte(.

11. to\ plh=qos: “the superior number,” as in iv.10.16. This superiority is explained by ou)de\ ga\r . . . tou= o(plitikou=, since always a part of the foot-force was occupied in guarding the walls (here esp. the wall of circumvallation).
parw|kodomh/kasin: cf. c. 6. 16.

mh\ ei)=nai: = mh\ parei=nai (or as Vat. reads, mh\ dunato\n ei)=nai). Cf. ii.97.23; v.40.10. ei)=nai in this sense always with the neg.— h)\n mh/ tis: only here in Thue.—to\ paratei/xisma: here, and in c. 43. 7, 35, the Syracusan cross-wall (to\ e)gka/rsion tei=xos, c. 7. 5) since now it had passed the Athenian peritei/xisma (vi.101.5).
17. a)/llous: obj. of poliorkei=n, h(ma=s au)tou\s subj. of pa/sxein. Compare similar order in c. 75. 40.
o(/sa ge: restrictive, as in iv.48.24; viii.70.5. Kr. Spr. 62, 1, 4.—th=s xw/ras: part. gen. depending on e)pi\ polu/. G. 168; H. 730 e. Cf. c. 38. 1; 39. 4; 40. 18; 65. 7; i.50.6; iv.3.11.
e)pi\ polu/: in local sense, over a great extent. Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 3.

The Syracusans are doing everything to reinforce their land troops and to practise their fleet for an attack, while our fleet, continually on duty and constantly expecting an attack, never has time for rest and repairs.
1. pepo/mfasi...oi)/xetai : cf. c. 7. § 2, 3.—e)p' a)/llhn stratia/n: cf. c. 7. 6.
kai/: more closely connected with cumpolemei=n.

a)po\ de\ tw=n : position as in iii.61.6; vi.45.5; 66. 6. Kr. Spr. 50, 1, 13.—e)/ti kai\ stratia/n: still more troops. Cf. c. 2. 7; 34.
5.—nautikou= paraskeuh/n: as in ii.62.14; = pareskeuasme/non nautiko/n. Cf. trih/rwn paraskeuh/, iii.39.7.
6. w(s...punqa/nomai : the pres., as in 9 and vi.17.18, of information repeatedly received.
peira=n: with the gen., as in i.61.13. In the second clause peira=n is used abs., being only locally defined by kata\ qa/lassan, which is opp. to tw=n teixw=n.

deino/n: incredible; cf. iii.57.8.— 8. o(/ti kai\ kata\ qa/lassan: sc. peira=n dianoou=ntai. An attack in the open sea, not on Plemmyrium, is meant. 9. h(=|per: hardly necessary, with Cl., to supply gene/sqai. h(=|per refers to the change that had taken place, and points therefore esp. to the second clause, nu=n de\ . . . e)/fqartai.

th=| chro/thti : opp. to dia/broxoi (in 11), the good condition of ships, when the wood is not thoroughly soaked from lying too long in the water. The means to preserve this condition is a)nelku/santas diayu/cai (13), or a)pochra=nai (17), which had not been possible for more than a year now (from July, 415—vi. 30—to September, 414 B.C.). Cf. Poll. i. 121, kai\ ai( me\n a)qala/sseutoi kai\ a)kraifnei=s kai\ chrai\ dieyugme/nai, ai( de\ e)nteqalatteukui=ai, di/ugroi, a)raiai/, dia/broxoi.
tw=n plhrwma/twn th=| swthri/a| : in the unimpaired condition of the crews. Cf. c. 4. § 6.

ai(/ te nh=es...e)/fqartai : ai(/ te nh=es . . . qalasseu/ousai is explained from 13 to c. 13. 5, kai\ ta\ plhrw/mata e)/fqartai from c. 13. 5 to the end of the chap. We see thereby how inaptly the connexion is broken by the division of the chaps.—dia/broxoi: not leaky, but water-logged. Dukas explains well, dia\ pollou= qalasseu/ousai e)pi\ polu\ diugra/nqhsan ka)nteu=qen barei=ai geno/menai duski/nhtoi h)=san. See on 10.
13. diayu/cai: accent acc. to Herodian. Cf. cummi/cai, ii.84.34, and prosmi/cai, iii.31.13. See App. on ii.84.34.
kai\ e)/ti plei/ous: the correct reading, from Vat. only, instead of kai\ o(/ti plei/ous, adds force to a)ntipa/lous tw=| plh/qei . . . ou)/sas, since they are equal in number and even superior.

16. a)napeirw/menai: (Vat., all the rest a)popeirw/menai) see on c. 7. 14.—
e)p' e)kei/nois: in their power. Kr. Spr. 68, 41, 9. See on vi.22.13. St. (who, following Codex M. in the Brit. Mus., omits e)cousi/a in 14) is wrong in extending the force of e)p' e)kei/nois to a)pochra=nai. ma=llon requires a more definite expression than e)p' e)kei/nois, they have, more than we, opportunity for drying their ships.
ou) ga\r e)formou=sin a)/llois: sc. w(/sper ai( h(me/terai, they are not obliged (as are our ships) to watch others.

But we dare not relax our watchfulness, on account of the difficulty of getting supplies. The army suffers loss, moreover, partly from sudden attacks of the enemy's cavalry, partly from the desertion of those who came with us either through compulsion or in hope of gain.
1. e)k pollh=s periousi/as new=n: lit., from a great numerical superiority in ships, i.e. even if we had such superiority. e)k of the consequence as in i.2.17; 75. 7; ii.33.12.
tou=to: sc. to\ a)pochrai/nein ta\s nau=s.

kai\ mh\ a)nagkazome/nois : with e)k pollh=s perionsi/as forming the prot. to a)\n u(ph=rxe. The difficulty attending the a)nelku/santas diayu/cai even with a greater number of ships (mo/lis a)\n tou=to u(ph=rxe) was shown in c. 12. § 4.
w(/sper nu=n: sc. a)nagkazo/meqa, explained by ei) ga\r a)fairh/some/n ti . . . e)skomizo/menoi.
pa/sais : with all (the ships), the military dat., as in i.49.18, and often.—a)fairh/some/n ti kai\ braxu/: leave off even a little.
para\ th\n e)kei/nwn po/lin: i.e. along by Syracuse, in sailing into the great harbour.
e)skomizo/menoi: sc. ta\ e)pith/deia. Cf. vi.22.6.

ta\ de\ plhrw/mata: see on c. 4. 27.— 6. dia\ to/de: set forth in the following up to the end of the chap., first in gen. abs. (tw=n me\n . . . a)pollume/nwn), then in dir. disc. (oi( de\ qera/pontes . . . au)tomolou=si kte(.). For similar cases of anacoluthon, see c. 15. § 2; 47. § 2.—e)fqa/rh, fqei/retai: the former referring to the cases that had already occurred (cf. c. 4. § 6), the latter to the continuance of the bad state of affairs.

tw=n nautw=n: the part. gen. placed first, including all the following parts, tw=n me/n, oi( de\ qera/pontes, and oi( ce/noi. This last is subdivided into oi( me/n (10), oi( de/ (11), and oi( de/ is further divided into oi( me/n (15), oi( de/ (15) and ei)si\ d' oi(/ (16). The nau=tai include e)piba/tai as well as e)re/tai. The most of the latter consist of qera/pontes and ce/noi. Cf. i.143.3, tou\s ce/nous tw=n nautw=n, and vi.31.23, toi=s qrani/tais tw=n nautw=n. Acc. to this view, tw=n before me/n in 7 is not to be omitted.

ma-
kra/n: adv. with a)pollume/nwn (“at a distance from their camp”), and rightly placed in Vat. after u(drei/an, not after a(rpagh/n. It would seem, however, to have esp. reference to u(drei/an if we compare c. 4. 29, u(/dati spani/w| xrw/menoi kai\ ou)k e)ggu/qen. The Schol. explains, a(rpagh\n makra/n: dia\ to\ e)pi\ pollou= diasth/matos e)f' a(rpagh\n e)cie/nai; but no doubt wrongly.

oi( qera/pontes: this term, which is used elsewhere (iv.16.9) only of the attendants of the Spartan hoplites, seems to refer here to the qh=tes, who were pressed for rowing, and bondmen. So Cl.; but prob. all, or most, were a)ndra/poda. See Boeckh, Public Economy of the Athenians, p. 360 ff.

e)peidh\ e)s a)nti/pala kaqesth/kamen: since we are reduced to an equality (with the Syracusans), i.e. since the prospect of a speedy victory has been lost. The same idea is expressed in other words in 13, e)peidh\ para\ gnw/mhn . . . a)nqestw=ta o(rw=sin.— 10. a)nagkastoi/: pred. with e)sba/ntes, as in c. 58. 17 with strateu/ontes. G. 138, N. 7; H. 619.
oi)o/menoi xrhmatiei=sqai: cf. vi.31.42.
a)po\ tw=n polemi/wn: on the part of the enemy.

e)p' au)tomoli/as profa/sei: on any occasion for deserting (to the enemy), i.e. whenever the deserters thought themselves unobserved by the Athenians, or found themselves unexpectedly in the neighbourhood of the Syracusan troops. pro/fasis, not of the pretended, but of the real occasion, as in i.23.23; 118. 3, and freq. See App.

w(s e(/kastoi du/nantai: i.e. as any opportunity offered of fleeing, without exactly going over to the enemy.—pollh\ d' h( *sikeli/a: epexegetical, just as v.110.1. pollh/ is here used as in Plat. Phaed. 78 a, pollh\ h( *(ella/s; Theocr. 22. 156, polla/ toi *spa/rta, polla\ d) . . . *)=alis.

au)toi\ e)mporeuo/menoi : (so Vat., the remaining Mss. au)tou=) while they devote themselves to merchandising, which, acc. to vi.31.42, many had made their object in the expedition. kai/ belongs to the whole clause a)ndra/poda . . . a)fh/|rhntai. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 15.—a)ndra/poda *(ukkarika/: inhabitants of the little town Hyccara, whom Nicias had sold as slaves (vi. 62. § 3). Of the crews, some that had gone out with money for the purpose of trading utilized the opportunity to buy men of Hyccara; and, with the consent of the trierarchs, put them in the naval service in their own places. These occurrences happened, doubt
less, in the autumn of 415 B.C., and the mention of them implies a complaint on the part of Nicias against the negligence of some of the trierarchs.

th\n a)kri/beian tou= nautikou=: the strict discipline of the naval service, which was disturbed by the mixing in of strange elements. a)kri/beia corresponds to a)kribe/s of vi.55.16. Cf. Arr. Anab. ii.21.9, a)kribesta/tois toi=s plhrw/masi.

The number of troops that can be depended on is small. I myself am not able to prevent the evils, and repair our losses. In Sicily we have only weak allies, and our supplies are threatened. However gloomy all this is, it is my duty to tell you the truth.
1. e)pistame/nois: the partic, is the important word, “you yourselves know best what I write to you.” Cf. iii.53.14.

braxei=a a)kmh/: understood by the Schol. of the short duration of the good condition of a crew. This seems to be correct, and so Bl., Kr. and Arn. explain. But acc. to Bauer, Cl. and St. the sense is: “the really efficient part of a ship's crew is always small.”

oi( e)cormw=ntes...th\n ei)resi/an : the two expressions (co-ord. by te kai/) bring together the two most important qualifications of an oarsman, which are in a certain degree opp. to each other: not only to start a ship (properly) (e)corma=n), but to keep the rowing in order (cune/xein). Cf. Poll. i. 123, ta\ de\ e)/rga a)na/gesqai, prosanapeira=sqai, e)corma=n th\n nau=n. St., however, understands the sense to be: who so impel a boat with oars as to keep time in rowing.
4. tou/twn de\ pa/ntwn: sc. a)po/rwn o)/ntwn, covering all back to c. 12. § 3, and repeated in the following tau=ta.

e)moi/ : on the dat. after oi(=o/n te ei)=nai instead of the subj. acc. with the inf., see Kühn. 585, note 2.—xalepai\ a)/rcai: inf. act. where we use pass. G. 261, 2, Rem.; H. 952 a; Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 7. See on vi.42.8, r(a/|ous a)/rxein.
ai( u(me/terai fu/seis : ingenia vestra. Cf. Ar. Pax, 607, ta\s fu/seis u(mw=n . . . kai\ to\n au)toda\c tro/pon.

e)piplhrwsw/meqa : fill up; e)pi- as in e)piskena/zein, c. 1. 2; vi.104.20; e)pipe/mpein, vi.73.10; e)pimanqa/nein, i.138.12. Cl. writes e)piplhrws w/ meqa (deliberative subj.), for e)piplhrws o/ meqa, acc. to analogy of ii.52.11; iv.28.16; v.65.21. But while Thuc. might of course have written the subjv. it is not abs. necessary. Besides, the Schol. explains, ta\ plhrw/mata a)naplhrw/somen. See on i.91.4. For the deliberative subjv., see Kr. Spr. 54, 7, 2; Kühn. 394, note 3. For fut., see
Kr. Spr. 53, 7, 8.

a)f) w(=n...gi/gnesqai : the sense is, “as we must supply the losses from the troops brought with us, so must what remains suffice for the service without compensation for the losses.” The reference is only to the crews ta\ plhrw/mata (not to war supplies). The art. not repeated with a)panalisko/mena, as in c. 7. 1; i.7.7; iv.25.8.
11. e(\n e)/ti: only one thing more, explained in the following w(/ste . . . xwrh=sai. The aor. inf. makes vivid the threatening danger.

kai\ u(mw=n mh\ e)pibohqou/ntwn: although in the gen. abs., to be taken with o(rw=nta, as te kai/ shows: “when they see in what condition we are and (that this is so) while you do not come to our aid.” Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.

pro\s e)kei/nous xwrh=sai: go over to them, as in i.18.28; v.22.11; 43. 6.— diapepolemh/setai au)toi=s: the fut. pf. of Vat., stronger than diapolemh/setai of the other Mss., “they will have ended the war.” Kr. Spr. 53, 9, 3. Acc. to the like expression in c. 25. 46, o( po/lemos could be spared here, and Kr. and St. omit it. But it is the reading of all the Mss., and as opp. to a)maxei/ is not without force: “an end would, without a battle, be put to the whole war.” See App.
e)kpoliorkhqe/ntwn: cf. c. 11. § 4.
17. ta\ e)nqa/de: corresponding to e)n w(=| e)/smen in c. 11. 3.
a)p' au)tw=n: sc. tw=n h(di/stwn, a(\ a)kou/ein bou/lesqe, with which o(moi=on has the meaning correspondingly. Cf. ii.54.16.
h(ghsa/mhn: aor., anticipating the time of reading. GMT. 17, 2, N. 5; H. 838; Kr. Spr. 53, 10, 1.

p.hi: Therefore you must not reproach us, but either recall the army, or send out a new one, equally strong and supplied with all that is necessary. And send me a successor, since I am enfeebled by sickness. Whatever you determine to do.
however, must be carried out as speedily as possible; for in delay is the greatest danger.

div2.p: 1. w(s...gegenhme/nwn : be of this opinion, that with regard to the object of our expedition neither the soldiers nor the generals ought to be blamed by you. For gen. abs. with verb of knowing, see GMT. 113, N. 10 b, c; Kühn. 488, 1 b b. The neg. is mh/ because the leading verb is imv. Kühn. 515, 3. e)f' a(\ h)=lqomen to\ prw=ton, i.e. to war with Syracuse alone.
ou(/tw: emphasizing the idea of the partic. clause. Kühn. 486, note 5. Cf. i.22.8; 37. 4; vi.24.3.—*sikeli/a a(/pasa cuni/statai: as was predicted vi.37.16, custh/setai ga/r.

prosdo/kimos, au)toi\ bouleu/sasqe...a)ntarkou/ntwn : this reading of Vat. is to be preferred to prosdo/kimos au)toi=s, bouleu/esqe of the rest of the Mss. The main stress of the sent. is on au)toi\ bouleu/sasqe, and indeed only the aor. imv. is compatible with h)/dh: “do you yourselves make up your minds at once, understanding that the troops which we have here certainly are not a match for even our present enemies.”—tw=n e)nqa/de, toi=s parou=sin: are both neut., referring to the still remaining force of the Athenians and the already strongly developed power of the Syracusans.
a)ntarkou/ntwn: Schol. a)nte/xein duname/nwn.
metape/mpein : recall, as in c. 8. 7.
e)pipe/mpein: as in vi.73.10. See on c. 14. 6. The alliteration in metape/mpein and e)pipe/mpein was observed by the old rhetoricians.
e)moi/ te: with Vat., instead of e)moi\ de/, acc. to the usage of Thuc., since it is after stratia/ and xrh/mata, the third demand. Cf. i.33.6; 67. 6; 69. 3; 76. 12.
dia/doxo/n tina: not any successor, but some one (another) as successor.—dia\ no/son nefri=tin: also mentioned by Plut. Nic. 17.
10. u(mw=n: dependent on cuggnw/mhs, but, as its position shows, not confined to the force of the possessive: “I expect to receive from you an indulgent judgment.”
eu)= e)poi/hsa: of politieal services, corresponding to eu)erge/ths in i.136.2; ii.27.9.
me/llete: sc. pra/ssein.

mh\ e)s a)nabola/s : = mhde\n a)naballo/menoi, without delay. Cf. c. 70. 49, mh\ di)
a)na/gkhn; Hdt. viii.21.11, ou)ke/ti e)s a)nabola\s e)poiou=nto th\n a)naxw/rhsin. For other similar consts., see on v.8.12.

w(s...fqh/sontai : Cl. explains: w(s as causal conj. introduces the rest of the sent.; the partic. clauses end with o(/mws de/ (sc. porioume/nwn with o(/mws de/ as well as with ta\ d' e)k *peloponnh/sou) and the main sent. is h)\n mh\ . . . fqh/sontai. But more probably w(s belongs to the gen. abs. G. 277, N. 2 a; H. 978. With ta\ d' e)k *peloponnh/sou sxolai/teron me/n sc. porioume/nwn, but after o(/mws de/ there is a change of const. to finite verb, as in c. 13. 9. With lh/sousin . . . fqh/sontai we must supply porisa/menoi. Kr. Spr. 56, 16 A.
w(/sper kai\ pro/teron: contains a reproach against the Athenians for not hindering the Peloponnesians from sending ships before (vi. 93. § 2, 3).

In consequence of this letter, the Athenians appoint from those in the army two men to share the command temporarily with Nicias, and determine to send him strong reinforcements of ships and troops, as well as of money. Demosthenes and Eurymedon are chosen generals, and the latter sets sail for Sicily in the beginning of the winter.
2. ou) pare/lusan th=s a)rxh=s: did not release from his office. The verb occurs also in viii.54.9.

au)tou= e)kei=: emphatic designation of place, on the very spot. Observe the use of the corresponding prons. au)to\s e)kei=nos in c. 1. 8. Cf. Soph. O. C. 78, tw=n e)nqa/d' au)tou=; Hdt. i.189.20, au)tou=tau/th|; v.19.7, au)tou= th=|de. The Schol. is therefore wrong in explaining, tw=n stratiwtw=n au)tou=, h)/goun tou= *niki/ou. tw=n au)tou= e)kei= means out of the number of men of prominence present with the army before Syracuse. Of the two, only Euthydemus has been mentioned before (v.19.9; 24. 6).
o(/pws...talaipwroi/h : that he might not have to bear the burden alone in his sickness, the no/sos nefri=tis of c. 15. 9.

e)peyhfi/santo: Vat., instead of e)yhfi/santo. e)pi- has the same force as in e)piplhrosw/meqa, c. 14. 6. The compound is found certainly in Aeschin. 11. 68; elsewhere the Mss. are uncertain (e.g. Xen. Anab. vii.6.14).

e)k katalo/gou: i.e. from the military list of the three highest classes of citizens.
See on vi.43.9.
*dhmosqe/nhn: last in active service, iv. 66-69.— *eu)rume/donta: after the unsuccessful expedition in Sicily in the year 424 B.C., he had been punished with a fine (iv.65.12).
10. ta\s xeimerina/s: Diod. (xiii. 8) wrongly says ta\s qerina\s tropa/s. Cf. Plut. Nic. 20, dia\ xeimw=nos.

ei)/kosi ta/lanta : that this sum did not in the remotest degree suffice for the necessities of Nicias is clear; for 20 talents were only a month's pay for 20 ships. Valla gives centum viginti; Diod. xiii. 8, e(kato\n tessara/konta. Hence Boeekh (P. E. p. 395) conjectures that Eurymedon first carried over 20 talents, Demosthenes later (c. 20. § 2) 120 talents. This view might seem to be favoured by the promise o(/ti . . . e)pime/leia au)tw=n e)/stai. But it is hardly possible that Thuc. should have mentioned the smaller sum and said nothing of the larger. The best solution of the difficulty seems to be, with Kr. and St., to follow Valla and one Ms. (h; Cl. says no Ms. has e(kato/n) and read ei)/kosi kai\ e(kato/n.
During the winter the Athenians on the one side and the Peloponnesians on the other carry on with equal zeal their preparations for the Sicilian War.

1. u(pome/nwn: remaining behind. Cf. iii.35.7; iv.90.20; v.14.18; vi.98.15.—pareskeua/zeto: takes a combination of two common consts., the simple noun-obj. (to\n e)/kploun, as in ii.56.3; v.10.1) and the fut. partic. with w(s (c. 41. 15; ii.7.2; iv.8.16). to\n e)/kploun is to be supplied with poihso/menos.

e)pagge/llwn : imperans, as in iii.16.16; viii.108.21. Cf. c. 18. 27, si/dhron perih/ggellon kata\ tou\s cumma/xons; also ii.85.11. e)pagge/llwn includes the force also of pe/myas, exactly opp. to a)pagge/llwn.
au)to/qen : sc. e)c *)aqhnw=n. The Schol. wrongly explains, a)po\ tw=n cumma/xwn.
4. pe/mpousi peri\ th\n *pelopo/nnhson: having learned a lesson from their former negligence (see on c. 15. 16), they send these ships on the usual peri/plous (cf. i.107.13; ii.23.5; 69. 2).
fula/ssoien mhde/na...peraiou=sqai : cf. ii.69.3, fulakh\n ei)=xe mh/t' e)kplei=n. The const. of mh/ with inf. is the same as with kwlu/ein. See on c. 6. 19.
7. au)toi=s oi( pre/sbeis h(=kon: h(=kon with the dat. as h(=lqon in c. 75. 5. See on i.13.12. On the reading, see App.
belti/w: sc. ei)=nai. Cf. Eur. Hec. 423, a)/ggelle pasw=n a)qliwta/thn e)me/.

ou)k a)/kairon...poih/sasqai : = ou)k a)kai/rws pro/teron ta\s nau=s pe/myai. The const. of nomi/santes . . . poih/sasqai is the same as that of h(ghsa/menoi i(erw=sqai in v.1.3. pe/myis is unusual; found in Thuc. only here, in Hdt. viii.54.3. The reference is to the sending out of Gylippus, vi.93.8.

e)n o(lka/si...pe/myontes : the use of common merchant vessels for the transport of troops is marked as unusual by the position of the word. o(lka/si coming first, the contrasted nau=s (i.e. trih/reis, in 13) has the same position. The use of the same method of transportation by the Lacedaemonians (tw=| au)tw=| tro/pw|) is also emphasized, and certainly more effectually by the new partic. pe/myontes (after a)postelou=ntes), to which v. H. objects without sufficient grounds. o(pli/tas is obj. of both partics.

14. o(/pws...a)popeira/swsi...kai\ kwlu/oien : the same change of mood as in iii.22.39; vi.96.18, 19. GMT. 44, 2, N. 1; Kühn. 553, 6. The first verb (aor.) refers to the act contemplated, the second (pres.) to its enduring result.

pro\s th\n e)n th=| *naupa/ktw| fulakh/n: against the Athenian squadron, generally 20 triremes, stationed on guard here during the whole war. Cf. ii.69.1; 80. 21.— 16. ta\s o(lka/das au)tw=n: the merchant vessels which were to transport their troops. au)tw=n instead of sfw=n, although sfete/ran follows. Cf. i.95.8.

pro\s th\n sfete/ran a)nti/tacin tw=n trih/rwn: a)nti/tacin is used in a proleptic sense, i.e. against their triremes whenever they (the Corinthians) should have arrayed themselves with these against them. The connexion is made clearer by the fact that the possessive pron. (sfete/ran, referring to the Corinthians) is placed with the verbal noun and not with trih/rwn, to which it really belongs. Kr. Spr. 51, 4, 7.
poiou/menoi: modifies *)aqhnai=oi.

The Lacedaemonians make preparations to invade Attica the next spring, and, on the adrice of Aleibiades, to establish themselves in Decelea. And they enter upon this undertaking with so much the greater confidence because they consider that the Athenians had broken the treaty of peace by the inroad on the coast of Laconia the year before (vi. 105).
1. pareskeua/zonto: continues per epanaphoram the account of c. 17. 11.

w(/sper proede/dokto...e)nago/ntwn : cf. vi. 93. § 1, 2. au)toi=s, as opp. to *surakosi/wn kai\ *korinqi/wn,= ipsis. The two clauses also are placed in opposition by te kai/. We should expect kai\ e)nh=gon instead of the gen. abs. For change of const., see Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 4.
e)peidh\ e)punqa/nonto: closely connected with e)nago/ntwn: “as soon as they (the Corinthians and Syracusans) received information of the new preparations of the Athenians to send aid into Sicily.”

th\n a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn boh/qeian: as in c. 42. 2; ii.92.21. Cf. also ii.86.22, pri/n ti a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn e)pibohqh=sai. Bk. wishes in all these places *)aqhnw=n, but a)po/ seems more appropriate with the name of the people.
dh/: in explanatory subord. clause, as in i.24.5; iv.23.6; vi.92.19.—diakwluqh=|: the subj. is h( boh/qeia.
proskei/menos : instans. Cf. viii.52.15.—e)di/daske: const. like keleu/ein, as also in i.136.9; iv.46.18; 83. 11.
mh\ a)nei=nai: the aor. (Vat.) makes the admonition just at this moment more urgent than the vulgate mh\ a)nie/nai.

8. tis r(w/mh: a sort of self-confidence. Cf. c. 42. 14. Neither the noun nor the corresponding verb ever signifies, Cl. holds, organic strength alone; they always refer esp. to the disposition of the mind. See App. on vi.31.3.
eu)kaqairetwte/rous: found only here in Thuc.; from kaqairei=n (pull down, iii.13.32; v.14.14; vi.83.6) and corresponding to the verbal adj. kaqairete/a (i.118.16).

o(/ti te: occurs also in vi.83.1. te (only in Vat.) and kai/ emphasize prop. the two different charges (cf. ii. 2 ff.),
the wrongful entry of the Thebans into Plataea, and the refusal of an adjustment by law on the part of the Lacedaemonians.

ei)rhme/non: acc. abs., as in c. 77. 32; i.140.13; v.30.9; 39. 12. GMT. 110, 2; H. 973; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 5.—e)n tai=s pro/teron cunqh/kais: referring to the triakontou/teis spondai/ of i.115.2. The adv. pro/teron merely indicates the time of the cunqh=kai; the adj. would contrast these cunqh=kai with others. Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 6. Cf. i.23.1; ii.87.32.
au)toi/: sc. oi( *lakedaimo/nioi.
e)s di/kas...tw=n *)aqhnai/wn : cf. i. 78. § 4; 145.
ei)ko/tws: deservedly.—e)nequmou=nto: here and in v.32.5=e)nqu/mion e)poiou=nto (c. 50. 29), “they considered the misfortune as a result of their guilt.”
ei)/ tis...ge/noito : of the freq. misfortunes, “any other that had happened to them.” General cond. GMT. 51; H. 894, 2. St.'s reading e)ge/neto (with one Ms.) is simpler.
19. tai=s tria/konta nausi/n: the expedition of Pythodorus and others (vi. 105), concerning which Thuc. observed (l.c.), ta\s sponda\s fanerw/tata . . . e)/lusan.
e)c *)/argous : added only in Vat., but indispensable with o(rmw/menoi. In vi.105.13, although it is not expressly stated, it is clearly implied in the context.
e)lh/|steuon: so Vat., for the mid. e)lh|steu/onto of the rest of the Mss., which Thuc. never uses.
kata\ ta\s sponda/s: in the treaty of peace of B.C. 424. Cf. v. 18 ff.
e)pitre/pein: to submit to arbitration. Cf. i.28.9; iv.83.10; v.31.14.
h(ma/rthto: pass., as in ii.65.45.

to\ au)to/: Cl. takes it as pred., and refers to c. 21. 17; ii.40.12; iii.21.10; but none of these is exactly parallel. It seems rather to be an emphatic repetition of to\ parano/mhma. Kr. Spr. 51, 5, 1.—periesta/nai: change round, shift. Generally it means to pass over into another form and manner, as in i.32.15; 120. 27; vi.24.6, polu\ de\ ma=llon w(/rmhnto kai\ tou)nanti/on perie/sth au)tw=|.
27. si/dhron: as in iv.69.6; vi.88.38, iron tools, such as were necessary in wall-building and in sieges. The term is sidh/ria in iv.4.5.
perih/ggellon: here and ii.85.11 with the acc., as e)pagge/llein in c. 17. 2; elsewhere with the inf. (i.116.5; ii.10.2; 80. 13; iv.8.5; v.54.8; vi.88.35).
e)po/rizon: they were procuring, sc. th\n e)pikouri/an, which is also to be supplied with a)pope/myontes.

proshna/gkazon : sc. pori/zein, the same brachylogy as with o(ra=n, i.78.10; ii.86.14. pros- has the same strengthening force as in iii.61.14; iv.87.8; v.42.19; viii.76.32. See on prosbiasqe/n, i.106.2.

At the beginning of spring, Attica is invaded and Decelea occupied and fortified. At the same time, the Lacedaemonians, Boeotians, Corinthians, and Sicyonians send fresh troops to the Syracusans. The transports which convey these depart unmolested on their voyage, being protected by the 25 triremes of the Corinthians, which hold in check the Attie ships at Naupactus.
1. tou= e)pigignome/nou h)=ros eu)qu\s a)rxome/nou prw/|tata: see App.
e)s th\n *)attikh\n e)se/balon: on the significance of this invasion in determining the periods of the Peloponnesian War, see App. to v.25.10.

ta\ peri\ to\ pedi/on: peri/ of a geographical designation without defined limits. See on i.5.17. The level country is meant which stretches from the western border of Attica up toward the Parnes mountain range, called also pedia/s and meso/gaia. See Bursian, Geogr. von Griechenland, I. p. 263. Where the road to Boeotia cuts through the eastern Parnes, almost due north from Athens, at the highest point of the pass (now called *klhdi/) on the site of the present village of Tatói, lies Decelea, where the Lacedaemonians built the Epiteichismos. See Bursian, I. p. 335.

kata\ po/leis dielo/menoi to\ e)/rgon; as in ii.78.4,
dielo/menoi kata\ po/leis to\ xwrio/n. Cf. ii.75.11; iv.69.10; v.75.22; 114. 3.

8. paraplh/sion: often joined with more or less similar expressions, as o(moi=a kai\ paraplh/sia, i.140.5; i)/son kai\ paraplh/sion, c. 42. 10; toiau=ta kai\ paraplh/sia, c. 78. 4; i.22.18; paraplh/siai kai\ e)/ti plei/ous, iii.17.3. Hence the addition kai\ ou) pollw=| ple/on is not objectionable here. The geographical designation, however, causes some difficulty, for the nearest border of Bocotia is by no means 120 stadia distant. The measurement was prob. taken on the road most used by the Athenians, that to Oropus, which was then in their possession.

e)pi\ tw=| pedi/w|...w)|kodomei=to to\ tei=xos : e)pi/ with the dat. in the hostile sense of e)piteixi/zein, c. 47. 15, and e)piteixismo/s, c. 18. 29; 28. 13, and of th=| xw/ra| e)pw|kei=to, c. 27. 11. e)s to\ kakourgei=n is added to explain the object still more clearly. Cf. vi.12.11, e)s to\ a)/rxein. St. and Kr. strike out e)s to\ kakourgei=n.
th=s xw/ras toi=s krati/stois : the most fruitful parts of the Mesogaia, between Thria, Acharnae, Cephissia, and Oenoë, which on this very account were liable e)s to\ kakourgei=n.
e)pifane/s : visible. See on vi.96.10. Cf. Xen.Hell. i.1.35, *)/agis de\ e)k th=s *dekelei/as i)dw\n ploi=a polla\ si/tou ei)s *heiraia= kataqe/onta.

13. a)pe/stellon: were dispatching. Cf. c. 20. 7; ii.85.10.—tai=s o(lka/si: without the e)n of c. 7. 12; 17. 10; 18. 30; 50. 6. The dat. indicates here, as in 29 below, the unusual means of transportation.
tou\s o(pli/tas: those mentioned in c. 17. 4.
tw=n *ei(lw/twn...tou\s belti/stous : this use of Helots for foreign wars seems to have become customary after it had been introduced by Brasidas (iv. 80. § 2).

neodamw/dwn: the class of new citizens formed of Helots emancipated for service in war. Cf. c. 58. 12; viii.5.7. They are first mentioned in v.34.6. See Schoemann, Griech. Alterthümer, I. p. 205 ff. The accent is acc. to Herod. I. 428, 13.

19. e)n toi=s prw=toi: so Bk. and the
later editt., against the Mss., following the constant usage of Thuc. The phrase means inter primos, and occurs nine times in Thuc. H. 652 a; Kühn. 349^{b}, 7. See on i.6.6. Acc. to c. 17. 13, 25, ships had already been dispatched, though not to Sicily. See below, 26.—o(rmh/santes:=o(rmhqe/ntes, though less freq. Cf. iii.24.1; iv.36.6; 90. 15.

a)fh=kan: sc. ta\s nau=s; in Thuc. only here, and likewise once in Hdt. (vii.193.13). a)fie/nai seems to have been used on account of the bolder voyage through the open sea (e)s to\ pe/lagos) without touching at Corcyra and the Italian coast, as ships coming out of the Corinthian Gulf usually did. Further particulars about these vessels are given in c. 50. On the form of the aor., see App.
a)/rxonta...prosta/cantes : the expression occurs in four other places in Thuc., viz.: iii.26.3; vi.93.8; viii.23.21; 39. 13. See App. on iii.26.3.
*sikuw/nioi: but a)nagkastoi\ strateu/ontes (c. 58. 17), since the Lacedaemonians had forced an oligarchical constitution on them (v. 81. § 2).

tai=s ei)/kosin *)attikai=s: the squadron regularly stationed at Naupactus, not the 20 triremes (c. 17. § 2) which were to watch the whole coast of the Peloponnese.— 29. au)toi=s: dat. of interest in loose relation, as in i.6.8; 48. 9; iii.98.9. G. 184, 3, N. 4; H. 771.
kai\ to\ prw=ton: from the very beginning they had been intended for this duty.
o(/pws mh\...to\n nou=n e)/xwsi : the same const. also in viii.8.16. Cf. iii.22.29.

About the same time the Athenians send out a second fleet of 30 ships under Charicles to the coast of the Peloponnese; and Demosthenes with 65 triremes, 1200 hoplites, some islanders, and military stores, to Sicily.

2. peri/ te *pelopo/nnhson: te, which
is found only in Vat., is necessary in opp. to kai\ to\n *dhmosqe/nhn in 6. On the contrary, the isolated te in 5, after *)argei/wn, is inadmissible.
*xarikle/a: later, one of the Thirty, acc. to Xen. Hell. ii.3.2.—e)/steilan: they dispatched (aor.). He set out immediately, but was detained in Argos attending to the duty assigned him.
parakalei=n: usual term for a summons for military aid. Cf. ii.96.8; v.6.18.
7. a)pe/stellon: they were preparing to send; impf., as from the extent of the preparations delay was to be expected, and, indeed, is mentioned in 14 and c. 26. 1 ff.
e)k katalo/gou: to be connected with o(pli/tais. See on c. 16. 7.
o(/sois...xrh/sasqai : “as many as they could possibly get into their service.” xrh/sasqai (aor.) = convertere in usum. GMT. 19, N. 1; H. 841. Cf. i.6.14.
tw=n u(phko/wn: i.e. those who furnished neither troops, nor ships in natura. Cf. c. 57. 13; i.19.6; 99. 11.

cumpori/santes: as the simple pori/zein (c. 18. 31)=conquirere; elsewhere in the mid. (viii.1.24: 4. 3).—ei)/rhto d) au)tw=|...periple/onta custrateu/esqai : this clause after the one above (4), w(=| ei)/rhto a)fikome/nw| parakalei=n, shows quite strikingly the freedom of const. The partic. usually takes the form of the acc. with inf. when placed at any distance from a dat. belonging to leading verb. G. 138, N. 8; Kr. Spr. 55, 2, 7.

15. u(pelei/peto: St. writes u(pele/leipto acc. to c. 33. 27, ei)/ tis u(pele/leipto e)ceta/sai. But in c. 33. 27 examination is to be made whether any one had purposely remained behind; here Demosthenes proposes if any person or thing had not been ready, was still behind, to wait for it. With the impf. here in the sense of continued waiting, cf. i.11.9, toi=s a)ei\ u(poleipome/nois, the pres. partic. of continued occurrence.

to\n *xarikle/a . . .
paralabei=n: Schol. a)po\ koinou= to\ perie/mene. The same const. occurs after e)pime/nein in iii.2.7.
In Syracuse Gylippus and Hermocrates vie with one another in the effort to put all their forces into the best condition, and especially to incite the Syracusans to naval warfare.
1. u(po\ tou\s au)tou\s xro/nous tou/tou tou= h)=ros: cf. iv.2.1.
o( *gu/lippos h(=ken: i.e. from the interior of Sicily. Cf. c. 7. § 2.

6. a)po/peiran: the noun found only here in Att.; the verb a)popeira=n also in c. 17. 15; 36. 2, and in mid. iv.24.7. a)po/peiran lamba/nein=a)po/peiran poiei=sqai, to make trial of a sea-fight, as in Hdt. viii.9.7. Cf. iii.20.20, th\n cumme/trhsin tw=n klima/kwn e)/labon; Plat. Prot. 348 a, pei=ran a)llh/lwn lamba/nontes.
a)p) au)tou= : Schol., tou= naumaxei=n.

katerga/sasqai : Cl. thinks the aor. inf. as appropriate after e)lpi/zein (cf. iv.13.4; 24. 10; 80. 3) as after e)lpi/s (ii.80.10; iii.32.13; v.9.27). St. (Qu. Gr. p. 7) has adopted here and everywhere after e)lpi/zein either the fut. inf. or the aor. inf. with a)/n. Cl. thinks the aor. inf. corresponds to the success confidently expected from the means specifically referred to (a)p' au)tou=).

8. cunane/peiqe ou)x h(/kista tou= tai=s nausi\ mh\ a)qumei=n [e)pixeirh/sein] pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: cunane/peiqe occurs also in vi.88.48. St. is doubtless right in thinking e)pixeirh/sein a gloss (Qu. Gr. p. 8 and Symb. Philol. Bonn. p. 388); for the fut. inf. is inappropriate and the connexion with pro/s without parallel. On the other hand, tou= . . . a)qumei=n (for which St. writes au)tou\s mh\ . . . a)qumei=n) is not to be given up. It expresses the object of the persuasion: and Hermocrates especially joined in persuading them, to prevent them from being without confidence against the Athenians on sea. GMT. 95. 1; H. 960. See on i.4.6. For Cl.'s explanation, see App.— 9. a)qumei=n pro\s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: cf. ii.88.11.

a)i/dion: usually understood of the past, but rather to be referred to the fut. in contrast with pa/trion, even their maritime skill was not hereditary, nor would it last forever. So Dem. uses a)qa/naton (IV. 8), mh\ w(s qew=| nomi/zet' e)kei/nw| ta\ paro/nta pephge/-
nai a)qa/nata.
e)/xein, h)peirw/tas : Vat. omits a)ll) after e)/xein.
oi(/ous kai\ *)aqhnai/ous : for the attraction of case as well as the proleptic use of kai/ in a rel. clause, cf. vi.68.9. G. 153, N. 5; H. 1002; Kr. Spr. 62, 4, 3; Kühn. 555, 3.

kai\ au)tou/s: this reading has been adopted by Cl., instead of the vulgate a)\n au)toi=s (of which a)/n is wanting in many Mss., while au)tou/s is read in some). The sense is, “in combat against bold men, such as the Athenians are, those who with boldness go against them appear also themselves the most formidable (enemies).” kai\ au)tou/s as in i.50.18, and often. xalepwta/tous kai\ au)tou\s fai/nesqai is explained in the following sent. and finally repeated in other words: kai\ sfa=s a)\n to\ au)to\ (sc. to\ fobei=n au)tou/s)toi=s e)nanti/ois u(posxei=n. St. omits both a)/n and au)toi=s. Kr. and Bm. take pro\s tou\s a)/ndras with tou\s a)ntitolmw=ntas (cf. 19) and refer au)toi=s to a)/ndras, which seems quite reasonable.

w(=| ga\r e)kei=noi . . . u(posxei=n: Schol., w(=| ga\r e)kei=noi, fhsi/, fobou=si tou\s pe/las, toute/sti dia\ qra/sos kai\ ou)xi\ dia\ duna/mews u(peroxh/n, tou/tw| a)\n kai\ u(po\ *surakosi/wn e)kfobh/sesqai tou\s *)aqhnai/ous. With the const., w(=|, to\ au)to/, cf. iii.12.4. The acc. sfa=s, instead of sfei=s, though referring to the subj. of the leading verb, as in iii.111.13; vi.49.9; 96. 5; viii.32.15. u(posxei=n in the sense of e)mbalei=n is very unusual and without parallel in Thuc. St. compares Pind. Ol. 2. 54, plou=tos baqei=an u(pe/xwn me/rimnan.
19. a)prosdokh/tws: the adv. only here and iv.29.17; elsewhere the adj.

ple/on ti: so Vat., instead of ple/on, as in ii.11.32; v.109.4.— perigenhsome/nous: reading of Vat. for periesome/nous. This and bla/yontas are supplementary partics. in ind. disc. with eu)= ei)de/nai. GMT. 113; H. 982.

24. *(ermokra/tous kai\ ei)/ tou a)/llou: unusual assimilation of the pron. Pp. compares Soph. Aj. 487, e)ce/fun patro\s ei)/per tino\s sqe/nontos. Kr. Spr.
60, 10, 2.
w(/rmhnto/ te e)s kte(.: cf. ii.65.5; viii.40.19; 47. 17.

Thereupon Gylippus attacks Plemmyrium from the land side, while simultancously 80 triremes sail out of the two harbours against the fleet of the Athenians. The latter, with 60 ships, stubbornly resist.
1. pareskeua/sato: St. has adopted from two Mss. pareskeu/asto, on the ground that Gylippus did not himself prepare the fleet. But it is sufficient that he had general direction in the matter.

a)gagw\n stratia/n: very generally used of setting out with an army. Cf. c. 84. 2; iv.93.3. He set out under cover of night (u(po\ nu/kta) and waited until the expected sea-fight should offer the favourable moment for attack. Cf. c. 23. § 1.—au)to\s me\n...e)/melle...ai( de\ trih/reis...e)pe/pleon...perie/pleon : paratactic const., “while he held himself ready for an attack by land, the two divisions of ships made a simultaneous onset.”— 4. ai( de\ trih/reis tw=n *surakosi/wn: the whole 80, after which follow the parts in the same case. See on ii.95.5; iii.13.17.—a(/ma kai\ a)po\ cunqh/matos: at the same time and on a preconcerted signal. Cf. iv.67.20; vi.61.10.

ai( de\ pe/nte: Cl. explains the art. as signifying the fleet that is ready and stationed in definite number in the smaller harbour, while the 35 triremes from the greater harbour do not comprise all the ships that are getting ready there. But better St. the remainder, the art., which has the same force as in ta\ de\ du/o, c. 24. 4, and in ai( de\ e(/ndeka, c. 25. 6, implying that the whole number was 80. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 8.

to\ new/rion: the harbour of the war-ships with the necessary appurtenances of wharves and docks. See Holm, H. p. 382.— perie/pleon: i.e. around the old city (the Nasos). On the omission of kai/ before perie/pleon, see App.
pro\s ta\s e)nto\s prosmi/cai: Schol., tai=s i)di/ais tai=s e)nto\s tou= mega/lou lime/nos cummi/cai.
a)mfote/rwqen : i.e. both by land and sea. We find it with qorubei=sqai also in iii.26.5; v.10.33.

10. a)ntiplhrw/santes: having manned
in turn, with reference to c. 21. 26.— 11. tai=s me/n, tai=s d' e)piloi/pois: the art. with numbers used as parts of a whole. See on 6 above. Cf. i.116.2.
tai=s e)piloi/pois: i.e. 35. e)pi/loipos is found only here in Thuc., who uses elsewhere u(po/loipos.
oi( me/n : sc. oi( *surako/sioi.
Gylippus by a sudden onset gets possession of the three forts on Plemmyrium; but the Syracusan fleet is beaten by the Athenian, and suffers considerable loss.

1. e)n tou/tw|: the battle at sea began before daylight, for when at daybreak (a(/ma th=| e(/w|, 4) Gylippus advanced to the attack, the Athenians had already been for some time looking on the sea-fight.
e)pikataba/ntwn: going down to the very edge (of the water), as in c. 35. 9; 84. 19; iv.11.2.
fqa/nei prospesw/n: i.e. before the Athenians could arm themselves to resist.
e)/peita de\ kai\ ta\ e)la/ssw du/o: the decisive success is briefly announced first; the details and results are described afterwards in 7 with kai\ me/n and in 11 with e)peidh\ de/.
tw=n fula/kwn : the garrison stationed there. Cf. c. 43. 22.

7. e)k tou= prw/tou a(lo/ntos: from that which was first taken. For the pred. adj. between the art. and its partic., see Kr. Spr. 50, 12, 1. Cl. writes (against the Mss.) prw=ton, taking it adv. both here and in 5. But even if it be not an adj. in 5, as St. claims (cf. vi.66.13), that would not be proof that it is not one here.

e)s ta\ ploi=a: which acc. to c. 4. 26 lay there at anchor under the protection of the fortifications of Plemmyrium.—e)s to\ strato/pedon: i.e. into the chief camp of the Athenian army near the double wall and close to the great harbour. See on c. 4. 24 and Holm, H. p. 395.
tw=n ga\r kte(.: explains xalepw=s . . . e)cekomi/zonto.

kratou/ntwn th=|
naumaxi/a|: as the Syracusans still had the advantage against the Att. ships, they could spare one trireme for the pursuit of the fleeing garrison of the larger fort.

e)peidh\...h(li/sketo : exact statement of the simultancous (impf.) occurrences at two different points: “at the time when the two smaller forts fell into the hands of the Syracusan land troops, the Syracusan fleet was already losing the day, so that the Athenian garrisons from the smaller forts, who were fleeing along the coast in boats, could no longer be pursued by the Syracusans.” How this change in the sea-fight had come about is then described from 14 (ai( ga\r tw=n *surakosi/wn kte(.) to the end of the chap.

14. ai( pro\ tou= sto/matos nh=es naumaxou=sai: i.e. ai( e)k tou= newri/ou periple/ousai. Cf. c. 22. 13. Thuc. is fond of placing the attrib. partic. after the noun, when other words are added. Kr. Spr. 50, 10, 3. See on i.11.19.

ou)deni\ ko/smw|: cf. c. 40. 10; 84. 9; iii.108.16; also pollw=| ko/smw| in viii.00.13.—taraxqei=sai peri\ a)llh/las: = e)n a)llh/lais (ii.65.50), or e)n sfi/sin au)tai=s (c. 67. 14; 84. 18), or prospi/ptousai a)llh/lais (c. 36. 33).

pare/dosan th
 ni/khn: gave away the victory, as in viii.71.3, th
 palaia
 e)leuqeri/an paradw/sein.

tau/tas te...e)nikw=nto : “for they routed not only these (who had fallen into disorder), but also those by whom they were at first worsted inside the harbour.” On this co-ordination of the rel. clause with the dem., see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 5.
e)n tw=| lime/ni: i.e. e)n tw=| mega/lw| lime/ni (10).

20. plh
 o(/son: limiting in adv. sense the preceding, except, with which we must supply tou\s a)nqrw/pous, to which ou(/s refers. In c. 62. 18 (plh
 o(/son a)
 o( pezo\s h(mw=n e)pe/xh|) the grammatical connexion is closer.
