e)n tw=| nhsidi/w|: it cannot be certainly determined whether this is Isola del
Castelluccio or San Marciano.
e)s to\ e(autw=n strato/pedon: see on 8.

The loss of Plemmyrium is the the more grievous to the Athenians, since large quantities of naval stores and ship material, as well as three triremes which had been drawn up on land, fall into the hands of the enemy.
1. ou(/tws e)pepra/gesan: had fared thus, used esp., as here, of unfavourable events, if the contrary is not expressed. Cf. ii.4.33.
tropai=a e)/sthsan au)tw=n: sc. tw=n a(lo/ntwn teixw=n. Cf. c. 41. 12; 54. 1; ii.82.8; iv.12.8; vi.98.20. Kr. Spr. 47, 7, 3.
kate/balon: as in i.58.13; v.83.8.— ta\ de\ du/o: see on c. 22. 6.
e)piskeua/santes: cf. c. 1. 2; 38. 11; vi.104.20.
e)n tw=n teixw=n th=| a(lw/sei: Thuc. and Hdt. are fond of inserting the gen. between a prep. and its case. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 19. Cf. i.9.25; v.47.65; vi.34.57.

xrh/mata: material of every sort. Cf. 9 below, wares, and c. 25. 7, military stores. For the facts, cf. Diod. xiii. 9; Plut. Nic. 20.—ta\ cumpa/nta: all together. Kr. Spr. 50, 11, 13. Cf. c. 1. 31.—w(/sper: Cl. and St., for w(/ste of the Mss., which is nowhere used comparatively in Att. prose. a(/te, which Bk. and Kr. write, would be admissible acc. to v.72.1; but w(/sper is more like the vulgate, and is supported also by the imitation of the passage in Jos. Antiquities, xviii. 9, e)xrw=nto w(/sper tamiei/w| tai=sde tai=s po/lesin.
tamiei/w| xrwme/nwn : in the same sense as vi.97.27, toi=s te skeu/esi kai\ toi=s xrh/masin a)poqh/kh. For the facts, cf. c. 4. 25.
tw=n trihra/rxwn: the art., added from Vat., because the trierarchs are a class belonging together, as opp. to e)/mporoi, who came together by chance.
e)gkatelh/fqh: sc. e)n toi=s tei/xesi. Cf. c. 30. 13; iv.116.4.

12. me/giston: cognate acc. with e)ka/kwse. G. 159, N. 2; H. 716 b; Kr. Spr. 46, 5, 7. Cf. c. 44. 32; v.82.21,
me/giston o)felh/sein; Xen. An. iii.1.38, me/ga o)nh=sai.
te : Vat., for de/, not correlative to kai/, but resumptive, as in i.4.5; 67. 3.—e)n toi=s prw=ton: see on c. 19. 19.
ou)d' e)/sploi: with Vat. for ou)d' oi( e)/sploi, because the statement is general; but in 16 ai( e)skomidai/, because the context renders it definite.
th=s e)pagwgh=s tw=n e)pithdei/wn: abstract for the concrete = tw=n e)pagome/nwn e)pithdei/wn. Cf. v.82.24.
dia\ ma/xhs: only by fighting. —e)s ta)=lla: favourite expression of Thuc. Cf. c. 7. 15; 77. 8; i.1.14; 6. 15; 36. 13.
pare/sxe: the subj. is h( tou= *plhmmuri/ou lh=yis.

The Syracusans dispatch ships and intercept some supplies sent out to the Athenians, and by the announcement of their success arouse their Peloponnesian allies to lend further assistance. Before Syracuse both sides seek by all manner of attacks to do each other as much harm as possible, and especially violent is the contest about the palisade built by the Syracusans for the protection of their ships. The Syracusans send ambassadors to the Sicel cities to try to arouse them to take a more active part in the war.
3. w)/|xeto: here, as always (c. 7. 6; 12. 3; 46. 6), expressive of haste. This one ship had separated immediately from the rest, and set off with all haste on its voyage to the Peloponnese.

o(/pws...gi/gnesqai : o(/pws from Vat., instead of oi(/per, has been adopted by the later editt. The rel. pron. with the subjv. of purpose cannot be established in Att. te, likewise from Vat., is indispensable, as ta\ sfe/tera is contrasted with e)kei= po/lemon. e)n e)lpi/si as below in 43; c. 46. 6; i.74.22; iv.70.20. Cf. e)s e)lpi/da e)lqei=n, ii.56.12.
ai( e(/ndeka: see on c. 22. 6.—th\n *)itali/an: in Thuc. used only of the peninsula south of the river Laus and Metapontum. See on vi.2.19; i.12.14.
xrhma/twn ge/monta: the order of Vat. more forcible than the Vulgate ge/monta xrhma/twn. For xrh/mata, see on c. 24. 7.

8. tw=n ploi/wn: the gen. with e)pi-
tugxa/nein unusual. Cf. iii.3.23; Xen. Oec. 2. 3; 12. 20; Plat. Phil. 61 d; Ar. Plut. 245.
*kaulwnia/tidi: the district of Caulonia north of Locri Epizephyrii, on the edge of the Sila forest, which produced much building timber and pitch. Cf. Strabo, vi.1.9.

12. mi/a tw=n o(lka/dwn...o(pli/tas : prob. one of the fleet which sailed from Taenarum (c. 19. § 3, 4), among the commanders of which was also a Thespian named Hegesander. This ship perhaps lost its course on the voyage dia\ pela/gous, and thus was detained longer than the others. The Thespians are reckoned with the Boeotians in c. 19. § 3.
14. fula/cantes d' au)tou/s: Schol. thrh/santes kairo\n e)s to\ e)piqe/sqai au)toi=s. Cf. c. 4. 36, pe/mpei e)s fulakh\n au)tw=n.

pro\s toi=s *mega/rois: the Hyblaean Megara. See on vi.4.8.— 16. au)toi=s a)ndra/si: dat. of accompaniment. G. 188, 5 N.; H. 774 a. Cf. ii.90.26; iv.14.6; viii.102.15.— 17. ou)k e)dunh/qhsan: sc. lamba/nein.
a)ll) a)pofeu/gousin : for change of subj., see on i.26.17.

20. pro\ tw=n palaiw=n newsoi/kwn: the regular dockyard (new/rion) of the Syracusans was, acc. to c. 22. § 1, in the smaller harbour. But for the protection of the ships temporarily lying in port there were ship-houses also on the shore of the great harbour, under which every ship found shelter. In time of peace they needed no further protection; but now the Syracusans had built a palisade to defend them from the attacks of the Athenians.
e)nto\s o(rmoi=en: i.e. behind the protecting palisade. e)nto/s is similarly used in c. 5. 14; ii.83.26; vi.67.9; 75. 2.

23. prosagago/ntes ga\r kte(.: in explanation of peri\ tw=n staurw=n a)krobolismo/s in 19.—muriofo/ron: since
the reading seems to be established (occurring also in Poll. ii. 82 and Strab. xvii.1.26), we must take a talent as unit of measure, and interpret, “a ship of 10,000 talents burden.” Cf. iv.118.28, ploi/w| e)s pentako/sia ta/lanta a)/gonti me/tra; also Hdt. i.194.17; ii.96.16. Lobeck's conjecture muriamfo/ron (Ad Phryn. p. 663) is therefore to be rejected.—au)toi=s: sc. toi=s stauroi=s (Schol. toi=s staurw/masi dhlono/ti).

pu/rgous te...kai\ parafra/gmata : this vessel of about 258 tons (if the talents were Att., or 357, if Aeginetan), with its wooden towers and bulwarks (parafra/gmata, also iv.115.7), served as a floating fortress for the troops. From its deck they repelled the attacks of the enemy and protected the operations of their own men (oi( d' e)k th=s o(lka/dos a)nte/ballon in 27). These operations consisted in the attempt, made from the smaller boats, partly to fasten cords to the stakes and then to pull them out with windlasses, partly to dive under the water and saw them off. See App.
29. th=s staurw/sews h( kru/fios: the hidden part of the palisade, after the analogy of h( plei/sth th=s stratia=s, c. 3. 15.
u(pere/xontas: as in iii.23.26.

mh\ ou) proi+dw/n tis...periba/lh| th\n nau=n : dependent on deino\n h)=n and explanatory of prospleu=sai. ou) belongs only to proi+dw/n. e(/rma is a rock. Cf. Hdt. vii.183.6, where e)pelau/nein is used, as here periba/llein.
misqou= : for pay. Cf. iv.124.22; v.6.7. The word indicates that the kolumbhtai/ (also iv.26.28) were esp. trained for their business.
35. oi(=on ei)ko/s: elliptical, as oi(=a ei)ko/s in ii.54.3; vi.69.15.
pei/rais: stratagems, found in pl. only here, though the sense is the same as in iii.20.8.

38. e)s ta\s po/leis: sc. tw=n *sikeliw-
tw=n. They hoped to make most impression on these through ambassadors from the Dorian cities of Hellas. The result of the mission is stated in c. 32.
a)gge/llontas: the rather unusual pres. partic. of purpose (as in c. 3. 4; iii.52.11; vi.88.62), with which are connected dhlw/sontas and a)ciw/sontas (42, 43), forming subord. explanatory clauses.
ou)...ma=llon h)/ : not . . . so much, as, the first member being completely subordinated, as in i.73.17.

ta/ te a)/lla dhlw/sontas...kai\ a)ciw/sontas : the ultimate main object is brought out more forcibly by the position of ta/ te a)/lla. The connexion would be disturbed by au)=, which is inserted before dhlw/sontas in all the Mss. except Vat. It was perhaps a marginal note of some reader, referring to 4 above.
e)p' au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.
w(s...prosdoki/mwn o)/ntwn : the expectation of this danger, which could be averted only by timely help, was to be the excuse for the demand (w(s).

a)/llh| stratia=|: cf. c. 16. 6.—au)toi/: Cl. explains in his last edit., “they alone, the Syracusans, without the help of the others.” But this does not agree with the request just referred to. The contrast is between the Athenians on the one side (au)tw=n), and the Syracusans and their allies on the other (au)toi/).

diapepolemhso/menon: so Vat. (which is more forcible than diapolemhso/menon of the vulgate), there would be an end of the war. Cf. c. 14. 13, and Liv. xxiii. 13, debellatum mox fore, si adniti paulum voluissent, rebantur. The impers, partic. in acc. abs. with w(s is co-ord. with the gen. abs., as in c. 15. 7.

Demosthenes joins Charicles on the coast of Argolis. The two ravage some places in Laconia, and fortify a point on the coast opposite Cythera, in order to furnish an asylum for fugitive Helots and a starting-point for predatory excursions. Thereupon Demosthenes continues his journey to Sicily. Charicles, however, after further strengthening the fort, turns back to Athens.

1. epei\ cunele/gh au)tw=|: cf. c. 17.
§ 1; 20. § 3. au)tw=| is not for u(p' au)tou=, but dat. of advantage, corresponding to the idea of perie/mene in c. 20. 16.

pro\s th\n *pelopo/nnhson: indefinite, to the coast in general, not to any special point; in 6, e)s th\n *akwnikh/n, definite, with the intention of engaging in some enterprise there.—tw=| *xariklei=: who in the meanwhile had performed his task (parakalei=n *)argei/wn o(pli/tas, c. 20. 5). The paralabei=n (c. 20. 16) is now carried out by Demosthenes and Charicles together.
7. *)epidau/rou ti th=s *aimhra=s: Epidaurus Limera was situated on a well-protected bay among the spurs of the Zarax mountains. Cf. iv.56.10. See Curtius, Pelop. H. p. 292.

ta\ katantikru\ *kuqh/rwn th=s *akwnikh=s: the part of Laconia opposite Cythera.—to\ i(ero\n tou= *)apo/llwnos: the site is not certainly known. See Curtius, Pelop. H. p. 330, Rem. 75.— 10. i)sqmw=de/s ti xwri/on: prob. the *)/onou gna/qos (Paus. iii.23.1), now Elaphonisi. See Curtius, ibid., and Bursian, H. p. 140.
w(/sper e)k th=s *pu/lou: cf. iv. 41. § 2; v. 14. § 3.
13. cugkate/labe: i.e. with Charicles, whose operations on the coast of the Peloponnese he was to support (ei)/rhto d' au)tw=| . . . custrateu/esqai, c. 20. 12).

pare/plei: sailed along the coast. This is the usual word, though most of the Mss. read e)pe/plei; Vat. e)pipare/plei, which is evidently only a slip of the pen.—tw=n e)kei=qen cumma/xwn: the part. gen. as in iv.80.7. G. 170, 1; H. 736.
e(/ws...e)cetei/xise : until he had completed the fortification of the place. Schol. ei)s te/los h)/gagen. Cf. c. 4. 25; iv.4.4; 45. 11.

kai\ au)to/s: i.e. as
Demosthenes before. It refers only to a)pekomi/zeto (iii.81.4; iv.96.35).
A corps of 1300 Thracian mercenaries arriving after Demosthenes's departure is sent back. Description of the evils that Athens suffered from the occupation of Decelea.

1. *qra|kw=n tw=n maxairofo/rwn tou= *diakou= ge/nous: in maxairofo/rwn we have the characteristic mark of the Thracians. Cf. ii.96.10; Xen. Cyrop. vi.2.10; Aesch. Pers. 56 (to\ maxairofo/ron e)/qnos e)k pa/shs *)asi/as e(/petai). Tac. Ann. iii. 38 mentions the Dii along with the Odrusae.

tou= au)tou= qe/rous tou/tou: so Vat. for the vulgate, e)n tw=| au)tw=| qe/rei tou/tw|, the gen. indicating the time within which anything takes place, without definitely fixing the date, during this same summer. See on vi.97.1.
e)/dei: as often, of an arrangement previously made. Cf. ii.5.1; 92. 24; iii.95.18; iv.76.17; v.42.4.
5. u(/steron: too late. Cf. c. 29. 1; ii.80.35.
a)pope/mpein: send back. a)po- as in a)podido/nai.
e)/xein : with pregnant force, retain.—pro\s to\n e)k th=s *dekelei/as po/lemon: i.e. against the incursions made from Decelea, not referring to o( *dekeleiko\s po/lemos proper.
draxmh/n: the usual pay of hoplites amounted to four obols. See Boeckh, P. E. p. 373.
e)la/mbanon: Vat. for e)la/mbanen. The subj. is oi( *qra=|kes, and e(/kastos is in pred. appos. to the pl. subj., as in ii.87.31; iii.38.24; iv.80.15; vi.69.19.

e)peidh\...e)pw|kei=to : Cl. explains that the occupation (e)pw|kei=to) consisted of two parts: the first, the fortification of the place, expressed by means of the partic. clause (u(po\ . . . teixisqei=sa); the second, the military operations, expressed by the dat., frou/rais a)po\ tw=n po/lewn (sc. tw=n cumma/xwn)kata\ diadoxh\n xro/nou e)piou/sais: “by means of garrisons which came in from the allied cities in fixed succession.” But St. explains perhaps more clearly, that the first clause is really subord. to the second, though the two are co-ord. by me/n, de/, and he cites in support iii. 82. § 1; vi. 69. § 1. Arn. understands, by zeugma, from teixisqei=sa, katexome/nh in the second clause. See App. Cl. connects th=| xw/ra| with e)piou/sais; but it seems better, with Arn. and St., to take it with e)pw|kei=to. Cf. vi.86.13, e)poikou=ntes u(mi=n; v.51.4, ou) ga\r e)p' a)/llh|
tini\ gh=| to\ xwri/on e)teixi/sqh; Paus. iv.26.5, a)cio/maxon po/lin e)poiki/sai *lakedaimoni/ois. See on c. 19. 9.

e)/blapte, e)ka/kwse: the subj. is to be inferred from the foregoing clause, viz. tou=to, to\ th\n *deke/leian e)poikei=sqai. polla/ is cognate acc. See on c. 24. 12.—e)n toi=s prw=ton: correctly restored by Bk. instead of prw/tois. See on c. 19. 19.
o)le/qrw|: Kr. objects to this word with xrhma/twn; but ai( pro/sodoi a)pw/llunto in c. 28. 32 supports the present reading.

14. braxei=ai gigno/menai ai( e)sbolai/: the five incursions of the first period of the war, of which the second (430 B.C.) was the longest, lasting 40 days (ii. 57. § 2), the fifth (425 B.C.) the shortest, lasting only 15 days (iv. 6. § 2).
e)pikaqhme/nwn: sc. tw=n e)sbalo/ntwn.

o(te\ me/n, o(te\ de/ = pote\ me/n, pote\ de/. This usage does not occur again till Arist. and the later writers. But cf. Plat. Phaed. 59 a, o(te\ me/n, e)ni/ote de/; Theaet. 207 d, o(te\ me/n, tote\ de/; Xen. Cyneg. 5. 8, o(te\ de/. Kr. Spr. 25, 10, 12.

th=s i)/shs froura=s: Cl. understands this, as opp, to kai\ pleio/nwn e)pio/ntwn, to mean the regular garrison furnished successively by the different cities (cf. 10, a)po\ tw=n po/lewn kata\ diadoxh\n xro/nou e)piou/sais). Schol., th=s i)/shs froura=s, th=s tetagme/nhs dhlono/ti. These had to provide for their own support and therefore kate/qee th\n xw/ran e)c a)na/gkhs, i.e. whenever there was need. St. explains cum modo etiam plures invaderent, modo ex necessitate aequalis (i.e. quanta necessitate postulabatur) manus excursionem faceret. See App.
basile/ws te paro/ntos: the third factor in the Decelean War.
e)k pare/rgou: also i.142.25. Cf. e)n pare/rgw|, vi.69.27; Soph. Phil. 473.
21. th=s xw/ras: Schol., th=s karpi/mou.
ple/on h)\ du/o muria/des : Boeckh, P. E. p. 55, reckons the number of slaves in Athens in the most flourishing period at 365,000, so that the number here given does not seem incredible.

polu\ me/ros: Vat. has to\ polu/, but most of these slaves could hardly have been handicraftsmen; for very many slaves would
be required for household service.— xeirote/xnai: artisans of every kind. See App. to vi.72.10.—a)polw/lei pa/nta: so Vat., which is more expressive than pa/nta a)polw/lei of the rest of the Mss.

zeu/gh: from Vat. instead of u(pozu/gia, since it would be natural acc. to Att. usage to choose for beasts of burden that term from which the citizens of the third class received their name, zeugi=tai.
o(shme/rai : adv. Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 15.

e)n gh=|...talaipwrou=ntes : the two causes of lameness expressed in unlike manner; first by means of the prep. and its case, then with the partic. cunexw=s talaipwrou=ntes, i.e. from the continual exertion. For same change of const., cf. iv.26.13. Kr. connects e)n gh=| a)pokro/tw| and cunexw=s with talaipwrou=ntes. Either explanation might be correct.

Even the importation of provisions is made difficult for the Athenians; and they are oppressed by all the inconveniences of a siege at home, while they themselves continue to besiege Syracuse. In the extreme financial straits into which they have come, they seek relief by a tax of five per cent. on all wares imported and exported by sea.

1. h(/ te tw=n e)pithdei/wn parakomidh\ kte(.: this is the last of the bad results (mega/la e)bla/ptonto) of the occupation of Decelea that are recounted from c. 27. 21 on. tw=n pa/ntwn o(moi/ws e)paktw=n e)dei=to in 4 does not belong in the same rank with the preceding; it contains rather the ground of the last statement, and must therefore be introduced, not by te, but by the epexegetical de/, as in i.26.23; 55. 3; v.10.21. But St. claims that even with Cl.'s interpretation te is more appropriate. The transportation of provisions from Euboea was more difficult and expensive, because they had to be brought around Sunium; nevertheless everything had to be imported, because the whole country was in the hands of the enemy, and out of it neither corn nor cattle could be got; and so (kai/) Athens resembled in fact rather a fortress than an open city.
kata\ gh=n: all the Mss. have kata\ gh=s, but kata\ qa/lassan shows that the acc. is required.
qa=sson ou)=sa: corresponds to r(a=|on au)tw=| e)fai/neto h( e)skomidh\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn e)/sesqai in c. 4. 18. The Mss., even Vat., give qa/sswn, but the adv. is the preferable expression.

tw=n de\...e)dei=to : = pa/nta w(=n e)dei=to e)pakta\ h)=n. The Schol. explains
e)paktw=n by ei)sagwgi/mwn e)c a)llodaph=s. See on vi.20.20. It is pred. Kr. Spr. 57, 3, 3.
frou/rion kate/sth: became a fortress, the verb used in the same sense as in i.118.3; ii.65.30; 89. 37.
pro\s ga\r th=| e)pa/lcei: = par' e)/palcin (ii.13.42).

e)f' o(/plois pou: so Vat. correctly, instead of the meaningless poiou/menoi, which perhaps crept into this place from the partic. in c. 27. 18, 26. o(/pla means the camping places, watch-posts, which were in different parts of the city; hence the indef. pou, “here and there.” Cf. i.111.6; iii.1.7; vi.64.20.

12. to\ ga\r au)tou\s poliorkoume/nous kte(.: the three infs. introduced by to/, a)posth=nai in 14, a)ntipoliorkei=n in 15, and poih=sai in 17 (the aors. of the simple occurrence, the pres. of continued activity) form the subj. of an incomplete period, the intention of which is already fulfilled in the inserted o(/son clause. On this anacoluthon and the different attempts to remove it, see App.
tw=| au)tw=| tro/pw|: sc. e)piteixismw=|, for as such, i.e. as the building a fort on an enemy's frontier, was also the attack of the Athenians on Syracuse to be regarded.
para/logon: miscalculation. Thuc. uses this form eight times, para\ lo/gon five times, and there are four places where it is doubtful which form should be preferred. See on i.65.3.

o(/son: Cl. explains it as giving the measure after tosou=ton (here with finite verbs following; in iii. 49. § 4 with inf. as well as finite verb), and since the measure is to be deduced from the difference between the expectation (e)no/mizon) and the present result (e)/tei e(ptakaideka/tw| e)s *sikeli/an h)=lqon) he claims that w(/ste cannot be correct, and conjectures o(/mws de/. But it is better, with Kr., Arn., and St., to take both o(/son and w(/ste as giving the measure after tosou=ton, and interpret o(/son, quatenus, in so far as. See App.

oi(
de\ triw=n ge e)tw=n, ou)dei\s plei/w xro/non: the two parts of the phrase are to be closely connected in reading, so that the gen. triw=n e)tw=n will be seen to depend on xro/non. Possibly ou)dei\s de/ would make the connexion clearer, unless Kr. and St. are right in removing the comma after e)tw=n, thus making ou)dei/s part. appos. to oi( de/ (“no one of the rest”).
perioi/sein: hold oui, a use of the word, which does not occur again till the later writers. It combines the force of perie/sesqai and a)nqe/cein (Suid.).
e(ptakaideka/tw|: the same form in iv.101.1.—th\n prw/thn e)sbolh/n: cf. ii. 19.
tetruxwme/noi: found in Thuc. only in the pres. and pf. pass. partic. Cf. iv.60.13. See on i.126.24.—prosanei/lonto: pros- with adv. force, insuper.
24. di) a(/: for all these reasons, to which kai\ to/te . . . prospipto/ntwn adds still a further cause. The a)/lla a)nalw/mata were recounted from c. 27. § 4 to c. 28. § 1.

u(po\ th=s *dekelei/as polla\ blaptou/shs: the partic. with the force of the verbal subst., as in c. 42. 10; iii.20.3; 29. 9; iv.29.9.— 26. a)du/natoi toi=s xrh/masi: Schol., h)/goun e)ndeei=s xrhma/twn e)gi/gnonto. The const. is not elsewhere found, but is warranted by kindred expressions, as xrh/masi dunatoi/ in i.13.19; duna/menos toi=s xrh/masi, Lys. VI 48.

th\n ei)kosth/n: with regard to this impost on exports and imports, see Boeckh, P. E. p. 434. It continued perhaps till the end of the Peloponnesian War. See Boeckh, l.c.—kata/: Cl. reads kata/ from Vat. alone, but the Schol. reads u(po/, and explains it by kata/(u(po/: kata/).
a)nti\ tou= fo/rou: cf. i.96.7; ii.13.23; v.18.22.
e)poi/hsan: of the introduction of a tax is not found elsewhere. St. writes, on Badham's conjecture, e)pe/qesan; Cl. prefers e)pe/tacan, comparing i.139.2; 140. 18; ii.7.10.
kai\ pri/n: as in vi.11.5.—kaqe/stasan: see on 6.
ai( de\ pro/sodoi a)pw/llunto: dependent on o(/sw| and closely connected with mei/zwn o( po/lemos h)=n, and the revenues kept failing.
The Thracian mercenaries who are sent back, betake themselves, on the way home, to robberies and cruelties on the Boeotian coast, especially in Mycalessus.
1. tw=| *dhmosqe/nei: dat. of advantage (cf. c. 26. 1), since they were intended as reinforcements for him. Cf. c. 27. § 1.

dapana=n: i.e. to be at great expense on account of them. Cf. c. 27. § 2.—a)pe/pempon: for the use of the impf., see on c. 20. 7. Kühn. 383, 3, takes it as equiv. to the aor. That they returned by ship is shown by what follows, and is implied in komi/sai.

*diitre/fei : prob. the grandson of the Diitrephes mentioned in iii.75.2; iv.53.5; 119. 10. It is he, doubtless, who is mentioned again in viii.64.7. See App. to c. 30. 15. St. writes, following inscriptions, *dieitre/fhs in all the places just cited.—ei)po/ntes: in sense of keleu/ein, as in iii.3.16; iv.2.8, and freq. Kühn. 473, 2.
a)/n ti du/nhtai: so Vat. correctly, instead of h)/n ti du/nwntai, since the sing. is required in connexion with a)p' au)tw=n bla/yai, the subj. of which is Diitrephes.

a)p' au)tw=n bla/yai: Schol. a)nti\ tou= di) au)tw=n, to do injury by means of them. “a)po/ expresses the instrument, that from which the hurt proceeded.” Arn. Cf. bla/ptesqai a)f' w(=n (of things) in c. 67. 19. The idea seems to be, “at their cost,” i.e. to use them as “food for powder.”

*tanagrai/an: for *ta/nagran of the Mss. The reference here can be only to the land extending down to the coast (cf. iv.76.17), not to the city, which was situated on a height at some distance from the sea. See Bursian, I. p. 122. After a short stay (dia\ ta/xous) they embarked again (though Thuc. does not mention this), and sailed over to Chalcis; then, recrossing the Euripus, they surprised Mycalessus. The two plundering incursions are connected by te (in 6) and kai/ before e)k *xalki/dos.
a)f) e(spe/ras : directly after nightfall, as in iii.112.8; viii.27.27 = u(po\ nu/kta in i.115.19; vi.64.3.
*mukalhsso/n: see Bursian, I. p. 217.
11. hu)li/sato: pitched his camp.
ou) mega/lh| : ou) added from Vat. Strab., ix.2.11, calls it kw/mh th=s *tanagrikh=s, and this agrees with w(s e)pi\ mege/qei in c. 30. 20.
a)prosdokh/tois: in the act. sense (see on vi.69.2) it takes, in consequence of the implied negation (= ou) prosdokw=si), also the dependent inf. with neg. mh/ after it. See on c. 6. 19; iii.32.14.
tosou=ton: about 30 stadia, and not so far as the city Tanagra is distant from the coast.
peptwko/tos: fallen down. Cf. i.89.19; iv.112.6.
braxe/os w)|kodomhme/nou: the adj. is pred. as in c. 4. 11, e)poikodomh/santes . . . u(yhlo/teron. This part of the wall had not been built high in the beginning.
19. tou\s a)nqrw/pous...h(liki/as : Paus., i.23.3, says of the same occurrence, *mukalhssi/wn ou) mo/non to\ ma/ximon oi( *qra=|kes, a)lla\ kai\ gunai=kas e)fo/neusan kai\ pai=das.
o(/tw| e)ntu/xoien : prot. of general cond. For o(/tw| in collective sense referring to pl. antec., see Kühn. 359, 3 c b.

o(/sa a)/lla e)/myuxa : in the strong expression may be perceived the aversion with which the historian tells the story.— 24. o(moi=a toi=s ma/lista: sc. fonikoi=s. o(moi=a is adv., as in i.25.18; Hdt. iii.8.2; 57. 8; vii.118.8; 141. 4. On the phrase (= ut qui maxime), see Kühn. 349^{b}, note 5.—e)n w(=| a)\n qarsh/sh|: wherever they have courage, i.e. have nothing to fear. The aor. occurs also in ii.79.19.

25. kai\ to/te...pai/dwn : and on this occasion not only did no slight tumult and every kind of destruction ensue, but also falling upon a boys' school, etc. kai\ to/te introduces an example under a general remark. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 8. Cf. c. 71. 41. To a)/llh te corresponds kai/ before e)pipeso/ntes. pa=sa i)de/a as in ii.19.1; 77. 7; iii.81.22; 83. 1; 98. 15; 112. 23.

o(/per me/giston h)=n...kai\ a)/rti
e)/tuxon oi( pai=des e)selhluqo/tes: without repetition of the rel. pron. (e)s o(/) in the second clause (cf. vi.64.18), and even without au)to/, which is expressed in the similar passage ii.4.25. G. 156; II. 1005; Kr. Spr. 60, 6, 2.

kai\ cumfora\ th=| po/lei...kai\ deinh/ : Thuc. sums up the horror of the whole affair in the most impressive manner, the subst. placed first, followed by the phrases ou)demia=s h(/sswn and ma=llon e(te/ras, which have the force of sups., and the dem. pron. The position of the subst. gives it a character of generality with nearly the effect of the part. gen. See on i.1.8. This passage differs, however, from those cited at i.1.8 in this respect, that here two qualities in their highest expression unite in a single case, viz. the extent of the destruction (ou)demia=s h(/sswn) and the complete unexpectedness of it (ma=llon e(te/ras a)do/khtos). “And so this blow, than which no greater ever affected a whole city, was in the highest degree both unexpected and terrible.” ma=llon . . . a)do/khtos and deinh/ stand in pred. relation to e)pe/pesen. See App.
Before they can embark, they are attacked by the Thebans, who had rushed to the rescue, and a large number is killed.

1. ai)sqo/menoi: without obj. expressed, referring to what precedes. See on i.95.21.—katalabo/ntes prokexwrhko/tas: finding that they had gone forward, i.e. on the retreat toward the coast. katalamba/nein in the sense find, discover (deprehendo), takes regularly the partie. pres. or pf., never aor., since only existing states can be in question. G. 279, 2; II. 982. See on i.59.3.
au)tou\s fobh/santes: putting them to flight. Cf. c. 79. 23; iv.56.6.
a(\ h)/gagen: a)/gein of ships, as in c. 25. 4; iii.70.8; iv.27.10.

6. tou\s plei/stous: closely connected with e)n th=| e)sba/sei. The sense is, most of those who were killed fell at the time of the embarkation. tou\s plei/stous cannot refer here to the majority of the whole number, as is proved by cu/mpantes . . . a)pe/qanon in 14. For plei=stoi in this sense, cf. iv.44.7 and Hdt. viii.89.9.—ou)/te e)pistame/nous...tw=n te...o(rmisa/ntwn : on the connexion of parties. in different cases by copulative particles, see Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.

e)/cw toceu/matos: without doubt the correct reading, although the Mss. have mostly
e)/cw zeu/gmatos. See App.

e)pei/ kte(.: gives the cause of the above a)poktei/nousin au)tw=n e)n th=| e)sba/sei tou\s plei/stous: “for elsewhere (e)n th=| a)/llh| a)naxwrh/sei) on the retreat they lost not so many men, since they knew how to defend themselves not unskilfully.”

ou)k a)to/pws: Schol., ou)k a)ko/smws. It belongs with the following description of the fighting.— 11. e)n e)pixwri/w| ta/cei: after the manner of fighting of their country (proekqei=n and custre/fesqai), which they used ou)k a)to/pws. Cf. Hdt. ix.62.14, proecai+/ssontes kat) e(/na kai\ de/ka, kai\ pleu=ne/s te kai\ e)la/ssones sustrefo/menoi, e)se/pipton e)s tou\s *spartih/tas.
e)n tou/tw| : i.e. e)n tw=| proekqe/ontas kai\ custrefome/nous th\n fulakh\n poiei=sqai.

e)gkatalhfqe/n : i.e. since in their greed for plunder they had allowed themselves to be surprised. Cf. iv.8.43; 35. 6; v.3.6.—oi( cu/mpantes: all together. See on c. 1. 31. Was Diitrephes among the slain? See App.
16. e)s ei)/kosi ma/lista: about twenty. See Kühn. 432, 1, 1 b; Kr. Spr. 60, 8, 1.

tw=n boiwtarxw=n: the whole number of Boeotarchs was eleven, of whom two were from Thebes, the rest (in unknown proportion) from the remaining cities. Cf. iv.91.4. See Boeckh, ad Corp. Inscr. I. 729, and Hermann, Griech. StaatsAlterthümer, § 179, note 10.
18. tw=n *mukalhssi/wn: i.e. of the armed citizens who had joined in the pursuit with the Thebans.—me/ros ti: a considerable part. Cf. i.23.16; ii.64.7; iv.30.2.

ta\ kata\ th\n *mukalhsso\n...toiau=ta cune/bh : cf. similar concluding sents. in iii.50.13, ta\ kata\ *le/sbon ou(/tws e)ge/neto; iii.68.30, ta\ kata\ *pla/taian . . . ou(/tws e)teleu/thsen. Cf. also iv. 48. § 5. Cl. thinks, with St., that Reiske's emendation, xrhsame/n hn for xrhsame/nwn, is necessary, esp. on account of the following w(s e)pi\ mege/qei. This is doubtless better, though the Schol. has xrhsame/nwn: tw=n *mukalhssi/wn dhlono/ti.— 20. w(s e)pi\ mege/qei: sc. th=s po/lews, in
proportion to the size (of the city). Cf. iii.113.25, w(s pro\s to\ me/geqos th=s po/lews.

Demosthenes takes measures, during the further course of his voyage to Sicily, for the reinforcement of his fleet and for the security of Naupactus and the adjacent regions. He unites forces with his colleague Eurymedon, whom he meets returning from Sicily.
1. to/te apople/wn: cf. c. 26. 14, where the word paraplei=n is used of the actual course of the voyage at that moment.
e)k th=s *lakwnikh=s: with unusual after-effect of a)pople/wn = a)pople/wn e)k th=s *lakwnikh=s meta\ th\n e)n au)th=| genome/nhn tei/xisin.

e)n *feia=| : the port of Olympia. See Curtius, Pelop. II. p. 45. Cf. ii.25.16.—eu(rw/n: the reading of Vat., adopted also by St., instead of the vulgate, labw/n, which is incompatible with diafqei/rei. For similar use of eu(ri/skein, cf. ii.6.14; v.42.7. See on katalabo/ntes, c. 30. 1.—oi( *kori/nqioi o(pli=tai: cf. c. 17. § 3; 19. § 4. This one ship had got separated from the squadron of Alexarchus, as in the similar case mentioned in c. 25. 11.
8. tw=n *messhni/wn: sc. o(pli/tas.
th=s *)akarnani/as : this coast Demosthenes had become well acquainted with during his campaigns in the summer and autumn of 426 B.C. (iii. 94 ff.).

*)alu/zeian: cf. Strab. x.2.21, h( *)alu/zeia pentekai/deka a)po\ qala/tths die/xei stadi/ous. On the form, see App.—au)toi/: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi, who occupied it in the autumn of 425 B.C. (iv. 49) and had not given it up again. Cf. v.30.15.

11. peri\ tau=ta: Schol. h)/goun peri\ to\ sulle/gein du/namin. On this use of peri/, see Kr. Spr. 68, 33, 2.—*eu)rume/dwn: having accomplished the voyage to Syracuse on which he had been sent (c. 16. 10), he was now on his way back to Athens, but meeting with Demosthenes entered immediately on his duties as joint commander, to which position he had been elected, c. 16. 8.

to/te tou= xeimw=nos: cf. c. 16. 10, peri\ h(li/ou tropa\s ta\s xeimerina/s. to/te used often of a time taken for granted as well known. See on i.101.9.—ta\ xrh/mata a)/gwn: cf.
c. 16. 12.
kata\ plou=n: as in iii.32.2. Cf. kaq' o(do/n, v.3.14; 37. 6.— to\ *plhmmu/rion...e(alwko/s : cf. c. 23. § 1.

15. *ko/nwn: without doubt the same who was prominent toward the end of the Peloponnesian War and later. He seems at this time to have had command both of the town and of the fleet stationed there. Diphilus no doubt came a little later, with reinforcements, to supersede Conon. Cf. c. 34. 13.
ai( pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi...a)nqormou=sai : cf. c. 17. § 4; 19. § 5. sfi/sin, sc. toi=s *)aqhnai/ois, is spoken from Conon's standpoint. For pl., see on c. 1. 27.

ou)/te katalu/ousi to
 po/lemon: Thuc. seems to have chosen the unusual expression, katalu/ein to
 po/lemon, “leave off military operations,” on account of the extraordinary circumstances. War had not yet been declared between Athens and the Peloponnesian alliance; and though arms had been gradually taken up everywhere, it was still possible to return to peaceful relations. The 25 Corinthian ships had been sent out with the special object of protecting the vessels intended for Sicily (c. 17. § 4; 19. § 5), and since these had now gone safely past Naupactus, there was no further cause for hostilities, and it might have been expected that they would abandon their hostile attitude (katalu/sein au)tou\s to
 po/lemon). But this was not the case; on the contrary, they showed an inclination to risk a sea-fight with the Athenians. This contrast is appropriately expressed by the co-ord. const. ou)/te katalu/ousi to
 po/lemon naumaxei=n te me/llousi. See App.
w(s: with acc. abs., as in i.134.21; vi.24.10; viii.66.20. GMT. 110, 2, N. 1; II. 974; Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 4.
duoi=n deou/sas ei)/kosi: pred. to ta\s e(autw=n. How the fleet of 20 triremes of c. 19. 28 had been reduced to 18 is not stated.
23. cumpe/mpousi: send along with. Cf. ii.12.11; iv.80.21.

peri\ th=s stratia=s to\n cu/llogon: for order, see on c. 24. 5. cu/llogos in the sense
of bringing together troops from all quarters only here, but corresponding to the freq. use of culle/gein. Cf. c. 7. 7, etc.
cunh=rxe: see on 11.— 28. a)potrapo/menos: i.e. giving up the voyage home (a)pople/wn in 12) and turning back toward Sicily. Cf. iii.89.5.—h(|re/qh: see on 11.

In Sicily, meanwhile, the Sicel allies of the Athenians, at the request of Nicias, attack the reinforcements sent by the Siceliote cities to Syracuse and destroy about 800. The rest escape to Syracuse.
1. oi( d) e)k...pre/sbeis : the subj. of the e)peidh/ clause placed first for emphasis. Kühn. 606, 7.—to/te meta\ th\n tou= *plhmmuri/ou a(/lwsin: refers to c. 25. § 9. As to to/te, see on c. 31. 12.

oi)xo/menoi e)s ta\s po/leis: the partic. is attrib. Thuc. is fond of placing the attrib. partic. after the noun whenever other modifiers are added. See on i.11.19. The cities esp. meant are Selinus and Himera, for Camarina and Gela are referred to separately in c. 33. 2, 4. Cf. c. 25. 38.
propuqo/menos: Vat. has only puqo/menos, but propuqo/menos is quite appropriate, and occurs besides in similar connexion in iv.42.14.

tou\s th\n di/odon e)/xontas: i.e. those who dwelt on the road leading from the northern part of the island to Syracuse. With this agrees the situation of *kento/ripa, Centuripa of the Romans, now Centorbi (Holm, I. p. 68), about 25 miles west of Aetna. A town Alieyae in this region is unknown. A place of the name situated in the north-western part of the island between Segesta and Selinus can hardly be the one referred to. Cf. vi. 88. § 4; 94. § 3.—sfi/si: from Vat. only, but indispensable with cumma/xous. For pl., see on c. 1. 27.

diafrh/sousi: Dobree's conjecture for the vulgate diafh/sousi, adopted by Bk., Bm., and St. A comparison with Ar. Av. 193, tw=n mhri/wn th\n kni=san ou) diafrh/sete, leaves scarcely a doubt as to its correctness. Cf. Etymol. Magnum, p. 246, 43, diafrw= shmai/nei to\ diakomi/zw kai\ ei)sie/nai kai\ a)fie/nai poiw=|.
a)/llh|: by another way, i.e. than the main road. Cf. c. 70. 27.—*)akraganti=noi ou)k e)di/dosan o(do/n: on account of their neutrality. Cf. c. 33. 7.

11. [tina trixh=]: Cl. brackets both words as inappropriate to the context; the rest of the editt. only trixh=. tina is wanting in Vat., trixh= in most of the Mss.—a)fula/ktois te kai\ e)cai/fnhs: the adv. modifiers in different forms, as in c. 13. 1, 2; 40. 10. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.
tou= *korinqi/ou: cf. c. 25. 39.
e)ko/misen: as in c. 29. 3, implying the idea of bringing through safely.

But gradually nearly all the Greek cities in Sicily declare for Syracuse, except Agrigentum, which remains neutral. Demosthenes and Eurymedon continue their voyage toward Sicily, and stop some time at Thurii.
2. oi( *kamarinai=oi: they had decided in the negotiations of the preceding year, e)n tw=| paro/nti mhdete/rois a)mu/nein, vi.88.14.
oi( *gelw=|oi: as to their zeal for Syracuse before this time, cf. c. 1. 21; vi.67.13.
e)s pe/nte nau=s: appos. to nautiko/n.
6. sxedo/n ti a(/pasa: almost all. Naxus and Catana were still wanting. a(/pasa is adopted from Vat. as stronger than the vulgate pa=sa. Cf. c. 15. 4. sxedo/n ti, as in iii.68.27; v.66.16.

ou)de\ meq' e(te/rwn: neutral, as in ii.67.34; 72. 11; vi.44.20.—oi( d' a)/lloi: resumes a(/pasa h( *sikeli/a after ou(=toi d' . . . h)=san, which on account of its influence on the const. of the remainder of the sent. is not to be put in parenthesis.
oi( pro/teron periorw/menoi: supplementary attrib. explanation referring to the Camarinaeans. periorw/menoi, exspectantes eventum, as in iv.73.5; vi.93.3; 103. 10.

11. e)pe/sxon to\ e)pixeirei=n: cf. ii.81.19; Soph. Phil. 881, mhd' e)pi/sxwmen to\ plei=n; Dem. XXI. 12, to\ lamba/nein di/khn e)ne/sxete. See on ii.76.4. e)pe/xein is not used in the mid. in Thuc., and in the sense “refrain from” perhaps only in aor.
e)/k te th=s *kerku/ras kai\ a)po\ th=s h)pei/rou: cf. c. 31. § 5.
to\n *)io/nion: without ko/lpon, as in vi.30.6; 34. 24; 104. 10. See on iii.107.4.
a)/kran *)iapugi/an: the promontory on the northern side of the bay of Tarentum. Cf. vi.30.5; 34. 22; 44. 9.

16. *xoira/das: in the inner recess of the Tarentine bay before the harbour of Tarentum, inhabited by Iapygians (nh/sous *)iapugi/as), to which people the tribe of the Messapians belonged. See Niebuhr, Rom. Hist. I. p. 146.
tinas: about, belonging to penth/konta kai\ e(kato/n. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 4. Cf. c. 34. 19; 87. 15; iii.68.16; 111. 17; viii.21.4.

*)/arta|: a prince of the Messapians, who was hostile to the Tarentines. See Niebuhr, ibid. p. 150. He is mentioned in Athenacus, iii. p. 108 f. (who cites this passage) as *messapi/wn basileu\s tw=n e)n *)iapugi/a|.
duna/sths : used in Thuc. only here of a barbarian prince.
tina: it is implied perhaps that Thuc. did not know the particulars.
th=s *)itali/as: added because at this point the boundary of ancient Italy begins. See on c. 25. 6.
22. kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n: the treaty has not been mentioned before.

a)nalabo/ntes: taking with them, as in c. 86. 3; v.64.20. tau=ta refers to a)kontista/s and trih/reis together. Vat. reads au)ta/s, which is perhaps preferable, since the 300 javelin-men were no doubt on the triremes.

e)s *qouri/an: the city, not the country, must be meant here, as in vi.61.36; 104. 13, for the country is called h( *qou-
ria/s in c. 35. 6. Steph. Byz. says that the name was written *qouri/a and *qou/rion, as well as *qou/rioi, and Eckhel describes a coin with the inscription *q*o*u*p*i*a. (Arn.) Thuc. uses *qou/rioi only of the inhabitants (below, 27; 35. 2; 57. 58; vi.104.22; viii.84.3). —katalamba/nousi...e)kpeptwko/tas : see on c. 30. 1.

26. ei)/ tis u(pele/leipto: to be connected, Cl. thinks, with e)ceta/sai. A final muster is meant, such as was called e)pece/tasis in vi.42.2. They wished, after bringing together all the gradually enlisted military forces, once more to examine closely whether all were present, no one left behind. St., claiming that with Cl.'s view the pf. is necessary, connects it with a)qroi/santes, which seems preferable, though the plpf. in indir. disc. might be admissible.
e)n tou/tw| tu/xhs: i.e. freed from the anti-Attic party. For const. see on c. 2. 16.
e)/prasson tau=ta: i.e. they were occupied with negotiations concerning a full alliance.

About this time the fleets of the Athenians and the Peloponnesians, which had been lying opposite one another in the Corinthian gulf, fight a battle near Erineus on the coast of Achaia. Each claims the victory, but neither gains a decided advantage.

2. oi( e)n tai=s pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi nausi/n: cf. c. 17. § 4; 19. § 5; 31. § 4.— 3. e(/neka: placed, as in i.57.10 (th=s *poteidai/as e(/neka a)posta/sews), between the objective and the governing gen., for tw=n o(lka/dwn depends upon th=s . . . komidh=s.
w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/a| : with the intention of fighting, as in iii.4.6; vi.34.33. Cf. w(s e)pi\ naumaxi/an in same sense in i.48.2; ii.83.10; 85. 12; 86. 3; iv.13.13.
prosplhrw/santes e)/ti nau=s: Schol. prose/ti a)/llas plhrw/santes. The arrival of fresh ships is implied. Cf. vi.104.12.
*)erineo/n: a small place on a bay of the gulf of Corinth east of Rhium, the harbour of the town Rhypes or Rhypae. See Curtius. Pelop. I. p. 458; Bursian, II. pp. 313, 330.

7. au)toi=s: the dat. placed thus early in the sent. has a general relation to the whole, and is only loosely connected with parete/takto. Cf. i.6.8; 48. 9, etc.—tou= xwri/ou mhnoeidou=s o)/ntos: the bay itself in which the ships had taken their station, so that the land troops could be drawn up on the promontories on either side, tai=s proanexou/sais (Vat., vulgate a)nexou/sais)a)/krais.
tw=n au)to/qen cumma/xwn : sc. *)axaiw=n, who were already at that time all on the Lacedaemonian side. Cf. ii. 9. § 2. tw=n au)to/qen as in vi.25.13 and freq.
e)mfra/casai: i.e. by their position barring the entrance to the bay. Cf. iv.8.22.

13. tria/konta nausi\ kai\ trisi/: in addition to the 18 triremes that Conon had, and the 10 given him by Demosthenes and Eurymedon (c. 31. § 4, 5), still others had prob. been brought by Diphilus. See on c, 31, 15.
15. a)rqe/ntos au)toi=s tou= shmei/ou: the raising of a flag or some such signal is implied. The opposite is ta\ shmei=a katespa/sqh (i.63.14). Cf. i.49.1; 63. 11; iv.42.20.
19. a(plw=s: outright. Cf. Plat. Phaed. 100 d; Phaedr. 257 b. Not found elsewhere in this sense except in late writers.—e(pta/ tines: see on c. 33. 17.

a)/ploi: Schol. a)xrei=oi pro\s pleu=sin. The word applies primarily to water hard to sail through, but is transferred by Thuc. here, as also in 33 and c. 60. 12, to unseaworthy ships.—e)mballo/menai: Schol. u(po\ tw=n polemi/wn new=n tupto/menai. It is pass. of e)mba/llein tini/ (i.49.28; iv.14.7). In c. 70. 33, 34 the act. and pass. occur together. The pres. partie. indicates repetition, the aor. (a)narragei=sai) the immediate result.

ta\s pareceiresi/as: for the acc. with the pass., see G. 197, N. 2; H. 724 a. The front part of the ship is
meant. Schol. pareceiresi/a e)sti\ to\ kata\ th\n prw/ran pro\ tw=n kwpw=n, w(s a)\n ei)/poi tis to\ pare\c th=s ei)resi/as. Cf. c. 40. 18; iv.12.5. It was bored through or ripped up by the violent blows of the e)pwti/des. a)narrhgnu/nai in this sense also in c. 36. 19; 40. 17.—e)p' au)tw=| tou/tw|: Cl. adopts the dat. (of purpose) from Vat., as in i.74.19, e)pi\ tw=| . . . ne/mesqai; ii.29.17, e)p' w)feli/a|; vi.31.14, e)pi\ braxei= plw=|. But there seems to be no certain example in Thuc. of e)pi\ tou/tw| expressing purpose, whereas e)pi\ tou=to occurs in c. 36. 3; iv.3.9; v.87.4.
ta\s e)pwti/das: a sort of calheads. Schol. ta\ e(kate/rwqen prw/ras e)ce/xonta cu/la. These beams projected like ears on both sides of the prow, and served to strengthen it.

23. a)nti/pala: acc. neut. pl. of inner obj. approximating to an adv., as a)gxw/mala c. 71. 21; e)nanti/a, iii.55.9. See on i.3.18; 38. 6.—w(s...a)ciou=n nika=n : w(s = w(/ste. GMT. 98, 2. N. 1. au)tou\s e(kate/rous (with order as in i.105.23; v.41.16), though referring to the subj. in naumaxh/santes, is in the acc., since the particularizing of the subj. in e(kate/rous requires an independent const. For the inf. clause expressing a qualification of the action, see Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 3.
th\n tou= a)ne/mou a)/pwsin au)tw=n: subjective and objective gen. respectively depending on a)/pwsin. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 7.—e)s to\ pe/lagos: i.e. towards the Athenians, who attacked from without.

dia\ th\n ou)ke/ti e)panagwgh/n: Schol. dia\ to\ mh\ e)pana/gesqai au)toi=s tou\s *korinqi/ous, i.e. abandoned the damaged ships. su)ke/ti in attrib. position modifying the verbal noun as in c. 44. 42. Kühn. 461, 6. See on i.137.26.—diekri/qhsan a)p' a)llh/lwn: as in i.105.22. The verb diakri/nesqai, meaning to desist from combat, occurs also in c. 38. 5; iv.14.22.

29. r(a|di/ws diesw/|zonto: (r(a|di/ws from Vat., for which most of the rest of the Mss. have kai/) escaped from pursuit easily, i.e. swam to the land when they were obliged to leave the sinking ships.
kate/du: to be taken as plpf., as is shown by a comparison with 19. No ship of theirs had been completely destroyed, and hence there had been no opportunity to capture the crew

33. kai\ nomi/santes au)toi\...nika=n : au)toi/ adopted, with St., instead of di) au)to/ (Vat. au)to/), since di) au)to/ (for dia\ tau)to/, or dia\ tou=to)di) o(/per is impossible. Render: and because they themselves considered that they were not defeated (for the very reason) on account of which the others did not claim to be victorious. Cl. explains di) o(/per . . . nika=n, “because the others did not claim to be victorious.”

ou)d' oi( e(/teroi nika=n: sc. e)no/mizon. On the one side, ou)x h(ssa=sqai=nika=n or kratei=n; on the other, ou) nika=n = h(ssa=sqai. On this equivalence rests the following explanation, oi(/ te ga\r *kori/nqioi . . . o(/ti ou) polu\ e)ni/kwn.
kai\ polu/ : giving strong emphasis, as in c. 41. 14. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 18. See on i.74.10.

37. a)popleusa/ntwn de\ tw=n *peloponnhsi/wn: emphatically contrasted with a)popleusa/ntwn de\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn in 30. The sailing away of the Peloponnesians signified that they gave up the idea of coping with the Athenians, and the latter therefore now definitely claimed the victory.
e)n th=| *)axai+/a|: on the coast of Achaia, without exact statement of the place, which is indicated only by the distance of the trophy from Erineus.
Demosthenes and Eurymedon, abandoning their intention of marching their land forces through the territory of Croton, embark at the mouth of the river Hylias and come by sea to Petra, near Rhegium.

2. pareskeua/sqhsan: had been induced; not equiv. to pareskeua/santo, but pass. of paraskeua/zein tina/, as used in iii.36.20; iv.132.11; viii.52.1. Kühn. 473, 2. It is the accomplishment of what was desired in c. 33. § 6, boulo/menoi . . . kai\ tou\s *qouri/ous pei=sai sfi/si custrateu/ein w(s proqumo/tata. In viii.52.1, we have pareskeu/aze kai\ a)ne/peiqen united in the same sense.

*suba/rei: the river near Thurii having the same name
with the destroyed city, on the site of which Thurii was built. Cf. Strab. vi.1.13 (where the gen. is *suba/ridos).
7. tw=| *(uli/a|: cannot be exactly identified.—prospe/myantes: as in i.53.2; iii.52.10. See on c. 3. 4. prope/myantes, which Portus proposes, is unnecessary.

ou)k a)\n sfi/si boulome/nois ei)=nai: on the periphrasis, see GMT. 112, 2, N. 8; Kr. Spr. 48, 6, 4. Cf. Sall. Jug. 84. 3, quia neque plebi militia volenti; 100. 4; Tac. Ann. i. 59; Hist. iii. 43; Agric. 18. Note the very rare inf. of indir. disc. after ei=pon. See Am. Jour. Phil. IV. 88.

e)pikataba/ntes: see on c. 23. 2. Cl. connects pro\s th\n qa/lassan with the partic., as in c. 23. 2; but St. takes it with hu)li/santo, citing Xen. Hell. ii.2.8, pro\s th\n po/lin e)stratope/deusen. Either view is admissible.
a)nabibasa/menoi: cf. c. 33. 18. Here to\n strato/n is to be supplied.
plh\n *lokrw=n: which was hostile to the Athenians. Cf. vi.44.13.
*pe/tran: usually called *leukope/tra. Cf. Strab. vi.1.7.

The Syracusans, hearing of their approach, determine to risk a second sea-fight in the great harbour before they arrive, and strengthen the prows of their ships in order that they may have the advantage of the Athenians in a battle in the confined space.
2. au)=qis: after the first sea-fight (c. 22, 23).—tai=s nausi\n a)popeira=sai: = naumaxi/as a)popeira=sai, c. 17. 14.

kai\ th=| a)/llh| paraskeuh=| tou= pezou=: Cl. explains, “and besides (cf. i.2.12; vi.72.17) by arming (and strengthening) the land army, as stated in c. 33. § 1, 2.” But in this case we should have o(/nper, referring to pezou=, rather than h(/nper. The sense is: to make trial with the ships and with the foot-force too (besides). Cf. c. 37. 3 ff. For this meaning of paraskeuh/, cf. vi.31.6. It is dat. of manner, rather than means; pezou=, gen. of description, not objective gen. On a)/llh|, see G. 142, 2, N. 3; H. 705.— h(/nper...cune/legon : the impf., since they were constantly expecting fresh troops from the allies. It corresponds to oi( d' a)/lloi e)boh/qoun, c. 33. 7. But St. and Kr. take this as equiv. in force to the plpf., which is perhaps better. See Kr. Spr. 53, 2, 8.—e)p)
au)to\ tou=to: see on c. 34. 21.
pri\n e)lqei=n: on pri/n with inf. depending on fqa/sai, see Kühn. 482, note 11.
pareskeua/santo: this and the following aors. used for the more exact plpf.
to/ te a)/llo nautiko/n: to\ a)/llo contrasted with kai\ ta\s prw/ras, “in every other respect they had fitted out their fleet in such manner, as—.”

e)nei=don: Vat. has ei)=don, but e)nora=n is a common expression with Thuc. for knowledge won by experience. Cf. c. 62. 1; i.95.24; iii.30.14.—ple/on sxh/sontes: = ple/on sxh/sein. Schol. tou=t) e)/sti pleonekth/sontes.
cuntemo/ntes e)s e)/lasson : shortening. See Graser, de veterum re navali, p. 28. Cf. viii.86.30, e)s eu)te/leia/n ti cunte/tmhtai; Ar. Ran. 1262, ei)s e(\n cuntemw=.
ta\s e)pwti/das : see on c. 34. 22.—paxei/as: pred.; they put on the prows cat-heads of great thickness or strength, i.e. made them stronger than they had been.

a)nthri/das: supports, braces, extending from the under side of the beams through the sides of the ship a length of nine feet both within and without. See Graser, Athens Kriegshäfen, Philol. 1871, p. 35, note; and compare the cut in de vet. re nav. tab. 2, fig. 10.—a)p' au)tw=n: sc. tw=n e)pwti/dwn; for the a)nthri/des served as supports for these.
e)piskeuasa/menoi: the Corinthians had in this manner refitted their ships. Cf. c. 34. 22. For e)pi-, see on c. 14. 6.

prw/raqen: Cl. explains, from the prow, i.e. attacking front to front with the prow (and the e)/mbolon), employing neither the peri/plous nor the die/kplous, as before (cf. 22). But it is better to take prw/raqen with e)piskeuasa/menoi, as St. and Kr., for the important point here is the strengthening of the prow, not fighting with the prow. This seems clear from ta\ prw/raqen e)xou/sas, below, which is contrasted with these words.
13. ou)x o(moi/ws a)ntinenauphghme/nas: not built in like manner to match them. Cf. c. 62. 11.
e)k peri/plou: by a circuit (around the hostile ship), i.e. from the side.

ou)k e)/lasson
sxh/sein: = ple/on sxh/sein. See on 6.

ou)k e)n pollw=|: as in ii.102.22, = e)n ou) pollw=| (ii.49.10), in a narrow space. Kr. Spr. 67, 10, 4.— 18. pro\s e(autw=n: to their own advantage. Cf. ii.86.19.—a)ntiprw/rois ga\r tai=s e)mbolai=s: St. has without doubt correctly restored, acc. to Reiske's conjecture, a)ntiprw/rois for a)nti/prwroi. Cf. 15; c. 40. 16.
a)narrh/cein: as in c. 34. 20.
pro\s koi=la kai\ a)sqenh=: sc. ta\ e)/mbola.
pai/ontes : reading of Vat. only; all the rest, pare/xontes.
21. ou)k e)/sesqai: = u(pa/rcein, in which sense ei)=nai, esp. with neg., is often used. Cf. below, 28, 35; i.2.5; 49. 11.—sfw=n: objective gen. with peri/ploun and die/kploun.

w(=|per th=s te/xnhs : const. similar to c. 33. 28, e)n tou/tw| tu/xhs. See on c. 2. 16. w(=|per refers to both the preceding nouns, just (per) the part of their naval skill on which they depended most.
diekplei=n: epexegetical to to\ me/n.— 25. w(/ste mh\ periplei=n: epexegetical to to\ de/. On w(/ste mh/ with inf. after kwlu/sein, see Kr. Spr. 67, 12, 4. See App.

25. th=| pro/teron...dokou/sh| ei)=nai : the same form of expression as in i.32.15. For the position of the partic., see on c. 32. 2 and i.11.19.— 26. tw=| a)nti/prwron cugkrou=sai: in explanatory appos. to the preceding clause. See App.

plei=ston...sxh/sein : Valla renders, se maxime superiores fore, which is doubtless his translation of plei=ston sxh/sein, as superiorem esse is of ple/on e)/xein. But St. writes plei=ston perisxh/sein, since no parallel example of the sup. with e)/xein can be found.
th\n a)na/krousin: backing water, i.e. backing without turning the ship, called pru/mnan krou/esqai in c. 40. 2; i.50.21, etc.—ou)k e)/sesqai: see on 21.

e)s th\n gh=n: i.e. to the coast behind them. Of this only the part where they had their camp, between the mouth of the Anapus and the swamp Lysimelea, was open to them.—tau/thn: St. (Pp.) and Goeller refer it to gh=n, and Arn. ap
proves; but Bm. to a)na/krousin. e)s o)li/gon is better connected with the idea of motion, as Kr. says, who compares, below 35, ou)k ou)/shs . . . th=s a)nakrou/sews. We might add also cumferome/nous . . . au)to/, 31.
di) o)li/gou kai\ e)s o)li/gon : through a short distance (to the coast) and to a small part (of the coast). e)s o)li/gon is explained by kat' au)to\ to\ strato/pedon to\ e(autw=n.
31. cumferome/nous e)s o)li/gon: driven together into a small space. Cf. c. 81. 11, cunh=gon e)s tau)to/; ii.84.3, cunh=gon e)s o)li/gon.

tara/cesqai : fut. mid. in pass. sense, as in c. 67. 15.— o(/per kai\ e)/blapte...naumaxi/ais : referring to the following events, “and it was just this which did the Athenians the greatest injury in all the following battles.”
e)s pa/nta to\n lime/na: contrasted with e)s o\li/gon in 30.

e)s th\n eu)ruxwri/an: = e)s to\ pe/lagos, outside of the great harbour.—sfw=n e)xo/ntwn th\n e)pi/pleusin: “since they had the power of entry (into the great harbour) in their control”; i.e. not only could they themselves enter at any time, but they could even prevent the enemy, esp. the expected fleet of Demosthenes and Eurymedon, from entering.

a)na/krousin: the art. not repeated, as in v.5.1, e)n th=| parakomidh=| th=| e)s th\n *sikeli/an kai\ a)naxwrh/sei. Cf. c. 37. 1. The position of te is explained by the close relation of the words in the phrase th\n e)pi/pleusin a)po\ tou= pela/gous. In 39 also the particle is thrown out of place by the emphatic position of polemi/ou. On Cl.'s conjecture, a)naxw/rhsin, see App.

Gylippus leads the land forces against the Athenian fortifications, and simultaneously 80 Syracusan ships sail out against their fleet in the great harbour. The Athenians make hasty preparations for defence by land and sea.

1. tau=ta: from Vat., for toiau=ta, answering to the definiteness and accuracy with which the refitting of the Syracusan ships and its object are described in the preceding chap.—pro/s: in proportion to. Cf. v.9.12.—e)pisth/mhn te kai\ du/namin:
the former referring to the acknowledged want of skill of their pilots (c. 36. 25), the latter perhaps to the shortness of the time, which did not admit of a greater improvement of the fleet.
teqarshko/tes: the pf. partic. expresses the confidence which they had felt now for some time.— 3. e)pexei/roun: were preparing to attack (impf.). Cf. c. 20. 7.

5. to\n e)k th=s po/lews: supplementary explanation which points to the following kai\ oi( a)po\ tou= *)olumpiei/ou.— 6. kaq) o(/son...e(w/ra: = kata\ tosou=to, o(/son tou= tei/xous pro\s th\n po/lin e(w/ra, on that side of it which faced the city. au)tou= depends on kaq' o(/son. Cf. iii.104.4. On the const. of the prep. with the rel. clause, see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 6.— oi( a)po\ tou= *)olumpiei/ou: cf. c. 4. 32 ff.

h( gumnhtei/a: found only here. The correct form from Vat. corresponding to the verb gumnhteu/ein; most of the Mss. have gumnhti/a. It stands for the concrete oi( gumnh=tes (Schol. oi( yiloi/), just as levis armatura is used concretely in Lat. The reference is to the a)kontistai/ of 16.— 9. e)k tou= e)pi\ qa/tera: ab altera parte, as in viii.33.7. Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 3. Cf. c. 84. 15; i.87.9.—prosh/|ei: the agreement with the last noun (h( gumnhtei/a), which is only in appos., is unusual.
e)pece/pleon: so Vat., for e)ce/pleon, indicating the purpose to attack. e)pekplei=n is omitted from the lexicon, but warranted by the subst. e)pe/kplous (viii.20.3).
11. kai\ oi( *)aqhnai=oi kte(.: Plut. (Nic. 20) states—whether on good grounds or not, cannot be determined —that Nicias was forced into fighting by the zeal of Menander and Eurymedon (c. 16. § 1).
e)pi\ ta\ tei/xh: (mounting) upon the walls, against those advancing on the city side (cf. 5). It is opp. to a)po\ tw=n teixw=n in c. 38. 5.

i(ppe/as te
pollou\s kai\ a)kontista/s: sc. o)/ntas, the appos. phrase explaining kata\ ta/xos xwrou=ntas. The o(pli=tai were behind these.
e)pi\ to\n ai)gialo\n pareboh/qoun: i.e. to aid any ship of theirs that might be driven to shore. Cf. c. 34. 10; 53. 5.
nau=s: Dobree and Bk. propose nausi/ as in c. 52. 4; but cf. viii.95.12, a)nh=ge ta\s nau=s; Hdt. vii.100.11, etc. For a like variety in const. with ai)/rein, see on i.52.5.
o)gdoh/konta: the same number with which they fought the first battle; the eleven then lost (c. 23. 19) had therefore been replaced.
But on this day they do not come to a general action, and on the following day Nicias seeks to strengthen the position of his fleet by transport ships anchored in front.
1. th=s de\ h(me/ras e)pi\ polu/: see on c. 11. 18. Cf. c. 39. 4.

prosple/ontes...peira/santes a)llh/lwn : Cl. and St. take prosple/ontes kai\ a)nakrouo/menoi as expressing the manner of the peira/santes, and hence omit kai/ before it: “after they had tried one another by advancing and retreating (backing) till late in the day.” The change seems hardly necessary.
ou)de/teroi: part. appos. to subj. of leading verb. Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 1.—a)/cio/n ti lo/gou paralabei=n: to win any advantage of importance. Cf. Hdt. vii.211.17. ou)de\n e)dune/ato paralabei=n.

ei) mh\...katadu/santes : except that the Syracusans sank a ship or two of the Athenians. Cl. explains that ei) mh/ is used elliptically, without finite verb, and cites h)\n mh/ in v.47.31. St. and Kr. understand (a)/cio/n ti lo/gou)pare/labon. Kühn. 577, 8. Certainly the verb is easily supplied both here and in v.47.31.—diekri/qhsan: see on c. 34. 26.

8. o(poi=o/n ti to\ me/llon: o(poi=o/n ti as in iii.28.5. Cl. takes it as an obj. of the verb, and to\ me/llon as adv., next (cf. vi.69.20). This is satisfactory, though Kr.'s explanation, = o(poi=o/n ti/ e)sti to\ me/llon o(/, is admissible. Kr. Spr. 57, 3, 5.

i)dw\n a)nti/pala ta\ th=s naumaxi/as geno/mena: seeing that their naval strength had become equal (aor. partic.), i.e. since the last battle, which had finally resulted in favour of
the Athenians (c. 23. § 3, 4). Or perhaps ta\ th=s naumaxi/as refers to the events of the previous day, which seems to be the view of Valla, pari eventu fuisse pugnatum.—e)lpi/zwn: expecting, as in iv.71.7.
e)piskeua/zein: cf. c. 1. 2; 24. 5; vi.104.20. See on c. 14. 6.—e)peponh/kei: of ships also in vi.104.20.

prow/rmise: not found elsewhere. The thing itself would not be likely to happen often. —pro\ tou= sfete/rou staurw/matos: which they had already built, vi.66.8, para\ ta\s nau=s stau/rwma e)/phcan. For sfete/rou, see on c. 1. 27.
a)nti\ lime/nos klh|stou=: i.e. to supply the place of a harbour which could be closed with chains.

14. dialeipou/sas: the pres., instead of dialipou/sas, which all the Mss. have, is necessary to express the idea of continuance required by the connexion. The Schol. has dialeipou/sas: h)/goun diistame/nas. The case is different from that in i.112.1; iii.74.1.
bia/zoito: pass. as in i.2.4, and freq.
kata/feucis: also in c. 41. 3; not found elsewhere.
Stratagem of Aristo. The Syracusans prepare to take their midday meal on the beach, with a view to surprising the Athenians.

1. th=s me\n w(/ras prw/|teron: earlier in the day (than before). Cf. iv.93.3, th=s h(me/ras o)ye/. For such adverbs with the gen., see G. 168; H. 757 a; Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 4. For the form prw/|teron, see on c. 19. 1.
th=| e)pixeirh/sei th=| au)th=|: in the same manner of attack, as described in c. 37. § 3; 38. § 1.
4. au)=qis: referring to th=s de\ h(me/ras . . . a)llh/lwn, c. 38. 1.—e)pi\ polu\ th=s h(me/ras: see on c. 11. 18.

peirw/menoi: the mid. used like the act. (cf. c. 38. 2), as also in ii.81.10; 85. 6; iv.132.13.—pri\n dh/: till at last; before critical events. Cf. c. 71. 26; iii.29.5. On the const. with indic., see GMT. 67, 1; H. 924; Kühn. 568,
1 a; Kr. Spr. 54, 17, 6.—*)ari/stwn: mentioned with praise also by Plut. Nic. 20, and Polyaenus, v. 13. Acc. to Plut. Nic. 25, he fell in the great sea-fight (c. 70).
tw=n meta\ *surakosi/wn: i.e. of all on the side of the Syracusans, those from abroad included.

sfete/rous: bracketed by Cl., as having no prop. connexion; but St. explains, “sfete/rous, sc. tw=n meta\ *surakosi/wn, ex quibus ipse Aristo erat.” Cf. c. 4. 10, a)ph/gage tou\s sfete/rous. See on c. 1. 27.
tou\s e)pimelome/nous: sc. th=s a)gora=s = tou\s a)gorano/mous.

th
 a)gora
 tw=n pwloume/nwn : “the market of all wares brought for sale”; in the army, of course, = o(/sa tis e)/xei e)dw/dima. Cf. Polyaenus, v. 13, th
 a)gora
 tw=n trofw=n metagagei=n e)pi\ th
 qa/lassan. Kr. and St. bracket tw=n pwloume/nwn as unnecessary and without parallel.

metanasth/santas e)pi\ th\n qa/lassan: so Vat., the rest of the Mss. para\ th\n qa/lassan metasth=sai komi/santas. But para/ is not used for e)pi/ with inanimate objects in Att. prose. Kr. Spr. 68, 36, 1. Besides, e)pi/ is confirmed by the passage cited above from Polyaenus. metanasth/santas indicates not only the change of place, but the removal with all the utensils necessary to the market business, i.e. the skhnai\ kai\ ge/rra, of which Dem. (XVIII. 169) speaks in a like case. metasth/santas would be nearly equiv. to komi/santas; but metanasth/santas signifies the activity that must precede the komi/sai, and therefore takes more prop. than komi/sai the form of the partic. But Kr. and St. write metasth/santas, because metanasth=sai seems to be used nowhere of things in this sense, while metasth=sai is so used in Eur. Bacch. 49; Polyb. ii.17.11.
au)tou=: Portus's conjecture for au)toi=s, on the spot, i.e. just on the shore, which seems to be confirmed by c. 40. 4. But au)toi=s might be ethical dat., as Arn. and Lamberton explain.

a)ristopoih/sontai: in the mid., prop. of the leaders, but implying also the sailors. Cf. viii.95.11, o( ga\r *)aghsandri/das a)ristopoihsa/menos a)nh=ge ta\s nau=s. For the fut. in final clause (though some Mss. have the aor.), see GMT. 44, 1, N. 1; H. 881 c.—di) o)li/gou: temporal as in c. 15. 13; ii.85.9.
e)pixeirw=si: co-ord. with the fut. a)ristopoih/sontai. The same change of mood occurs in reversed order in ii.72.20, 21.

The Athenians allow themselves to be deceived, and begin the battle without sufficient preparation. The Syracusans do them great damage with the strengthened prows, and with little boats which run up under the sides of the hostile ships.
1. kai\ oi( me\n kte(.: the rapid succession of short sents. connected by kai/ expresses vividly the execution of the plan.
pru/mnan krousa/menoi: see on c. 36. 28.
pa/lin: back; au)=qis (9), again.

5. w(s h(sshme/nous sfw=n: “in the conviction (w(s) that they could not cope with them.” sfw=n is pers. gen. with h(sshme/nous; elsewhere we find the gen. of impers. nouns, as tou= deinou=, tou= r(h/matos, iv.37.6; v.111.15.— 7. w(s oi)o/menoi: in the belief. On w(s with the partic., see Kühn. 488, 1 a, a. Cf. vi.32.21.

10. dia\ qoru/bou, kai\ a)/sitoi: see on c. 32. 11.—ou)deni\ ko/smw|: common expression in Thuc. (c. 23. 16; 84. 9; ii.52.5; iii.108.16), here having its cause in dia\ qoru/bou, as iii.108.16 in a)ta/ktws.
mo/lis pote/ : i.e. it was a long time before order was sufficiently restored to enable them to sail out for battle.

12. a)pe/sxonto a)llh/lwn: “they held off from one another.” Cf. sfw=n au)tw=n a)pe/sxonto, viii.92.52.—fulasso/menoi: i.e. guarding against unforeseen attack.—ou)k e)do/kei toi=s *)aqhnai/ois...a(li/skesqai : “they did not think best to wear themselves out with delay,” lit. to be overcome with weariness through themselves (i.e. through their own fault) by delaying. Lamb. compares Soph. Aj. 216, mani/a| a(lou/s. On the change of case in diame/llontas, see G. 138, N. 8; Kr. Spr. 55, 2, 7. St. adopts Madvig's conjecture a)nali/skesqai, which is used of animals in the sense overwhelmed, consumed (Plat. Prot. 321 b; Aesch. Ag. 553), and is no doubt admissible; but it does not seem to be necessary.
15. deca/menoi: sc. e)piferome/nous au)tou/s. Cf. iv.127.7.
w(/sper dienoh/qhsan: cf. c. 36. 18.

tw=n e)mbo/lwn: necessary emendation of Abresch, for e)mbolw=n; for here the beak of the ship is meant, in which sense e)mbolh/ does not occur in Att. prose. Observe, however, its use for a battering ram in ii.76.28.—a)nerrh/gnusan: cf. c. 34. 20; 36. 19.
e)pi\ polu\ th=s pareceiresi/as: “far into the front part of the ship.” See on c. 34. 21. For e)pi\ polu/ with the gen., see on c. 11. 18.
au)toi=s: sc. toi=s *surakosi/ois. For the const. of the dat., see on c. 34. 7.
toi=s leptoi=s ploi/ois: as in ii.83.26.

e)s tou\s tarsou\s u(popi/ptontes: Schol. u(poduo/menoi u(po\ tou\s tarsou/s, i.e. darting in among the banks of oars, thus interfering with the rowing, and injuring the oars. Cf. Dio C. 1. 32. 8, e)/s te tou\s tarsou\s tw=n new=n u(popi/ptontes kai\ ta\s kw/pas sunara/ssontes. Boeckh (Seewesen, 112) explains the tarsoi/ as the whole of the oarage.— 22. e)s ta\ pla/gia paraple/ontes: sailing against (not past) the sides (of the ships).
e)c au)tw=n: sc. tw=n leptw=n ploi/wn.

e)s tou\s nau/tas a)konti/zontes : hurling at the sailors. The acc. is used without prep. when hitting or wounding is to be expressed. Kr. Spr. 47, 14, 1. The missiles were doubtless hurled, as Arn. explains, through the port-holes for the oars. As to the size of these port-holes, cf. Hdt. v.33.12.
At last the Athenian ships, after great loss, seek refuge behind the line of transport boats. Elation of the Syracusans.

1. kata\ kra/tos: with all their might, to be connected with naumaxou=ntes, not, as the Schol. says, with e)ni/khsan. It is so used with poliorkei=n (i.64.14); polemei=n (i.118.21; ii.54.14); prosba/llein (iv.131.4).
dia\ tw=n o(lka/dwn: cf. c. 38. 11.
o(/rmon: the open place of anchorage of the Athenians (cf. vi.44.12), which they had tried to turn into a limh\n klh|sto/s (c. 38. 11 ff.).

5. ai( kerai=ai: similar contrivances to those that the Plataeans had erected to ward off the battering rams from their walls (ii. 76. § 4). As in the passage cited, beams (dokoi/) were attached to crane-shaped poles, to be let down, so here delfi=nes (Schol., sidhrou=n kataskeu/asma h)\ moli/bdinon ei)s delfi=na e)sxhmatisme/non), heavy weights of lead or iron in the form of dolphins, possibly with the tail sharpened for the purpose of piercing through the vessels, and thus sinking them. Cf. Liv. xxxviii. 5, tollenonibus libramenta plumbi incutiebant. Poll. i. 54 mentions this contrivance as one used even on triremes, u(pe\r to\ e)/mbolon delfi\s i(/statai, o(/tan h( nau=s delfinofo/ros h)=|. But this seems to be the only notice of the kind.

h)rme/nai: (pf.) always drawn up (not a)rqei=sai, occasionally), they hung threateningly over the intervals between every two ships (c. 38. 14), u(pe\r tw=n e)/splwn. As the interval was two plethra, the length of the kerai=ai was extraordinary; but they are to be conceived as stretching out from both sides over the intervening space. On the position of the partic., see on c. 23. 14.
7. e)pairo/menai th=| ni/kh|: flushed with victory.
prose/mican au)tw=n e)ggu/s: as in iv.93.4, prose/micen e)ggu\s tou= strateu/matos. Without e)ggu/s the dat. would be necessary. au)tw=n includes both o(lka/dwn and kerai=ai.
h( e(te/ra : the one (of these two ships), from which it follows that the crew of the other escaped.
10. katatraumati/santes: of ships also in viii.10.20; 42. 11. Cf. iv.14.5, e)/trwsan me\n polla/s; Liv. xxxvii. 24, multis ictibus vulnerata navis erat.
tropai=a/ te a)mfote/rwn tw=n naumaxiw=n e)/sthsan: see on c. 24. 3. The reference is to the undecided action two days before (c. 38. § 1), and the last far more important one.

tai=s me/n: so placed as if only to
 de\ pezo
 xeirw/sesqai were to follow.—kai\ polu/: see on c. 34. 35. —e)do/koun de/: weaker than th
 e)lpi/da (opinionem) h)/dh e)xura
 ei)=xon with which it is connected, “and they even thought.”
kat' a)mfo/tera: sc. tw=| te pezw=| kai\ tai=s nausi/. Cf. c. 50. 16; 59. 4; vi.31.17.

pareskeua/-
zonto au)=qis: refers to the preparations of the Syracusans before the last battle (c. 36; 37. § 1), and doubtless shows the zeal of Gylippus.

Just at this time Demosthenes and Eurymedon reach the harbour of Syracuse with a fleet of 73 triremes and a reinforcement of 5,000 hoplites and numerous light troops. Demosthenes, in view of the unfavourable results of the previous dilatory manner of carrying on the war, urges Nicias to a speedy attack, by way of Euryelus, upon the Syracusan cross-wall.

1. e)n tou/tw|: i.e. while the Syracusans were still making preparations (pareskeua/zonto). The day cannot be definitely determined. Grote (VII. c. 60, p. 141) considers it the second day after the sea-fight.

a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: as to Bk.'s conjecture, a)po\ tw=n *)aqhnw=n, see on c. 18. 4.—paragi/gnontai: refers to the entrance of the boh/qeia into the great harbour, and the union with the fleet of Nicias. It is strange that the Syracusans who controlled the mouth of the harbour (c. 36. § 6) made no attempt to prevent the entrance. Plut. Nic. 21 states that Demosthenes sailed in o(/plwn ko/smw| kai\ parash/mois trih/rwn kai\ plh/qei keleustw=n kai\ au)lhtw=n qeatrikw=s kai\ pro\s e)/kplhcin polemi/wn e)chskhme/non; but on what authority is not known.

trei=s kai\ e(bdomh/konta: this number consists of 65 (c. 20. 7), 15 (c. 31. 26), 2 (c. 33. 23), and Eurymedon's ship (c. 31. 11), minus the 10 given to Conon (c. 31. 21). Since the number is stated with such accuracy, ma/lista after e(bdomh/konta is rightly omitted by Vat. Plut. Nic. 21 agrees with Thuc.—cu\n tai=s cenikai=s: including those of the allies, i.e. of the Chians (c. 20. 8), the Coreyraeans (c. 31. 26), and the Metapontians (c. 33. 23).—o(pli/tas...pentakisxili/ous : Plut. and Diod. agree with Thuc.— 5. barba/rous: the 150 a)kontistai\ tou= *messapi/ou e)/qnous, c. 33. 17.—ou)k o)li/gous: Plut. Nic. 21 says a)kontista\s kai\ toco/tas kai\ sfendonh/tas trisxili/wn ou)k e)la/ttous.

8. ei) pe/ras...kindu/nou : if there shall not be to them a final escape from danger. For the prot. with ei) after kata/plhcis . . . e)ge/neto, see GMT. 77, 1 c. tou= a)palla)gh=nai is not governed by, but is explanatory of pe/ras, appos. gen. Kühn. 402 d. Cf. Dem. XL. 40, ti/ a)\n h)=n pe/ras h(mi=n tou= dialuqh=nai; Hdt. ii.139.2, te/los de\ . . . th=s a)pallagh=s . . . w(=de e)/legon gene/sqai.

o(rw=ntes : as if ou)k o)li/gon katepla/ghsan preceded. The anacoluthon similar to ii.53.13, where kri/nontes is connected with
the acc.; iii.36.8, e)pikalou=ntes with au)toi=s. Kühn. 493, 1 a.—dia\ th\n *deke/leian teixizome/nhn: see on c. 28. 25.
ou)de/n: merely repeats the neg. in ou)/te. The correlative of ou)/te is te.
i)/son kai\ paraplh/sion : cf. toiau=ta kai\ paraplh/sia in i.22.18; i)/sos kai\ o(moi=os, i.27.4; v.27.12; 59. 24.
pantaxo/se: in all directions, only here in Thuc., who uses elsewhere pantaxo/qen, though rather in the sense “for the most various reasons” (i.124.1; ii.53.11; 59. 8; vi.61.18, etc.).

w(s e)k kakw=n: w(s restrictive, as in iii.113.25: “a feeling of confidence (r(w/mh, see on c. 18. 8 and App. to vi.31.3) was restored so far as it was possible after their misfortunes.” Cf. Hdt. viii.101.1, tau=ta a)kou/sas *ce/rchs w(s e)k kakw=n e)xa/rh; Liv. x.43.15, agmine incolumi ut ex tanta trepidatione Bovianum preventum. On w(s, see Kr. Spr. 69, 63, 4.

15. ou)x oi)=o/n te ei)=nai: non licere. Cf. iv.22.10; viii.92.23.—ou)de\ paqei=n: sc. oi(=o/n te ei)=nai. Cf. vi.92.6, where a)ciw= is understood in like manner after ou)de/. So St. explains. For Cl.'s view, see App.
fobero/s: inspiring lerror, act. in force as in ii.98.20; iv.126.21, and below (26) deino/tatos.
e)n *kata/nh| diexei/mazen : cf. vi. 72 ff.
au)toi/: alone, without help from outside. Cf. ii.15.6; iv.49.5; v.60.4; vi.84.9.
au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *surakosi/ous, the obj., with which we must supply as subj. to\ metape/myai.

ou)=n : after a long parenthesis as in c. 6. 7; ii.85.10; iii.95.9; vi.64.13.—a)naskopw=n: reflecting on, renewing the idea of i)dw\n
kai\ nomi/sas above. Cf. i.132.8.

ma/lista: to be closely connected with th=| prw/th| h(me/ra|, on the very first day, so that these words form a strengthening addition to the sup. deino/tatos e)n tw=| paro/nti. On such intensive expressions with the sup., see Kühn. 349^{b}, 7 c.

o(/ ti ta/xos: as quickly as possible, in Thuc. only here. Cf. Hdt. ix.7.29. Kühn. 349^{b}, 7 e.— a)poxrh/sasqai: to get the full benefit. Cf. i.68.20; vi.17.5.—th=| parou/sh| tou= strateu/matos e)kplh/cei: i.e. the consternation caused by his army. The gen. is objective. Kr. Spr. 47, 7, 5.
28. to\ paratei/xisma: cf. c. 4. § 1; 7. § 1.

a(plou=n o)/n: cf. c. 4. 3.— e)pikrath/seie: from Vat., more expressive than krath/seie, which the rest of the Mss. have. Cf. i.2.10, th=s trofh=s e)pikratei=n; of persons, iii.93.16; viii.48.9. e)pikrath=sai = get the mastery of; e)pikratei=n (c. 43. 3) = be master of.—tw=n te *)epipolw=n th=s a)naba/sews: the objective gen. placed first, as often. See on i.32.8. The place of ascent was kata\ to\n *eu)ru/hlon (c. 43. 21; vi.97.11).

kai\ au)=qis: and furthermore, i.e. in consequence thereof. Cf. i.70.9; v.43.16.—tou= e)n au)tai=s stratope/dou: the hostile camp situated there, which is more definitely described, in its three divisions, in c. 43. § 4. Didot and Grote (VII. c. 60, p. 145) refer it to the camp of the Athenians made there after the storming of Euryelus (vi.97.24). They understand au)=qis = for the second time, but certainly incorrectly.
sfa=s: see on c. 1. 27.

e)piqe/sqai: = e)pixeirh=sai, with the idea of haste.—kai/ oi( cuntomwta/thn h(gei=to diapole/mhsin: “and considered it his shortest way of ending the war.” diapole/mhsin is pred.; the subj. is to be supplied from e)piqe/sqai th=| pei/ra|. See App.
35. tri/yesqai: wear out, as in vi.18.37. The fut. (Vat.) is necessary with a)pa/cein.
a)/llws : Schol. a)pra/ktws. Cf. c. 47. 17; ii.18.8; iv.36.2.
*)aqhnai/ous te tou\s custrateuome/nous: = tou/s te custrateuome/nous *)aqhnai/ous, i.e. not only the Athenians in the field, but the whole of the citizens at home.

After fruitless attacks on the cross-wall from the southern side, Demosthenes undertakes with the whole of the army, provided with all that was necessary, an attack from the north on Epipolae and the fortifications of the Syracusans situated there. They ascend the heights, and take the first fortifications. Even after Gylippus takes upon himself the defence, the Athenians continue to drive back the Syracusans before their impetuous assault, until they are checked by the stubborn resistance of the Boeotians, fall into confusion, and finally are forced to give way.
1. prw=ton me\n ou)=n...*)olumpiei/ou : with this sent., which is usually included in the preceding chap., c. 43 begins more appropriately.—e)celqo/ntes: sc. e)k tou= stratope/dou.

e)pekra/toun : sc. th=s gh=s. See on c. 42. 30.—w(/sper to\ prw=ton: i.e. after the fleet had united with the land army in the great harbour, vi. 103. § 1, 2. Later, it is true, Nicias declared in his letter to Athens (c. 11. 18), ou)de\ th=s xw/ras e)pi\ polu\ dia\ tou\s i(ppe/as e)cerxo/meqa.
ou)de\ kaq) e(/tera : i.e. neither by land nor sea = kat' ou)de/tera. Cf. ii.67.34, mhde\ meq' e(te/rwn. See on c. 41. 15.
o(/ti mh/: nisi, as in iv.26.5; 94. 9. Kr. Spr. 65, 5, 11.

tou= parateixi/smatos: the cross-wall (to\ e)gka/rsion tei=xos) begun by Gylippus c. 4. § 1, carried on c. 5, § 1, and finished c. 7. § 1, by which the completion of the Athenian wall of circumvallation was rendered impossible. Nicias calls it in his letter likewise paratei/xisma (c. 11. 15), and points already at that time to the present undertaking of Demosthenes, mh\ ei)=nai periteixi/sai au)tou/s, h)\n mh/ tis to\ paratei/xisma pollh=| stratia=| e)pelqw\n e(/lh|. See map of the siege.
prosagago/nti: the first fruitless attempt must have been directed from the south against the more eastern part of the paratei/xisma. The Athenians found here a strong and watchful garrison. See App.
pollaxh=|: at different points of the Syracusan cross-wall.
pei/sas to\n *niki/an: acc. to Plut. Nic. 21, Nicias long opposed the plan.—tou\s a)/llous: Eurymedon, Menander, and Euthydemus (c. 16. 5, 9).

w(s e)peno/ei:
only Vat. has w(s, the rest kai/ after e)peno/ei, which was prob. added after w(s dropped out.
13. a)du/nata: the neut. pl. accords with the usage of Thuc. Cf. i.1.11; 125. 5; iv.1.13. See on i.7.2. All the Mss. except Vat. have a)du/naton.
pe/nq) h(merw=n siti/a : gen. of measure. See on c. 2. 17.
liqolo/gous kai\ te/ktonas: as in vi.44.4. Cf. te/ktones kai\ liqourgoi/ in v.82.27.

a)/llhn: besides. See on c. 4. 12.—paraskeuh\n toceuma/twn: hardly appropriate between carpenters and what was necessary for wall-building. Madvig (Advv. I. p. 330) proposed moxleuma/twn, Meineke laceuma/twn (= laceuthri/wn, implements for hewing stones); but neither is prob. The correct reading is still to be found. sidh/ria liqourga/ (iv.4.5) would suit the sense.
a)po\ prw/tou u(/pnou: = peri\ prw=ton u(/pnon (ii.2.10). Cf. a)f' e(spe/ras eu)qu/s in iii.112.8; viii.27.27.

a)nalabw\n...e)xw/rei : unusual sing. after several preceding nouns, agreeing with the main subj. Cf. iv.112.9. The sing. at the beginning before several subjs. is common. Cf. i.29.6; iii.70.7; 72. 4. Kr. Spr. 63, 4.—th\n pa=san stratia/n: Diod. says, “10,000 hoplites and as many light troops”; Plut. “the foot force.”— 19. *niki/as de\...u(pelei/peto : with Euthydemus, as it seems. The impf. u(pelei/peto refers to his task of guarding the camp.

a)/ndras tw=n fula/kwn: tinas, which Vat. inserts after a)/ndras, is not in accord with the usage of Thuc. Cf. ii.33.13; iv.132.16; v.115.11; viii.71.18. a)/ndras has itself in these passages almost the force of tinas.

26. e)n proteixi/smasin: rightly added from Vat., referring to the defensive outworks out of which Gylippus sallies (39). They were
situated at some distance from one another, and abutted on the northern side of the paratei/xisma. See the map.
tw=n cumma/xwn: i.e. those from Greece proper.

toi=s e(cakosi/ois: this corps of the loga/des tw=n o(plitw=n (vi.96.16) which had suffered great loss (vi.97.20), had been restored prob. to its former strength, and stood here too, again, at the most dangerous post.
e)/frazon: informed them more clearly (impf.).

31. oi( d) e)boh/qoun te...kai\ au)toi=s o( *dhmosqe/nhs kte(.: paratactic const. for more vivid representation: “as they hastened to lend aid, the Athenians met them and put them to flight.” See on c. 4. 5.

tou= perai/nesqai: pass., not mid. as most editt. take it; for of the mid. of the simple verb there seems to be no example, though Plat. has diaperai/nesqai (Phaedr. 263 e; Prot. 314 c; Legg. 673 c, etc.). It can therefore be taken only with bradei=s ge/nwntai (not with o(rmh=|), which the Schol. correctly explains, to\ mh\ bradei=s ge/nwntai a)nti\ tou= mh\ u(sterh/swsi kei=tai; “in order that they, in the impulse of the moment, might not be slow about the accomplishment of that for which they had come.” G. 175, 2; H. 749. Quite different is the causal dat. bradute/rous tw=| a)mu/nesqai in iv.34.4, to which Kr. refers.

a)/lloi: as contrasted with au)toi/ (Demosthenes and the main body of the Athenians), Eurymedon and Menander with the rest of the Athenian forces.
