After the former had driven back the foremost Syracusans, the latter turned immediately to the attack on the crosswall (paratei/xisma).—a)po\ th=s prw/ths to\ paratei/xisma: the Mss. read to\ a)po\ th=s prw/ths paratei/xisma, which is impossible. Goeller transposed the art. as in our text. a)po\ th=s prw/ths means at the very beginning. This formula, as well as a)po\ prw/ths (i.77.11), a)po\ th=s prw/ths eu)qu/s (Luc. de Conscrib. Hist. i. 1), refers only to time. Matth. Gr. 282, 3.
h(/|roun te kai\...a)pe/suron : inchoative impfs.

38. o( *gu/lippos kai\ oi( met' au)tou=: Cl., referring to 27, thinks that Gylippus perhaps had taken com
mand esp. of the more independent Siceliotes, most of whom were in action now for the first time; Hermocrates of the main army of the Syracusans and the dependent allies. But Diod. XIII. 11 says that Hermocrates commanded the Six Hundred (29). It is more likely, perhaps, that oi( meta\ *guli/ppou refers to tw=n cumma/xwn in 28 (the allies from the rest of Greece), oi( cu/mmaxoi here to tw=n a)/llwn *sikeliwtw=n, in 27.
e)kpeplhgme/noi: i.e. from the very beginning, biasqe/ntes (aor.) in the course of the battle.—u(p' au)tw=n: sc. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn.
43. w(s kekrathko/twn: the pf. partic. indicates the fatal illusion: “feeling that the victory had already been fully decided for them.”

dia\ panto\s tou= mh/pw memaxhme/nou: the common use of the neut. partic. in a collective sense, as in c. 85. 12, 14; iv.96.17; vi.89.16. Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 17. So it is used in an abstract sense in i.36.3; ii.87.9, 10.

dielqei=n: to get through with them, as in iii.45.9, diecelhlu/qasi dia\ pasw=n tw=n zhmiw=n oi( a)/nqrwpoi. But St. understands dielqei=n in lit. sense, pervadere per hostes eosque dissipare. So Valla.—th=s e)fo/dou: with a)ne/ntwn, as in v.32.13, a)nei=san th=s filoniki/as. Kühn. 421, 3.
oi( *boiwtoi/: cf. c. 19. 17; 25. 13. The merit of the Boeotians is mentioned esp. by Plut. Nic. 21.
e)s fugh\n kate/sthsan: cf. iii.108.5; iv.14.4, etc.

The difficulty of maintaining order in the darkness and uncertainty turns the retreat into a wild flight, in which many perish, part in the pursuit, still more in leaping down from the cliff. Vivid description of the different events.
1. e)n...a)pori/a| e)gi/gnonto : comprehensive expression for the fearful situation described in § 2 ff. Cf. iv.26.8.

h(/n: placed first by prolepsis. Arn. explains that we should have expected o(/tw| tro/pw| cunhne/xqh, sc. h( taraxh/, but that e(/kasta having been inserted, the sent. is now ungrammatical. As it stands, e(/kasta seems to bear a sort of partitive relation to the subj. implied in h(/n.
ou)de\...r(a/|dion h)=n : this expression undoubtedly refers to Thucydides' own experience. See Introd. to Book I. p. 15.

ou)d' a)f) e(te/rwn: i.e. neither from Athenians nor from Syracusans. Cf. v.26.26, where Thuc. speaks of his care in
making accurate investigations: genome/nw| par' a)mfote/rois toi=s pra/gmasi. For position of the prep., see on c. 43. 4.
safe/stera me/n: not to be const. with oi)=den, but with something like ta\ gigno/mena/ e)sti to be supplied from cunhne/xqh.

o(/mws...oi)=den : “but still even of these things those who are engaged do not (know) everything, except (so far as) each knows with difficulty what happens just about himself.” pa/nta follows ou)de\ tau=ta in explanatory appos. oi)=den agrees with the nearer e(/kastos. Kr. Spr. 63, 1, 3. Cf. c. 27. 8, where e(/kastos takes a pl. verb.
dh/: belongs with mo/nh as in ii.77.7 with pa=san, i.33.13 with o)li/gois.
e)/n ge tw=|de tw=| pole/mw| : ge (from Vat.) as in iv.48.24, o(/sa ge kata\ to\n po/lemon to/nde.
a)/n tis...h)/|dei : the transition to the particular case was made at h(/, hence only h)/|dei, not ei)dei/h, which some Mss. give, is possible.
9. w(s...ei)ko/s : sc. o(ra=n, to which the following infs. are added in explanation.

th\n de\ gnw=sin tou= oi)kei/ou a)pistei=sqai: “to distrust their recognition of persons.” tou= oi)kei/ou signifies what was especial or peculiar, in direct contrast to tou= sw/matos. a)pistei=sqai as v.68.6, ta\ plh/qh h)pistei=to.
a)nestre/fonto : versabantur, as in iv.35.2; viii.94.9.
12. tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: i.e. those who, acc. to c. 43. § 3, 4, had first ascended the heights and immediately pressed on (c. 43. § 5). With these is contrasted in 13 to\ a)/llo stra/teuma.
oi( de\ e)/ti...e)xw/roun : i.e. were advancing unchecked with their first impulse. Cf. c. 43. 33.
au)toi=s: see on c. 34. 7.
pro\s o(/ ti xrh\ xwrh=sai: which way to turn.
ta\ pro/sqen: the troops that had first pressed forward.
xalepa\...diagnw=nai : with ta\ pro/sqen, as in i.1.10, ta\ e)/ti palaio/tera safw=s eu(rei=n a)du/nata.
18. w(s kratou=ntes: in the feeling of victory. The w(s of Vat. is preferable to the simple partic.

kraugh=| ou)k o)li/gh| xrw/menoi: “with loud cries,” to be taken with parekeleu/onto (sc. a)llh/lous) and kai\ a(/ma tou\s prosferome/nous (the Athenians coming up) e)de/xonto as shown by te, kai\ a(/ma.
a)du/naton o)/n : for the acc. abs. of impers. phrase, see G. 278, 2; H. 973; Kühn. 487, 3.
shmh=nai: common term in military language. Cf. c. 50. 26; v.71.17.

oi(/ te *)aqhnai=oi: i.e. oi(\ newsti\ a)nebebh/kesan. te is correlative to te in 17. Observe the repeated correlation with te, kai/ throughout the sent.—sfa=s au)tou/s: = a)llh/lous, as in viii.92.52. Kr. Spr. 51, 2, 16. The meaning is: those who were just coming up looked about for those who had gone before, but took all who came toward them, i.e. even their own people who were fleeing back, for enemies.

to\ e)c e)nanti/as: the correct reading from Vat. instead of the vulgate to\ e)nanti/on. Cf. Schol. gra/fetai kai\ pa=n to\ e)c e)nanti/as. For e)c e)nanti/as, from the opposite direction, cf. iv.33.5; 35. 11. For the neut. sing. in collective sense, see Kühn. 347, 3.—pa/lin: see on c. 40. 3.
tou= cunqh/matos: lo/gos e)n pole/mw| tw=n oi)kei/wn dido/menos, Etymol. Mag. Cf. 31 below. Cf. Tac. Hist. iii. 22, crebris interrogationibus notum pugnae signum.
ei)=nai: = parei=nai. See on c. 11. 15.—gnwri/sai: sc. a)llh/lous.
sfi/si te au)toi=s...e)rwtw=ntes : i.e. they caused confusion among themselves, because all were asking at the same time, and therefore no one got an intelligible answer.
safe\s au)to\ kate/sthsan: cf. i.32.6; 140. 30. au)to/, sc. to\ cu/nqhma.

27. to\ d) e)kei/nwn...h)pi/stanto : but their (the Syracusans') watchword the Athenians did not know to the same extent (ou)x o(moi/ws).—dia\ to\...h(=sson a)gnoei=sqai : sc. e)n a)llh/lois. The Syracusans had no need to ask for their own watchword, because they kept together (mh\ diespasme/nous) and knew one another.

e)ntu/xoie/n
tisi: sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi. tisi governs tw=n polemi/wn.

au)toi/ : the Athenians again, who throughout the whole description are those first in mind.—u(pokri/nointo: = a)pokri/nointo. Cf. Hdt. i.78.14; 91. 29; 164. 8. Understand here something like e)ntuxo/ntes krei/ssosi tw=n polemi/wn.

32. me/giston kai\ ou)x h(/kista: see on c. 24. 12.—kai\ o( paianismo/s: cf. Schol. on i.50.20, du/o paia=nas h)=|don oi( *(/ellhnes, pro\ me\n tou= pole/mou tw=| *)/arei, meta\ de\ to\n po/lemon tw=| *)apo/llwni. Cl. and St. adopt everywhere, though against most of the Mss., paianismo/s, paiani/zein for the forms with w(paiwn-). See on i.50.20; vi.32.10. Herodian recognizes only paian—.

fo/bon parei=xe : sc. to\ paiani/sai. The Athenians thought the pacan of their Dorian allies was hostile, just as that of the enemy themselves.— 36. oi(/ te pole/mioi o(moi/ws: sc. o(po/te paiani/seian.
39. kaqi/stasan: understand au(tou/s or a)llh/lous. Cf. e)s fo/bon katasth=nai, ii.81.27; iv.96.23. See on c. 43. 47. On the impf. for the aor., see App.
mo/lis a)pelu/onto: were separated with difficulty, of bitter contest, as in c. 63. 3; i.49.7.

41. polloi/: so all the later editt. for oi( polloi/ of the Mss., because acc. to the whole account, and esp. c. 45. § 2, the majority did not perish in this way. Besides, Plut. and Valla seem not to have read the art.—r(iptou=ntes: on the form, see App.—e(autou/s: for sfa=s au)tou/s. Cf. ii.4.18; 49. 22.
pa/lin: with kataba/sews as in c. 38. 16 with e)/kplous, c. 62. 13 with a)na/krousis. Cf. iv.10.14; v.5.1. Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 4.
e)peidh\...katabai=en : opt. with reference to the different divisions.

tw=n prote/rwn stratiwtw=n: i.e. th=s prote/ras stratia=s (c. 43. 21), who, as they had ascended Epipolae in the summer of 414 B.C.,
were better acquainted with the country.

diefu/gganon: for this fuller form, cf. fugga/nw, Aesch. Prom. 513; Soph. El. 132; a)pofugga/nw, Dem. XXIII. 74; diafugga/nw, Aeschin. 111. 10; Arr. An. iv.4.6; e)kfugga/nw, Aesch. Prom. 525; katafugga/nw, Aeschin. III. 208; Hdt. vi.16.4.
ei)si\n oi(/: part. appos. to oi( de/, as i.119.4, oi( a)/lloi, oi( plei/ous. Cf. iv.52.4; vi.88.21.— diamarto/ntes tw=n o(dw=n: also in i.106.3.
e)planh/qhsan, die/fqeiran: the fate of individuals (ei)si\n oi(/) stated in the aor.
The Syracusans erect two trophies. Losses of the Athenians.

2. h(=| h( pro/sbasis: sc. e)ge/neto = h(=| oi( *)aqhnai=oi prose/bhsan, corresponding to h(=| oi( *boiwtoi\ a)nte/sthsan. pro/sbasis is used not in a local sense, the way up, but with verbal force, the ascending (of the heights by way of Euryelus, c. 43. 21).
h(=| oi( *boiwtoi\ a)nte/sthsan: on the reading, see App.
u(pospo/ndous e)komi/santo: see on c. 5. 9.
ou)k o)li/goi: acc. to Diod. XIII. 11, 2500; Plut. Nic. 21, 2000.
o(/pla: esp. shields.

plei/w h)\ kata\ tou\s nekrou/s: cf. c. 75. 22; i.76.17; ii.50.2; v.102.2; vi.15.10. Kr. Spr. 49, 4.— 7. yiloi\ [a)/neu tw=n a)spi/dwn ]: yiloi/ is pred. The bracketed words Pluygers, Cl., and St. consider an interpolation. See App. Cobet proposed a)pw/lonto, but the impf. is prop. used of those who, scattered over the country (e)planh/qhsan, c. 44. 47), met their death, one after another, at the hands of the cavalry. e)sw/qhsan indicates only the final result.
oi( me\n...oi( de/ : part. appos. to oi( ga\r . . . biasqe/ntes a(/llesqai.
The Syracusans try to get reinforcements from Agrigentum and the interior of Sicily.
2. eu)pragi/a|: Thuc. uses equally the forms eu)pragi/a and eu)praci/a. Cf. iii.39.23, a)prosdo/khtos eu)praci/a.

pa/lin au)= : as in c. 64. 1, not pleonastic; pa/lin, back, i.e. into the former mood,
au)=, again, this change having taken place once already. pa/lin au)= and w(/sper kai\ pro/teron both belong to a)narrwsqe/ntes, and refer to c. 41. § 4, when a feeling of confidence had been conceived, and to c. 42. § 2, when this had again been lost.

e)s *)akra/ganta: Schol. to\n *)akra/ganta a)rsenikw=s. Cf. c. 50. 2. It is named from the river near by. See Schubring, Akragas, p. 5. The city had declared itself neutral, c. 33. 7; but now in consequence of internal disturbances (stasia/zonta) the prospects were more favourable for Syracuse. Therefore 15 triremes had been sent to the support of the Syracusan party in the city.

*sikano/n: one of the generals chosen with Hermocrates, vi.73.3.—e)paga/goito: must be preferred here, as in iii.63.5 (cf. v.45.4), to the vulgate u(paga/goito, as Pluygers (Mnem. 11, 95) rightly observes; for the object was to bring over the city to the Syracusan side, not to subdue it. Cf. c. 50. § 1.
a)/llhn: rightly added by Vat., as Sicily is opp. to Agrigentum. Cf. c. 7. 6, o( *gu/lippos e)s th\n a)/llhn *sikeli/an e)pi\ stratia/n te w)/|xeto, to which au)=qis in 6 refers.
e)n e)lpi/di w)/n: see on c. 25. 4.

The attack on Epipolae having failed, and the Athenian army suffering severely from sickness, Demosthenes proposes as hasty a departure as possible, in order that they may at least bring help to the hard-pressed mother-city.
2. pro\s th\n...cumfora/n : in view of the misfortune that had befallen them. See on ii.22.1.
a)rrwsti/an: as in iii.15.11, despondency. Cf. viii.83.7, a)rrwsto/teron.— 5. a)xqome/nous th=| monh=|: cf. v.7.3, a)xqome/nwn th=| e(/dra|.

no/sw| te ga\r e)pie/zonto...e)fai/neto : this sent. contains the reasons why the troops were displeased at remaining longer (h)/xqonto th=| monh=|), of which there are two: the prevailing sickness and the utter hopelessness of success. The first reason, which is introduced by ga/r, rests in turn on two grounds, of which the first is expressed in gen. abs., the second (to\ xwri/on . . . h)=n) in independent const. (cf. c. 13. 7 ff.). The second main cause, however (ta\ a)/lla a)ne/lpista e)fai/neto), is connected by o(/ti directly
with a)xqome/nous th=| monh=|, on account of the interposition of the irregular to\ xwri/on h)=n. The two reasons, the material one (sickness) and the moral one (hopelessness), are co-ord. by te, te as equally influential. In accordance with this view, Cl. puts a colon after monh=| and a comma after h)=n. So Arn. explains, but without altering the punctuation. Kr., St., and Bm. follow Reiske in omitting o(/ti.

kat) a)mfo/tera : for two reasons, as in viii.65.8.—th=s w(/ras tou= e)niautou=: cf. Plut. Nic. 22, metopw/rou ga\r h)=n h( a)rxh/. Thue. says in c. 79. 10, only a few weeks later, tou= e)/tous pro\s meto/pwron h)/dh o)/ntos. Cf. c. 50. § 4.
a)/nqrwpoi: on the omission of the art., see Kr. Spr. 50, 3, 6.
xalepo/n: hard to bear, i.e. unhealthy.

10. a)/per kai\ dianohqei\s...diekindu/neusen : so with Vat., for as the remark belongs to Thue., not to Demosthenes, diakinduneu=sai (sc. e)/fh, referring to Demosthenes) is impossible. Thuc. recalls the views which Demosthenes had held from the beginning. Cf. c. 42. § 5.

e)s ta\s *)epipola\s diekindu/neuse: risked (the attack) on Epipolae. Cf. iii.36.11, e)s *)iwni/an . . . parakinduneu=sai. Kr. Spr. 68, 21, 4.— 12. e)yhfi/zeto: i.e. in this council of the commanders only; yhfizome/nous meta\ pollw=n in c. 48. 5 refers to a general council to be held later.—to\ pe/lagos oi(=o/n te peraiou=sqai: i.e. before Nov.— 13. tou= strateu/matos...kratei=n : the part. gen. depending on tai=s . . . nausi/, kratei=n on oi(=o/n te, “while it was possible, at least with the newly arrived ships of the armament (even if little dependence was to be placed on the remainder) to prevail at sea.” The Schol. wrongly explains, tou= polemi/ou strateu/matos.

16. h)\ *surakosi/ous: i.e. h)\ pro\s tou\s *surakosi/ous. On the omission of the prep., see Kr. Spr. 68, 9. Cf. i.6.21; 21. 5; vi.78.4; viii.96.10. In iii.44.3, the prep. is repeated.—ou(\s...ei)=nai : inf. by assimilation. G. 260, 2, N. 2; H. 947.

ou)d' au)=: neque vero, as in i.10.31; iv.87.19, and freq. The thought of c. 42. § 5
is repeated in this passage with more emphasis.
proskaqh=sqai: of persistent siege, as in c. 48. 10; 49. 7; iv.130.9; vi.89.30.

Nicias, on the contrary, although secretly recognizing the gravity of the situation, still considers that of the Syracusans not more favourable, because they lack money and are not equal to the Athenians at sea. Besides, the secret information which he receives from the pro-Athenian party in Syracuse, leads him to hope for a revolution. But especially does he fear that their withdrawal without having accomplished anything will bring upon them the bitterest accusations at Athens, and even lead to their destruction. And since the Syracusans cannot possibly long keep up their great exertions, he insists on waiting for the probable ruin of their power.
3. po/nhra: Schol. a)sqenh=, e)pisfalh=, e)piki/nduna. For the accent in this sense, see App.—tw=| de\ lo/gw|: in open speech, i.e. in the council of war.

katagge/ltous gi/gnesqai: Schol. dh/lous dia\ mhnu/matos; “he did not wish that it should be revealed to the enemy that they (Nicias and the other leaders) in a full council (meta\ pollw=n) openly voted for the retreat.” With this personal const. of the verbal adj. with gi/gnesqai cf. viii.14.2, e)ca/ggeltoi gene/sqai; Hdt. ii.119.10, e)pa/i+stos e)ge/neto. See on iii.30.3.—laqei=n ga\r a)\n kte(.: sc. ei) kata/ggeltoi gi/gnointo kte(., i.e. they could not so easily retreat unobserved, whenever they might wish to do so, if, etc.

poiou=ntes: nom. referring to e)/fh to be supplied from e)bou/leto (4), and pl. since Nicias represents the Athenians. Kühn. 476, note 1, explains that it is attracted into the case of the subj. of the subord. clause dpo/te bou/lointo.
to\ de/ ti kai/: accedit quod, as in i.107.19; 118. 12.

a)f) w(=n...au)tw=n : “according to what he more than the rest knew of them.” Cf. vi.17.23; 20. 4. au)tw=n depends on a(/ contained in a)f' w(=n, and refers to ta\ tw=n polemi/wn. Kr. Spr. 47, 10, 2. Cf. v.26.25, cune/bh moi . . . kaq) h(suxi/an ti au)tw=n ma=llon ai)/sqesqai.
e)lpi/dos ti : also in ii.51.29. Cf. c. 69. 11, lampro/thto/s ti; iii.44.6, ti cuggnw/mhs.
xrhma/twn...e)ktruxw/sein : for they would wear them out by want of supplies. au)tou/s refers to the
Syracusans; the subj. of e)ktruxw/sein is the Athenians. The remainder of the sent., a)/llws te kai\ . . . qalassokratou/ntwn, seems to indicate that xrh/mata here means supplies, not money.

qalassokratou/ntwn: sc. sfw=n, the gen. abs., although the subj. implied in e)ktruxw/sein is nom. Cf. iii.13.30, bohqhsa/ntwn de\ u(mw=n proqu/mw|s, po/lin te proslh/yesqe kte(., where the subj. of the gen. abs. is the same as that of the leading verb. Kr. Spr. 47, 4, 2. Cf. ii.83.15, 16; v.31.7.—kai/ (h)=n ga\r...e)ndou=nai ) e)pekhrukeu/eto: the causal sent. in parataxis before the main one, not uncommon in Thuc. See on i.31.7. The subj. of e)pekhrukeu/eto is to be supplied from the parenthesis to\ e)n tai=s *surakou/sais boulo/menon kte(. The word is used here and in c. 49. 4 of secret messages, the bearers of which are called dia/ggeloi in c. 73. 27.
ou)k ei)/a: advised against. Cf. vi.72.7; viii.46.31.
16. e)p' a)mfo/tera e)/xwn: an unusual expression, inclining to both sides, wavering between two decisions, explained by diaskopw=n.

a)nei=xe : kept, with e)/xwn and diaskopw=n to complete the meaning. Schol. ou)demia= proseti/qeto gnw/mh|. Cf. Dio C. lviii. 12, e)/ti diaskopw=n o(/ ti pra/ch| a)nei=xe. It is intr. Kr. Spr. 52, 2, 3. Cf. ii.18.22; viii.94.11.—tw=| d' e)mfanei= to/te lo/gw|: in open speech at that time (as he was obliged to express his opinion in the council of war); opp. to tw=| me\n e)/rgw|.

ou)k a)pode/contai : “as in iii.57.5, would not approve=me/myontai, and so, like it, const. with ace. of thing and gen. of person. Cf. i.84.1, o(\ me/mfontai ma/lista h(mw=n.” Cl. But there h(mw=n is possessive gen. with o(/, here sfw=n depends on tau=ta.— 19. w(/ste...a)pelqei=n: explanatory of tau=ta namely, that they should withdraw without their order. w(/ste as in c. 14. 11; 49. 5; vi.88.47. GMT. 98, 2, N. 2.—ou) tou\s au)tou\s yhfiei=sqai/ te peri\ sfw=n au)tw=n kai\ ta\ pra/gmata...gnw/sesqai : the paratactic const., though logically the second clause is subord., “not the same persons would pass judgment on them and form their opinions.” etc., i.e. a class of persons would pass judgment on them very different from those who would form their opinions from seeing the state of affairs, as they do themselves, rather than from hearsay on the fault-finding of others. Bk. was right in striking out au)tw=n after sfw=n,
since sfw=n refers not to tou\s au)tou/s but to the speaker (Nicias) and his comrades.
w(/sper kai\ au)toi/: the nom. as in i.32.3; v.29.9; 44. 9.—a)/llwn e)pitimh/sei a)kou/ontas: so with Vat. rather than the vulgate a)kou/santas, since it is co-ord. with o(rw=ntas.

e)c w)=n a)/n tis...diaba/lloi : a)/n belongs to the opt. and not to the rel. “by slanders such as any one might bring forward (diaba/lloi a)/n) in fine speeches, they would allow themselves to be persuaded.” Cf. c. 50. 33; viii.54.6, o(/ph| a)\n au)toi=s dokoi/h. GMT. 63, 2. eu)= le/gwn, by fine speeches, is ironical. Cf. iii.38.20, a)po\ tw=n lo/gw| kalw=s e)pitimhsa/ntwn.
e)k tou/twn : epanalepsis, as in iii.64.5. G. 152, N. 3; II. 996 b.—au)tou/s: sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.
24. kai\ tou\s plei/ous: and even most. Cf. c. 68. 7; 80. 18.
bow=sin: cry out, esp. of indignant complaints. Cf. vi.28.9; viii.86.8.

u(po\ xrhma/twn kataprodo/ntes: becoming traitors for money. Cf. Lys. VII 21, u(po\ th=s e)mh=s duna/mews kai\ tw=n e)mw=n xrhma/twn ou)dei\s e)qe/lei soi marturei=n. kataprodo/ntes is used intr. Kr. Spr. 52, 1, 2.

e)pista/menos ta\s *)aqhnai/wn fu/seis: cf. c. 14, § 2, 4.— 28. e)p' ai)sxra=| ai)ti/a|: on a disgraceful charge. Cf. i.102.16, e)pi\ tw=| belti/oni lo/gw|; i.141.3, e)pi\ mega/lh| kai\ e)pi\ braxei/a| o(moi/ws profa/sei.

ma=llon h)\...i)di/a| : rather than incurring danger of his own accord to suffer this, if need be, at the hands of the enemy. kinduneu/sas has the principal emphasis. This idea is emphasized still further by the significant position of i)di/a|. For other advs. thus emphatically placed last, cf. i.28.12; 77. 19; iii.55.13.—i)di/a|: on his own responsibility, as opp. to e)p' ai)sxra=| ai)ti/a|; Arn. and St., for his part, i.e. he would rather lose his individual life, etc.
31. o(/mws: i.e. however bad their own condition might be, still—. Cf. v.61.3.
e)n peripoli/ois: Schol. e)n toi=s peri\ th\n po/lin teixi/smasi kai\ oi)kodomai=s. Cf. vi.45.6, e)s ta\ peripo/lia ta\ e)n th=| xw/ra| froura\s e)seko/mizon.
a)nali/skontas : sc. xrh/mata.

kai\
. . . e)/ti: et praeterea. Cf. vi.31.13, kai\ cu/mmaxoi e)/ti.
bo/skontas : maintaining, as in Hdt. vi.39.14, pentakosi/ous bo/skwn e)pikou/rous. It is not elsewhere used of men in Att. prose, but often in a contemptuous sense in the poets.
ta\ me/n, ta\ de/: the first is explained by disxi/lia ga/r . . . prosofei/lein; the second by h)/n te . . . pra/gmata.

e)/ti : Cl. and Kr. render hereafter (cf. vi.86.24, e)/ti boulh/sesqe): Arn. translates the passage: “Were in some respects ill provided, and in others, moreover, they would be utterly at a loss how to proceed.”
a)nhlwke/nai: on the aug., see App.—prosofei/lein: they owed besides, i.e. were in arrears with many payments.
h)/n te kai\ o(tiou=n e)kli/pwsi th=s nu=n paraskeuh=s: cf. c. 13. 3, ei) a)fairh/some/n ti kai\ braxu\ th=s phrh/sews.

trofh/n : pecuniam alimentariam, the common meaning in military usage. Cf. vi.93.20. In Dem. IV. 28, sithre/sion (= trofh/). —fqerei=sqai: fut. mid. used pass. Kühn. 376, note 1; Kr. Spr. 40 s.v.— e)pikourika\ ma=llon h)\ di) a)na/gkhs: Schol. misqofo/rwn toi=s *surakosi/ois o)/ntwn, kai\ ou)xi\ di) a)na/gkhn strateuome/nwn politw=n, w(/sper *)aqhnai/wn.

39. kai\ mh\ xrh/masin: it seems better not to bracket xrh/masi as Cl. does. The concluding argument of Demosthenes in c. 47. 17 was, “nor again was it proper to continue the siege, expending much money to no purpose,” i.e. the money consideration was his final objection to staying longer. Nicias's final argument was an answer to this, “they ought to continue the siege (tri/bein proskaqhme/nous) and not to go away conquered by money (by the money consideration), as they were much su perior (in this respect).” With this comparison the sent. becomes clear. If any change in the text is to be made, the emendation of Korais, oi(=s for w(s, most commends itself. See App.

Demosthenes is decidedly against the continuation of the siege, and insists, if they may not leave Sicily without orders from Athens, that they go back to Thapsus or Catana, whence they could ravage the enemy's territory with their land-force, and where they would have the advantage of the open sea for the movement of their fleet. On account of this difference of opinion much precious time is lost.

1. le/gwn i)sxuri/zeto: as in 23, insisted emphatically. The idea is, asserted confidently, rather than asserted persist-
ently. Cf. iii.44.9; iv.23.6.

polu\ to\ boulo/menon: the correction polu/, for the unintelligible pou of the Mss., is due to Linwood (Jahrbb. 1862, p. 202), who refers to the imitation of the passage in Dio C. xlv. 8, plei=ston ga/r e)sti to\ boulo/menon pa/ntas . . . a)llh/lois diafe/resqai. Cf. Plut. Nic. 21, h)=san a)/ndres ou)k o)li/goi dialego/menoi tw=| *niki/a| kru/fa w(/ste mh\ a)pani/stasqai. The art. is prop. with boulo/menon, since reference is had to c. 48. 13.—toi=s *)aqhnai/ois gi/gnesqai: Cl. is doubtless right in explaining toi=s *)aqhnai/ois as dat. of possession with gi/gnesqai, though in the examples he cites (iii.23.26; v.55.14; viii.57.8) gi/gnesqai seems rather = contingere, evenire. St. adds u(poxei/ria before gi/gnesqai, citing iii.86.18.

w(/ste: see on c. 48. 19. —tai=s gou=n nausi/n, h(=| pro/teron, e)qa/rshse krathqei/s: this is St.'s reading for h)\ pro/teron qarsh/sei (Vat. e)qa/rshse) of the Mss.: “and at the same time though beaten, he placed confidence in the ships at least, as before.” See App. For h(=| pro/teron, cf. c. 4. 22 ff. The connexion of the finite verb e)qa/rshse with the partic. ai)sqo/menos raises no difficulty. The anacoluthon is essentially the same as in c. 47. § 2. Cf. i. 57. § 4.
7. peri\...tou= proskaqh=sqai : as to the question of continuing the siege. See on c. 47. 18.—ou)d' o(pwsou=n: cf. c. 60. 20; i.77.9; viii.90.16; 91. 21.
e)nede/xeto: here, as in v.15.9, without def. obj., which is easily supplied from the context.
au)tou=: there, i.e. in Sicily. Kr.'s emendation, adopted by Cl. and St., for au)tou/s, which as the subj. of tri/bein is without force and unnecessary, even if admissible.
*qa/yon: where the fleet on the voyage out had lain for some time. Cf. vi.97.9.—*kata/nhn: here too the fleet had made a long stay, vi.50.10 to vi.97.3.
e)pi\ polla\ th=s xw/ras: see on c. 11. 18.— qre/yontai: = to\ stra/teuma qre/yousi, the fut. in rel. clause of purpose, as in vi.21.7.
pro\s tw=n polemi/wn: in the enemy's favour. See on c. 36. 18. For the facts, cf. c. 36. § 3, 4.

e)n h(=| ta/ te th=s e)mpeiri/as xrh/sima sfw=n e)/stai: where the advantages of skill will be theirs. Some editt. take xrh/sima as pred. and sfw=n with e)mpeiri/as, but in this case sfi/sin would be more natural.

ou)k e)k braxe/os kai\ perigraptou=: belongs to the parties. o(rmw/menoi/ te kai\ katai/rontes, though in form appropriate only to the former, since with katai/rontes we should prop. have e)s with ace. The parties. stand too in chiastic order as compared with a)naxwrh/seis and e)pi/plous.
e(/cousi : “they will have in their power.” See on c. 36. 37.
to\ cu/mpan ei)pei=n: inf. used abs. in parenthetical phrase. GMT. 100; H. 956. Cf. i.138.17.

o(/ti ta/xista h)/dh e)cani/stasqai kai\ mh\ me/llein: so restored by Haase (Lucubr. Thuc. p. 58) instead of o(/ti ta/xista h)/dh kai\ mh\ me/llein e)cani/stasqai. Cf. v.30.29, e)ke/leuon tou\s *korinqi/ous i)e/nai e)s th\n cummaxi/an kai\ mh\ me/llein, which proves that in our passage there has been only a careless change in the order of the words. e)cani/stasqai means to withdraw from their position. Cf. a)pani/stasqai (5) depart, a)nasth=nai (10) retire, remore.
cunhgo/reuen: cf. vi.6.26.

22. e)ge/neto: so Vat., confirmed by the imitation of Jos. A. I. Prooem. 2, o)/knos moi kai\ me/llhsis e)ge/neto. Some other Mss. have e)nege/neto, which Thue. uses with the dat. Cf. c. 80. 12; i.2.16; ii.49.32; 62. 29.—ti kai\ ple/on ei)dw/s: cf. v.29.12, ple/on te/ ti ei)do/tas.
dieme/llhsan : they came to delay (aor.).

The Syracusans in the meantime get fresh reinforcements; in the army of the Athenians the sickness keeps spreading, and Nicias becomes more inclined to depart. The decision is now made, and everything is ready for the departure, when an eclipse of the moon occurs. The superstitious Nicias thereupon refuses to stir until thrice nine days have passed, as the soothsayers direct.
1. o( de\ *gu/lippos kai\ o( *sikano/s: cf. c. 46.—parh=san e)s: as in vi.88.51. Cf. ii.34.11, parei=nai e)pi/; iii.3.19, parei=nai para/.

h( toi=s *surakosi/ois sta/sis fili/a : the party friendly to the Syracusans. fili/a is Bauer's conjec
ture for e)s fi/lia, e)s fili/an, e)s fili/a (Vat.) of the Mss. See App. toi=s *surakosi/ois belongs to fili/a, and the attrib. adj. is placed after its noun as in iii.56.5, kata\ to\n pa=si no/mon kaqestw=ta; iv.122.19, th=| kata\ gh=n *lakedaimoni/wn i)sxu/i a)nwfelei=. Cf. 7 below and c. 23. 15.
a)/llhn te stratia/n: cf. c. 21. § 1. Acc. to Diod. XII. 12, this army was collected from Selinus, Gela, Himera, and Camerina.
tou\s e)k th=s *peloponnh/sou...a)postale/ntas : cf. c. 19. § 3.

8. a)penexqe/ntes e)s *libu/hn: i.e. driven thither by storms. Cf. vi.104.16, a(rpasqei\s u(p' a)ne/mou . . . a)pofe/retai e)s to\ pe/lagos. Niebuhr's view of an intentional voyage in that direction (Lectures on Anc. Hist. H. p. 160) is therefore wrong.
*eu)esperi/tais: Steph. Byz. *eu)espe/rides po/lis *libu/hs. to\ e)qniko\n *eu)esperi/ths. It is the later Berenice, west from Barea, near the great Syrtis.

*ne/an po/lin: cf. Strab. xvii.3.16; not to be confounded with the Neapolis which is also called Leptis, Strab. xvii.3.18. See Kiepert, Alte Geogr. p. 193, 197.— o(/qenper *sikeli/a e)la/xiston du/o h(merw=n kai\ nukto\s plou=n a)pe/xei: correctly emended by Bm. for o(/qen pro\s *sikeli/an . . . plou=s (Vat. plou=n)a)pe/xei. Cf. vi.2.38, e)nteu=qen e)la/xiston plou=n *karxhdw\n *sikeli/as a)pe/xei. For plou=s as a measure of distance, see on iv.104.17. o(/qenper as in iv.73.27.— 14. e)s *selinou=nta: they went thither next because it was in alliance with Syracuse, vi. 48. From there Gylippus brings them to Syracuse, 5.

19. e)pi\ to\ be/ltion xwrou=nta: cf. e)pi\(e)s)to\ mei=zon e)pidido/nai, vi.60.8;
viii.24.22.

kaq' h(me/ran: in dies, with the comp. also in vi.60.8; 63. 5.—toi=s pa=si: in every respect. Cf. v.28.12.—xalepw/teron i)/sxonta: growing worse. i)/sxein intr. here and Plat. Lach. 181 e; elsewhere trans. See on iii.58.26.
meteme/lonto: with past partic., as in iv.27.13, ou) deca/menoi; v.35.17, a)podedwko/tes.
o(moi/ws : i.e. as hitherto. Cf. i.75.12; 99. 6.—a)ll' h)/: nisi, praeterquam. Kr. Spr. 69, 4, 6. Cf. iii.71.4; v.60.5; 80. 6; viii.28.9. See App.

proei=pon...shmh/nh| : as secretly as possible they gare orders for departure to all and to be prepared (i.e. to sail out) whenever the signal should be given. The orders were given to the trierarchs (pa=si) secretly, lest the soldiers might find out the plan and by some imprudence disclose it to the enemy. Cf. c. 48. 5. Abresch's emendation pareskena/sqai (for paraskeua/sasqai) is necessary, since it is clear that the orders must be to be ready (to sail out) when the signal shall be given, not then first to get ready (paraskeua/sasqai). Cf. Plut. Nic. 22, parh/ggeile toi=s stratiw/tais eu)trepei=s ei)=nai pro\s a)po/ploun. For Cl.'s view, who reads [kai\] paraskeua/sasqai, see App.
26. e)peidh\ e(toi=ma h)=n: constant expression. Cf. ii.3.15; 10. 5; 56. 3; 98. 2.
h( selh/nh e)klei/pei: Aug. 27, 413 B.C. See Heis, Die Finsternisse w. d. Pelop. Krieges, p. 11.— 28. oi( *)aqhnai=oi oi(/ te plei/ous...kai\ o( *niki/as : part. appos. Cf. c. 71. § 1.

e)nqu/mion poiou/menoi: making it a matter of religion. Cf. v.16.18, e)s e)nqumi/an proba/llein; Hdt. viii.54.8, e)nqu/mio/n oi( e)ge/neto e)mprh/santi to\ i(ro/n; Eur. Here. 722, soi\ to/d) e)/st) e)nqu/mion.
kai\ a)/gan qeiasmw=| : Schol. eu)xh=| kai\ mantei/a|, all religious usages and practices, whose observance is called qeia/zein in viii.1.8.
proskei/menos: inclined to, as in vi.89.13; viii.89.22.— ou)d' a)\n diabouleu/sasqai: would not even allow a consultation, i.e. about the question contained in o(/pws a)\n pro/teron kinhqei/h.

e)chgou=nto : regularly used of seers and priests. Cf. Eur.
Phoen. 1011; Iph. Aul. 529; Plat. Theag. 131; Xen. Cyrop. vii.5.57; viii.3.11.—tri\s e)nne/a h(me/ras: prob. acc. to priestly law, as in the prediction of the tri\s e)nne/a e)/th, v.26.22. Diod. XIII. 13 gives only ta\s ei)qisme/nas trei=s h(me/ras; Plut. Nic. 23 relates, *niki/as a)/llhn e)/peise selh/nhs a)name/nein peri/odon. The statement of Thuc. is certainly not to be questioned, even though they did not actually remain 27 days. See Ullrich, Quaest. Aristoph. p. 40.—o(/pws...kinhqei/h : indir. question representing pot. opt. of dir. disc.
kai\ toi=s...e)gege/nhto : and so the Athenians, having once delayed for this reason, must stay. Cl. proposes e)ge/neto for e)gege/nhto; more likely would be e)nege/neto.

So much the more are the Syracusans filled with hope of victory, and spend several days manœuvering preparatory to a sea-fight. But they first make a preliminary attack on the Athenian fortifications from the land side, and drive back a small party of the Athenians who come out against them.

1. tou=to: i.e. both the intention to depart and the abandonment of it.— 2. e)phrme/noi: Vat. for the vulgate e)ghgerme/noi, which is unusual in this sense in prose writers. e)phrme/noi signifies the confidence of victory (cf. c. 41. 7) with the added idea of lively excitement which urged them to vigorous action (cf. ii.11.9; viii.2.3), the enhancement of the idea of a)narrwsqe/ntes of c. 46. 2: “they were full of confident resolution.”—mh\ a)nie/nai: as in c. 18. 7; vi.18.16, not to be slack about.

w(s...pezw=| : since even they themselves evidently had already come to the conclusion that they were no longer superior to them either by sea or land. kategnwko/twn of unfavourable judgment, as in iii.45.4. au)tw=n = tw=n *)aqhnai/wn; sfw=n = tw=n *surakosi/wn. The latter is governed by kreisso/nwn.
ou) ga\r a)\n...e)pibouleusai : for otherwise they would not have projected the departure. Cf. i.11.5; 68. 18; iii.84.13. For the inf. in indir. dise., see Kr. Spr. 65, 11, 7.
kai\ a(/ma ou) boulo/menoi: co-ord. with the gen. abs. clause as second reason for e)phrme/noi h)=san. Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.

a)/llose/ poi...prospolemei=n : not wishing that they should establish themselves anywhere else in Sicily and be harder to contend with. For th=s *sikeli/as as part. gen. depending on adv. of place, see G. 168; H. 757. On the matter, cf. c. 49. § 2. For const. of xalepwte/rous prospolemei=n, see on c. 14. 5.
8. ta\s nau=s_ e)plh/roun kai\ a)nepeirw=nto: exaetly as in c. 7. 14. a)nepau/onto, the reading of most of the Mss., including Vat., does not agree with the context.

th=| me\n prote/ra|: on the first (of the two days that come under consideration), opp. to th=| d' u(sterai/a|, c. 52. 3. Herbst (Geg. Cobet, p. 36) has shown that h( prote/ra (not proterai/a, which Vat. has here) is used only where reference is made from the earlier to the later day; where it is made from the later to the earlier (as in i.54.16), h( proterai/a is used.
prose/ballon: inchoative impf.
a)polamba/nousi: cut off. Cf. v.8.16.
treya/menoi katadiw/kousin: referring to the whole force, not the o(plitw=n tinas, as shown by what follows.

th=s e)so/dou: the entrance (to the fortifications of the Athenians).—i(/ppous: understood by some (Heilmann, and Holm, H. p. 56) of horsemen; but the repetition tou\s i(/ppous in c. 54. 3 makes it prob. that the reference is only to horses. In the jam at the gates the horsemen prob. abandoned their horses and escaped.
a)pollu/ousi: as in iv.25.19; in viii.10.16 a)pollu/asi. Both forms seem to have been used by the older Att. writers.
On the following day the two fleets come to an engagement. The Syracusans conquer at first in the centre, then defeat the right wing, slaying Eurymedon, and at last drive the whole fleet ashore.

3. e(\c kai\ e(bdomh/konta: 76 Syracusan and 86 Athenian ships against 80 and 75 respectively in the previous sea-fight, c. 37. 19, 20. No reason is given for the variation in the numbers; the Athenians prob. did not fit out a larger number now, after the arrival of the 73 fresh ships (c. 42. 3), on account of the narrow space.
a)ntanh=gon nausi/n: see on c. 37. 19.
e)nauma/xoun: began the battle (impf.).

8. e)peca/gonta: so Cl. and St., following Vat.; other editt. since Bk. e)pecagago/nta (with a few Mss., most having e)ca/gonta). The pres. expresses vividly the moment when Eurymedon, extending his line, or perhaps drawing off (cf. Diod. xiii. 13, w(s a)pespa/sqh th=s ta/cews), to the right, in order to turn the left wing of the enemy, approaches too near the land, and is cut off. Cf. v.71.14, dei/sas de\ *)/agis mh\ sfw=n kuklwqh=| to\ eu)w/numon, kai\ nomi/sas a)/gan perie/xein tou\s *mantine/as, toi=s me\n *skiri/tais kai\ *brasidei/ois e)sh/mhnen e)pecagago/ntas a)po\ sfw=n e)cisw=sai toi=s *mantineu=sin. In this passage the aor. is necessary before e)cisw=sai.
ka)kei=non : referring to *eu)rume/donta mentioned above and emphatically repeating it after nikh/santes to\ me/son prw=ton.

e)n tw=| koi/lw| kai\ muxw=| tou= lime/nos : in a recess of the inner bay of the harbour. Diod., who in the account of the battle (xiii. 13) follows in many particulars good authority, prob. Philistus, says: a)pelh/fqh pro\s to
 ko/lpon to
 *da/skwna me
 kalou/menon. katakleisqei\s d' ei)s steno
 to/pon kai\ biasqei\s ei)s th
 gh=n e)kpesei=n, au)to\s me
 u(po/ tinos trwqei\s kairi/a| plh/gh| to
 bi/on meth/llacen: e(pta\ de\ nau=s e)n tou/tw| tw=| to/pw| diefqa/rhsan. The steno\s to/pos is named by Thuc. koi=lon, a recess of some depth at the foot of the hill of the same name, Dascon (vi.66.9), in addition to the more general designation of muxo\s tou= lime/nos of c. 4. 21. Therefore koi/lw| kai/ is not to be bracketed as v. H. (Stud. p. 100) proposes. With much probability, however, v. H. conjectures from the above passage of Diod. that e(pta/ has dropped out after e)pispome/nas.
met) au)tou= e)pispome/nas : as in c. 57. 47, meta\ *)aqhnai/wn h)kolou/qoun. As to the position of the partic., see on c. 23. 14.
ta\s pa/sas h)/dh nau=s: so Vat.; vulgate nau=s h)/dh. Cf. viii.26.1, peri\ dei/lhn h)/dh o)yi/an; viii.56.19, e)n th=| tri/th| h)/dh cuno/dw|.

In the attempt to secure the Attic ships on the shore, the Syracusans are driven back with great loss; but they take 18 ships and kill the crews. An attempt to set the remaining ships on fire is baffled by the Athenians.
2. e)/cw tw=n staurwma/twn: cf. c. 38. § 2; vi. 66. § 2.—kai\ tou= e(autw=n stratope/dou: see on c. 23. 8.

kataferome/nas: driven to shore, as in
c. 71. 31.

a)fe/lkein: cf. c. 74. 12 ff.; ii.93.25. Cl. is clearly wrong in writing a)ne/lkein for a)fe/lkein, and Grote's view is right: “Gylippus marched down his land force to the water's edge, in order to prevent the retreat of the crews, as well as to assist the Syracusan seamen in hauling off the ships as prizes.” So also Thirlwall understands it. The tau/th| of 7 shows that that part of the shore was rather in the possession of the Athenians, and th=s gh=s fili/as ou)/shs (St. si ab amicis teneretur) means that Gylippus expected to make that part of the shore friendly by the aid he brought, not that it was then so. Besides, the issue, as related in § 3, shows how dangerous it would have been for the Syracusans to draw the ships up on shore at that point. After the great sea-fight, they did without opposition what they now wished to do, namely, took the ships in tow, and brought them to the city (c. 74. fin.).
e)pi\ th\n xhlt/n: to the causeway. This was a quay which ran along by the swamp Lysimelea toward the Athenian camp. See the map.
6. oi( *turshnoi/: an Etruscan auxiliary corps which acc. to promise (vi.88.34) had joined the Athenians, with three fifty-oared boats (vi.103.10).
ou(=toi ga\r e)fu/lasson toi=s *)aqhnai/ois tau/th|: for these had been stationed by the Athenians on guard in that quarter, i.e. on the northern side of the camp.
prosferome/nous: sc. tou\s *surakosi/ous.
e)pekbohqh/santes : cf. viii.55.18.
th\n *lusime/leian kaloume/nhn: cf. c. 80. 20. The place is called to\ e(/los in vi.101.2. See Holm, I. p. 12.
11. paro/ntos: partic. from parh=n in sense of the aor. Cf. c. 50. 1; i.47.5.
e)pibohqh/santes kai\ dei/santes peri\ tai=s nausi/n: the effect and the cause (dei/santes) placed co-ord., as in i.1.3, a)rca/menos . . . kai\ e)lpi/sas.
e)s ma/xhn kate/sthsan : = katasta/ntes e)ma/xonto (i.49.10), i.e. it came to a regular battle.

cunh/gagon kata\ to\ strato/pedon: i.e. they brought them again into safety
behind the staurw/mata (2) in front of the camp.—duoi=n de\ deou/sas ei)/kosin...e)/labon au)tw=n : Grote thinks that these 18 ships had belonged to the division, which was out of reach of all help, in the bay of Dascon. But Cl. is doubtless right in considering this loss of 18 captured ships to be different from that of the (seven) ships of Eurymedon that were destroyed (diafqei/rousi) as stated in c. 52. 11. The muxo\s tou= lime/nos at the foot of Dascon was on the opposite side of the Lysimelea from the Athenian camp.
19. da|do/s: collective sing., as ke/ramos in ii.4.7; a)/mpelon, iv.90.9. Kühn. 347, 1. Cf. Diod. xiii. 13, klhmati/dwn kai\ da/dwn, e)/ti de\ pi/tths plhrw/sas.
h)=n e)pi\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous o( a)/nemos ou)/rios : = a)/nemos(pneu=ma)e)pi/foros with dat., as in ii.77.20; iii.74.11.

[th\n nau=n]: Cl. follows Badham (Mnem. 1876) in considering these words as a gloss after o(lka/da palaia/n. There seems to be no reason, however, why Thuc. should not have repeated the obj. after the parenthesis.

sbesth/ria kwlu/mata: the general term kwlu/mata (i.16.1; v.30.11, 24) is explained by the unusual sbesth/ria. Cf. Poll. i. 168, sbesthri/ois kwlu/masin e)xrw=nto, which seems to be an imitation of this passage. The effect of sbesth/ria is expressed in pau/santes th\n flo/ga; of kwlu/mata in (pau/santes)to\ mh\ proselqei=n (cf. iii.1.7) e)ggu\s th\n o(lka/da. The two effects are co-ord. by te (after th/n, Vat.), kai/. The plan (a)ntemhxanh/santo/ te . . . kwlu/mata) and its execution and result (kai\ pau/santes . . . a)phlla/ghsan) are co-ord. in parataxis, and hence there is no need to omit te after e)mhxanh/santo, as St. does. On to\ mh/ with inf. after pau/santes, see GMT. 95, 3; H. 1029; Kühn. 516, note 91.
On both sides trophies are erected.
1. th=s...naumaxi/as tropai=on : see on c. 24. 3.
a)/nw: i.e. on the land. Cf. c. 51. 13.
o(/qen: where, strictly = e)c h(=s(th=s a)/nw a)polh/yews) —tou\s i(/ppous: see on c. 51. 15.

h(=s...troph=s : on the attraction and
assimilation, see G. 154, N.; H. 995 a.
h(=s au)toi/: cf. c. 53. 13 ff.
The superiority of the Syracusans at sea having been thus clearly demonstrated, the Athenians lose all hope of accomplishing in any way at all the object of the expedition.

1. lampra=s: pred., the victory of the Syracusans haring been decisive. Cf. Luc. Ver. Hist. i. 17, th=s de\ troph=s lampra=s gegenhme/nhs. Cl. proposes to write lamprw=s, rendering, “vietory on the sea having also clearly decided for the Syracusans”; but there is no necessity for the change, since the pred. adj. has this force. See App.

h)/dh kai\ tou= nautikou=: kai/, even (also), which Vat. omits, is indispensable, since the reference is to the defeat of Demosthenes in the battle on Epipolae, c. 43.—me/n: without a direct correlative, but answering irregularly to de/ above.
e)pelqou/sas: for the position of the attrib. partic., see on c. 23. 14. G. 142, 2, N. 5.
e)n panti\ a)qumi/as: in the greatest despondency. For const., see on c. 2. 16; 33. 28. Cf. Plat. Rep. 579 b, e)n panti\ kakou=; Hdt. vii.118.3, e)s pa=n kakou= a)pi/kato.
o( para/logos : see on c. 28. 17.
th=s stratei/as o( meta/melos: regret over the expedition, objective gen. Kühn. 414, 4. d( meta/melos is not found elsewhere in Att., but occurs again in the later writers.

6. po/lesi tau/tais kte(.: the placing of the subst. first gives it a character of generality, with nearly the effect of the part. gen.: “of all the cities with which they had gone to war, these were the only ones at that time of kindred organization.” The order is the common one in Thuc., in which a pron. subj. is placed after a pred. subst, and before a sup. adj. (here represented by mo/nais) which belongs to the subst. See on c. 29. 29.—h)/dh: at that time, as in vi.31.46.

mege/qh: though the pl. does not occur elsewhere in Thuc., it is found in Ar. Ran. 1057; Xen. Cyncg. 4. 1; Plat. Prot. 356 c; Criti. 115 d; Legg. 860 b, 861 e. Kühn. 348, note 3. It refers to the size of the cities, as well as to their noteworthy buildings and improvements, esp. those for warlike purposes.
e)k politei/as ti metabolh=s: “by a change of constitution in any respect.” ti is adv. acc., a const. esp. common after negs., as in c. 57. 4, ou) kata\ di/khn ti ma=llon.

to\ dia/foron : as in c. 75. 39, the change, the revolution. Kr. takes ti with to\ dia/foron, and this in the sense of discord, explaining: to\ dia/foron o(\ au)toi=s e)du/nanto e)penegkei=n ou)de\n h)=n. Cf. i.
140. 27, to\ ga\r braxu/ ti tou=to pa=san u(mw=n e)/xei th\n bebai/wsin; iv.27.21, w(rmhme/nous ti to\ ple/on.

w(=| prosh/gonto a)/n : by which they might have brought them into subjection, i.e. ei) e)du/nanto tou=to e)penegkei=n. Cf. ii.30.7; vi.94.14. Kr. Spr. 54, 12, 9.— 10. ou)/t' e)k paraskeuh=s pollw=| krei/ssonos: Cl., Kr., and St. write krei/ssonos instead of the vulgate krei/ssous. See App. The phrase is manifestly opp. to ou)/te e)k politei/as ti metabolh=s, and both are to be connected as means with ou) duna/menoi e)penegkei=n. The sense of the sent. thus far is: “these were the only cities at that time similar in character to their own, against which they had gone to war; for they had a democratic constitution, as they themselves had, and possessed ships and cavalry, and were not inconsiderable in size; therefore they could neither by a change in their constitution in any respect, nor by very much superior military forces, bring about among them the change (either by inward factions, or by a defeat in open field) by which they might have hoped to bring them under their rule.” The three partics. e)pelqo/ntes (6), ou) duna/menoi e)penegkei=n (8), and sfallo/menoi de\ ta\ plei/w (11, of the results of the undertaking) contain the successive causes of the following h)po/roun kte(. See App.— 11. ta\ pro\ au)tw=n: adv., before this, i.e. before the unsuccessful sea-fight. au)ta/ of the matters under discussion, as in i.1.10, and often.
The confidence of the Syracusans, on the other hand, rises now to the point of hoping completely to destroy the Athenian army, and thus win great glory and a conspicuous position among the Greeks.
2. pare/pleon: i.e. they sailed along the shore of the harbour, even past the Athenian ship-station, in a demonstrative and threatening manner.—dienoou=nto: with fut. inf. as in iv.115.7; 121. 3.
4. au)toi/: from Vat., for au)tou=, alone admissible as opp. to e)kei/nous.

kwlu/swsi : the reading of all the Mss. After verba curandi with o(/pws, Thuc.'s usage varies between the fut. indic. and aor. subjv. GMT. 45; H. 885 b. See on i.19.3 and St. Qu. Gr. p. 11. With kwlu/swsi understand mh\ swqh=nai. Cf. vi.88.28; 102. 8.—a)po\ tw=n paro/ntwn: on account of (in consequence of) the present state of affairs, stronger than e)k tw=n paro/ntwn. Cf. ii.77.3.—
7. kaqupe/rtera: as in v.14.8.

e)s tou\s *(/ellhnas: the prep. e)s with reference to the lit. meaning of fanei=sqai, as it were, shine into. Quite similar is dhlou=n e)s tou\s *)aqhnai/ous, i.90.10. Cf. i.72.13; vi.31.32.—kalo/n: glorious, with a)gw/nisma also in c. 59. 2.

tou\s me/n, tou\s de/: part. appos. to tou\s . . . *(/ellhnas, as in c. 45. 8.—e)leuqerou=sqai, a)polu/esqai: these infs. are evidently used in fut. sense. St., following v. H., has inserted a)/n before e)leuqerou=sqai, but unnecessarily; for whether Cl.'s idea that in the older Att. writers some presents of pure and contract verbs are used in the sense of the fut. (see on iii.58.29) be right or not, certainly the pres. with eu)qu/s here expresses much more forcibly the instantancous result. The Schol., as St. observes, seems to have read a)polu/s esqai, since he explains it by r(u/sesqai.

kai\ au)toi/ : opp. to tou/s te a)/llous *(/ellhnas in 10. —do/cantes ai(\tioi au)tw=n ei)=nai: having the reputation of being the causes of these things. For au)tw=n, see on c. 55. 11. The Schol. correctly explains, th=s te e)leuqeri/as tw=n *(ellh/nwn kai\ tou= a)pallagh=nai tou= fo/bon.

16. kai\ h)=n de\...a)gw/n : and the decisive combat was indeed an important one. kai/ is not copulative, and de/ is epexegetical. See on i.132.22.— 17. o(/ti...periegi/gnonto : the impf. of anticipation, because they were conquering.—mo/non,...mo/non : Cl. and St. write mo/nwn, mo/noi, the former explaining: “As mo/noi in 18 is necessary as opp. to meta\ tw=n cumbohqhsa/ntwn, so in 17 also, for the sake of symmetry at least, mo/nwn is necessary. Besides, mo/nwn is, if not indispensable, at least much more expressive, and au)= before mo/noi refers to a preceding mo/nwn. Kr. unnecessarily objects to the words kai\ ou)d' au)toi\ au)= mo/non, because that would diminish the glory of the Syracusans. That the Syracusans in this struggle appeared as leaders, even by the side
of Corinthians and Lacedaemonians, and that the contest took place in their territory, gave them great importance for all Hellas.” But the change seems unnecessary: see App.— 21. e)mparasxo/ntes: cf. vi.12.13. e)n- has adv. force, as if tw=| a)gw=ni were expressed. Cf. ii.20.9, o( xw=ros e)pith/deios e)fai/neto e)nstratopedeu=sai; ii.44.5, e)neudaimonh=sai o( bi/os . . . cunemetrh/qh. The sense of the passage is, “having put forward their own city in the contest to take the post of danger.”—te: as if kai\ proko/yai followed. There is a slight change of const., since proko/yantes is conformed rather to e)mparasxo/ntes.

tou= nautikou=...proko/yantes : having made great progress in naval affairs, lit. having opened the way for the navy in large measure. Cf. iv.60.12, kai\ th=s a)rxh=s a(/ma prokopto/ntwn e)kei/nois. Kühn. 416, note 2. Thuc. sometimes uses me/ros (adv. here) in other places also in an unusual way, e.g. in iii.3.6; v.32.9.
e)/qnh ga\r plei=sta dh\ kte(.: cf. i.1.8. ga/r refers to tw=n a)/llwn pollw=n cumma/xwn and meta\ tw=n cumbohqhsa/ntwn sfi/si above.

e)pi\mi/an po/lin: not against but to the city, since not only the enemy but also the allies are meant. —tou= cu/mpantos o)/xlou: the Mss. read lo/gou, which the Schol. explains by a)riqmou=. Kr. proposed o)/xlou, which Cl. and St. adopt. It is supported by c. 75. 26, muria/des tou= cu/mpantos o)/xlou ou)k e)la/ssous tessa/rwn a(/ma e)poreu/onto. Besides, only with the reading o)/xlou is it admissible with tou= . . . pro\s th\n *)aqhnai/wn te po/lin kai\ *lakedaimoni/wn to supply cunelqo/ntos from cunh=lqe, and thereby to put the prep. pro/s in a prop. light. Instead of this, St. would supply or insert custa/ntos. Heilmann and Madvig propose cullo/gou for lo/gou.
The allies of the Athenians.
1. e)pi\ *sikeli/an te kai\ peri\ *sikeli/as: for e)pi\ *sikeli/an with e)pole/mhsan, see Kr. Spr. 48, 9, 3.

e)lqo/ntes: belongs to both fut. partics.— 3. [e)pi\ *surakou/sas] e)pole/mhsan : the aor. means not they carried on the war, but they entered into the war (sooner or later), took part in it. e)pi\ *surakou/sas, against Syracuse, Cl. considers a marginal explanation of e)pi\ *sikeli/an (1) which has crept into the text. Kr. and St. adopt Bauer's emendation, e)pi\ *surakou/sais e)pole/mhsan = e)s to\n e)pi\ *surakou/sais po/lemon kate/sthsan. Arn. holds to e)pi\ *surakou/sas e)pole/mhsan and renders came to Syracuse to war, e)pole/mhsan being synonymous with e)s po/lemon, or meta\ pole/mou, h)=lqon. This would be preferable if polemei=n e)pi/ tina in this sense could be established.—ou)...ti : not at all. See on
c. 55. 9.
met' a)llh/lwn sta/ntes: “choosing their side.” Cf. c. 61. 12; i.33.22; iii.39.12.

w(s e(/kastoi th=s cuntuxi/as...e)/sxon : this is Heilmann's and Bm.'s conjecture, for e(ka/stois . . . e)/sxen. (Vat. has e(/kastoi, prima manu.) e)/xein is not used impers. in Thuc. The const. is the same as in i.22.14, w(s e(kate/rwn tis eu)noi/as h)\ mnh/mhs e)/xoi. See on c. 2. 2. e)/sxon (aor. as in v.28.12), inceptive: “according as the individual (states) whether for the sake of their own advantage or through compulsion came into a nearer relationship with (cuntuxi/as) the one side or the other.”
6. *)aqhnai=oi...*)/iwnes...*dwrie/as *surakosi/ous : chiastic order.

e(ko/ntes h)=lqon: the hostile relation of the chief contestants was founded also in race difference; here, therefore, there was no need of compulsion from without.—th=| au)th=|: belongs in force also to nomi/mois and governs au)toi=s (7).

*lh/mnioi kte(.: the occupation of Lemnos by Att. cleruchs was effected by Miltiades, Hdt. vi. 140 ff.; that of Imbrus prob. about the same time; of Aegina, 431 B.C. (cf. ii. 27. § 1, to which to/te refers); of Hestiaea, or Histiaea, 446 B.C. (i.114.16). The city Hestiaea was called after its occupation by the Athenians, in the dialect of the people, Oreus, from the place near by with which it was united; but in public documents and on coins it was called even later Hestiaea. See Bursian, H. p. 407.
oi( e)n *eu)boi/a| *(esti/aian oi)kou=ntes: perhaps to distinguish it from the city of the same name in Acarnania, mentioned by Steph. Byz. s.v.
cunestra/teusan: aor. set out with them. a)/poikoi o)/ntes giving the reason. Cf. cunestra/teuon (13), took part in the expedition with them.

12. a)po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi: a)po\ cummaxi/as gives the cause of their taking part in the expedition; au)to/nomoi shows the relation they occupy in it. On a)po/, according to, see Kühn. 430, 1 g. “Thuc. calls all those who have entered into a perpetual alliance with the Athenians to wage war on the barbarians, and who acknowledge their hegemony, u(ph/kooi cu/mmaxoi, and distinguishes from them those who, like the Corcyraeans, made simply a temporary alliance. The latter are here termed a)po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi, elsewhere simply au)to/nomoi (c. 57. 33; vi.69.23), or pa/nu e)leuqe/rws cummaxou=ntes (vi.85.9). Of the former he distinguished two classes,—the one who, enjoying their own laws and free from tribute, furnish ships of their own
accord to the Athenians (cf. vi.85.8, new=n parokwxh=| au)tono/mous, and below, § 4, 5); the second, those who pay money instead of ships (cf. ii.9.15, po/leis ai( u(potelei=s ou)=sai, and below, § 4, 5; the same being called u(poxeiri/ous in iii.11.2). And so besides the a)po\ cummaxi/as au)to/nomoi there is another class of au)to/nomoi, who, though really u(ph/kooi, are considered au)to/nomoi because they are under no constraint in point of laws and customs in the sphere of their separate governments. (Cf. iii. 10. § 6; 11. § 1; 39. § 2.)” St.

13. kai\ tw=n me\n u(phko/wn kte(.: as the enumeration of subject and tributary allies follows geographical subdivisions,—i.e. the allies from Euboea, those from the Cyclades, and those from Ionia,—the Chians also are reckoned among the last, since here the geographical point of view is most important; but immediately afterwards, regard being paid to the condition of the cummaxi/a, the correction is added: tou/twn *xi=oi . . . cune/sponto (we should have expected tou/twn de\ *xi=oi). See App.
*th/nioi: from one of the larger Cyclades; the reading of Vat. only, the others incorrectly *th/ioi.
cune/sponto : aor., as cunestra/teusan in 11.—to\ plei=ston: adv., for the most part.

ou(=toi pa/ntes sums up the u(ph/kooi kai\ fo/rou u(potelei=s (13), including the Chians, who geographically are counted with these. *)/iwnes o)/ntes emphasizes the point of race, which is still more closely defined by the addition kai\ a)p' *)aqhnai/wn (sc. a)/poikoi; cf. vi.76.14, a)po\ sfw=n).

*dru/opes: mentioned among the oldest Hellenic inhabitants of Greece, dwelling near Mt. Oeta. Cf. Hdt. viii.43.9. See Hermann, Griech. St. Alt. § 16, note 6. —u(ph/kooi o)/ntes...*dwrie/as : though their service was not voluntary, still (o(/mws) it was not unnatural, since they went as Ionians (emphasized by ge, of Vat.) against Dorians. In the cases that follow the race-connexion is sensibly violated.
21. pro\s au)toi=s: i.e. besides the Ionian peoples.

*mhqumnai=oi: Methymna in Lesbos had been spared the harsh treatment of the remaining Lesbians, iii.50.7, and the inhabitants are named, vi.85.8, along with the Chians, as new=n parokwxh=| au)to/nomoi. The same relation is here expressed by nausi\ kai\ ou) fo/rw| u(ph/kooi, paying ser
vice with ships, not with tribute, u(ph/kooi being used in an arbitrarily limited sense.
*ai)/nioi: from *ai)=nos, an old Aeol. settlement on the Thracian coast. See Herm. St. Alt. § 76, note 17.

*boiwtoi=s toi=s meta\ *surakosi/wn: the toi=s which hitherto had rested only on Lindau's conjecture has been lately confirmed by the Ms. in the Brit. Mus. (M. in Stahl). The general designation toi=s kti/sasi *boiwtoi=s, “the Boeotians who had colonized the above-named places” had necessarily to be restricted by toi=s meta\ *surakosi/wn, “who stood now on the Syracusan side.” With regard to the subject, see Curtius, Gr. Hist. I. p. 127, “Bocotia was the starting point for the emigration (of the Aeolian races), and was considered also in later times the mother-country of the Aeolian colonies.”—kat' a)na/gkhn: because they were u(ph/kooi and u(potelei=s. Here the breaking up of the natural relation of kata\ to\ cuggene/s (c. 58. 15; i.6.12; iii.82.36) was brought about by outward compulsion.

*plataih=s de\...e)/xqos : the Plataeans on the other hand were influenced in their choice of alliance by their well-grounded hate against the Thebans, therefore ei)ko/tws. Cl.'s rendering of katantikru/, on the other hand, is at least doubtful, Bm. proposes kai\ a)/ntikrus, indeed outright (cf. i.122.15; viii.64.23; 92. 65), which would give exactly the idea of *kerkurai=oi de\ . . . safw=s in 35 below. kata\ to\ e)/xqos, with Vat., referring to wellknown occurrences, the other Mss. kat) e)/xqos.

mo/noi : i.e. no other Boeotians had joined the Athenians. Moreover, the Plataeans here referred to are either such as had found refuge in Athens, e.g. those who succeeded in escaping when Plataea was besieged, iii. 24. § 3, or such as had settled in Scione, v. 32. § 1.

28. *kuqh/rioi: repeated to avoid misunderstanding. Cf. c. 86. 10.— 29. e)pe/feron: this reading of Vat., for e)/feron, seems to be supported by c. 18. 15; v.18.12.—*)argei=oi ge/nos: see O. Müller, Dorier, I. p. 113 ff.— 30. a)poi/kois e(autw=n: cf. vi. 4. § 3.
32. *kefallh=nes me\n kai\ *zaku/nqioi: cf. c. 31. 7. The correlative is de/ in 35.

kata\ to\ nhsiwtiko/n: on
account of their insular position.
kateirgo/menoi: constrained. Cf. iv.98.18.
safw=s: clearly, actually.— 37. tw=n me/n: sc. *korinqi/wn.
tw=n de/ : sc. *surakosi/wn.
e)k tou= eu)prepou=s : for appearance's sake. Schol. i(/na eu)preph\s a)pologismo\s au)toi=s h)=|.
kata\ e)/xqos to\ *korinqi/wn : cf. i. 26.— 39. ou)x h(=sson: not less, i.e. even more.

oi( *messh/nioi nu=n kalou/menoi: “more common is the order oi( nu=n *messh/nioi kalou/menoi, as h( nu=n *(ella\s kaloume/nh, i.2.1; h( nu=n *qessali/a kaloume/nh, i.2.14. Cf. ii.99.19. But oi( has not dropped out after *messh/nioi, as a comparison with ii.29.11, e)n *dauli/a| th=s *fwki/dos nu=n kaloume/nhs, shows. The phrase nu=n kalou/menoi is added because the Helots whom the Athenians had settled at Naupactus (i. 103. § 3) were not in fact all Messenians (i. 101. § 2).” St. See App.
e)k *naupa/ktou...parelh/fqhsan : as stated in c. 31. § 2.—e)k *pu/lou...e)xome/nhs : acc. to iv. 41. § 2 the Athenians had placed the Messenians from Naupactus as a garrison at Pylus (425 B.C.).

fuga/des ou) polloi/: cf. iv. 74. § 2; vi.43.15.—*megareu=si...ou)=si : pred. to *selinounti/ois. The position as in 7 and 23 above.— 43. kata\ cumfora/n: in consequence of their misfortune, i.e. banishment which had brought them to Athens. Schol. cumfora
 a)/rti th
 fugh
 le/gei.

44. h)/dh: from this point (in the enumeration). Cf. ii.96.17. With the last named the motive was a)na/gkh or cumfora/ under the controlling influence of the Athenians; those named after this went of their own accord, for even the misqofo/roi are to be reckoned under this head.

th=s parauti/ka e(/kastoi i)di/as w)feli/as: cf. similar consts. in c. 70. 47; vi.69.19. w)feli/as, although indispensable, is found only in Vat. The meaning seems to be that the 500 Argives mentioned in vi.43.11 had offered themselves of
their own accord, as they individually expected profit from the expedition. That the Argives, as the Arcadians, sometimes served as mercenaries, is shown by Ar. Pax, 477.
*mantinh=s kai\ a)/lloi *)arka/dwn: cf. vi.43.12.
a)ei/: from time to time, i.e. in each particular case, opp. to which is kai\ to/te, so this time.—polemi/ous: pred. Kr. Spr. 50, 12, 1.—sfi/sin a)podeiknume/nous: sc. u(po\ tw=n misqwsa/ntwn.

tou\s meta\ *korinqi/wn e)lqo/ntas *)arka/das : cf. c. 19. 23.—ou)de\n h(=sson: with polemi/ous. “As they were accustomed at other times to turn against any who were pointed out to them as enemies (usually of course strangers), so now they had no hesitation in fighting, for the sake of pay, their own countrymen.”
*krh=tes: cf. vi.43.14.—*ai)twloi/: they serve now as mercenaries with the Athenians, who had invaded their country in 426 B.C. Cf. iii. 94. ff.
cugkti/santas: cf. vi. 4. § 3. For the acc., see on c. 40. 13.

e(ko/ntas: this reading of Vat., for a)/kontas, is of course the only one admissible with meta\ misqou= and in this class of the allies. Cf. 44 above. Valla renders, ultro. On the other hand, a)poi/kous is necessary (Vat. e)poi/kous, cf. ii.27.5), on account of the antithesis (mh\ cu\n—a)ll' e)pi/).
54. *)akarna/nwn tine/s: cf. c. 31. 28.
*dhmosqe/nous,...*)aqhnai/wn : objective gens. For proofs of the friendly disposition here alluded to, cf. iii. 7. § 1; 94. § 2; 105. § 3; 107. § 2; 114. § 1.
*)ioni/w| ko/lpw|: here taken as extending to the west coast of Italy.

e)n toiau/tais a)na/gkais to/te stasiwtikw=n kairw=n kateilhmme/nol: Thuc. states in c. 33. 24 ff., concerning Thurii, that the Att. party had prevailed and driven out their opponents; and they were now in such a situation, resulting from party relations (stasiwtikw=n kairw=n), that they were forced (toiau/tais a)na/gkais) to the alliance with Athens. As Thuc. mentions in c. 33. § 5 factions only among the Thurians, and says that the Metapontians joined the Athenians kata\ to\ cummaxiko/n, St. thinks, with reason, that we should read *metapo/ntioi kai\ *qou/rioi.

kateilhmme/noi : Reiske's emendation for kateilhmme/nwn, which
would be gen. abs., *qouri/wn kai\ *metaponti/wn being understood. The gen. is doubtless an error of the copyist due to the preceding gens.
barba/rwn de\ *)egestai=oi: cf. vi. 2. § 3, 6.
e)phga/gonto: sc. tou\s *)aqhnai/ous.
*sikelw=n : most of the Mss., except Vat., wrongly *sikeliwtw=n. Cf. c. 58. 10; vi. 88. § 4.
*turshnw=n: see on c. 53. 6.
*)ia/puges: cf. c. 33. § 4.
e)/qnh e)stra/teuon: neut. pl. with pl. verb, because e)/qnh denotes persons. Kühn. 365 a.
The allies of the Syracusans.
1. *kamarinai=oi...kai\ *gelw=|oi : cf. c. 33. § 1; vi.67.13.
met' au)tou/s: back of them, i.e. further up the coast, in the same sense as e)n tw=| e)p' e)kei=na in 3. It is the same use of meta/ with acc. as in descriptions of lines of battle (cf. v.67.7, 16).
*)akraganti/nwn h(suxazo/ntwn: remaining neutral. Cf. c. 33. 7.—e)n tw=| e)p' e)kei=na: in the country beyond (the Agrigentines). See on c. 37. 9. Cf. viii.104.25.
5. tetramme/non: for position of the attrib. partic., see on c. 23. 14.

mori/ou: v. H. (p. 100) rejects this word here and in ii.65.52 without sufficient reason, for mo/rion is not dim. of mo/ros, as he asserts, but has a specializing force, as all nouns ending in -ion. Cf. a)rgu/rion, a)/rguros; xrusi/on, xruso/s; bibli/on, bi/blos; xwri/on, xw=ros.
*(/ellhnes : pred., as the only Hellenes. Cf. vi.62.9.—e)c au)tou=: sc. tou= pro\s to\n *turshniko\n po/nton mori/ou.
9. [oi(] au)to/nomoi : all the editt. follow Bk. in omitting the impossible oi(. Reiske proposed to place it after au)to/nomoi.

*sikeloi\ mo/noi : neither Elymi, then (vi.2.15), nor Phoenicians (vi.2.32), joined them.—o(/soi mh\ a)fe/stasan: acc. to c. 57. 61 (*sikelw=n to\ ple/on) the majority had re
volted. Cf. vi. 88. § 3, 4.
neodamw/deis...kai\ *ei(/lwtas : see on c. 19. 16.

[du/natai de\...h)/dh ei)=nai ]: Dindorf and v. H. justly recognized that these words were not from Thuc. The explanation of the Schol. (neodamw/dhs o( e)leu/qeros para\ toi=s *lakedaimoni/ois) proves that he did not have them before him. Besides, in c. 19. 16 and v.34.6 Thuc. took for granted on the part of his readers acquaintance with this Spartan institution.

mo/noi: i.e. kai\ nausi\ kai\ pezw=|. The Leucadians and Ambraciots furnished only ships, which the Corinthians manned in addition to their own. Cf. vi.104.10, oi( *kori/nqioi pro\s tai=s sfete/rais de/ka *leukadi/as du/o kai\ *)amprakiw/tidas trei=s prosplhrw/santes u(/steron e)/mellon pleu/sesqai.— 15. parageno/menoi: belongs only to *kori/nqioi; but kata\ to\ cuggene/s (supply cunema/xoun from 9) belongs to the three subjects *kori/nqioi, *leuka/dioi, and *)amprakiw=tai; for to\ cuggene/s (sc. tw=n *surakosi/wn) is the motive with all three for participation in the war.— 16. e)c *)arkadi/as misqofo/roi...kai\ *sikuw/nioi : cf. c. 19. § 4.
a)nagkastoi/: because since 418 B.C. an oligarchic constitution had been forced on the Sicyonians (v.81.6). Cf. c. 18. 31.
*boiwtoi/: cf. c. 19. § 3.
pro/s: here and in 22 below, in comparison with.
o( a)/llos o(/milos: of light-armed troops of every kind.

cunele/gh: used esp. of the collection of troops. Cf. i.115.18; ii.10.8; iii.94.16; vi.32.13; 66. 14; 98. 6.—au)=qis: only to introduce the second comparison.—w(s ei)pei=n: limiting a(/pantas. It is the regular form in Thuc., never w(s e)/pos ei)pei=n. See on i.1.9.
me/geqos po/lews: art. omitted as with mh=kos plou= in vi.34.28; 86. 10.

25. tosai=de cunele/ghsan:—tosai=de
h)=san ai(\ cunele/ghsan.
to/te : in the latter part of the summer of 413 B.C.
The Syracusans, determined to wage a war of extermination against the Athenians, now shut off the entrance to the great harbour by means of ships anchored broadside before it.

1. oi( d' ou)=n *surako/sioi: since the narrative, interrupted at the end of c. 56, is here resumed, giving in e)no/misan kalo\n a)gw/nisma sfi/sin ei)=nai almost a verbal repetition of c. 56. 9, Kr.'s conjecture, de/ (for te of the Mss.), which is the usual connecting particle in Thuc. in such cases, is doubtless right. See on i.3.19. For ou)=n, see on c. 6. 7. See App.
e)pi\ th=| gegenhme/nh| ni/kh|: not only temporal, after the victory won, but also on the basis of the victory won, i.e. trusting now in victory.

mhde\ kaq' e)/tera: i.e. kata\ mhde/tera. See on c. 41. 15; 43. 4.—au)tou\s...diafugei=n : with changed subj., dependent on kalo\n a)gw/nisma. With regard to the force of the aor. infs. e(lei=n, diafugei=n, see App. to 1, above.
dia\ qala/sshs: more def. than kata\ qa/lassan, referring to the wide sea to be crossed.
e)/klh|on: imp.; they undertook the work, which, acc. to Diod. xiii. 14, they finished in three days.

o)ktw\ stadi/wn ma/lista: for gen. of measure, see on c. 2. 17. Holm (Vortrag in Karlsr. Philol. Wochenschrift, 1882, No. 44, and Zeitschr. f. allg. Gesch. 1884, p. 16, 17) adopts here a small itinerary stadium of about 150 metres. See App. to c. 78. 14.
plagi/ais: belongs to the three substs. The ships were placed broadside before the harbour and anchored (e)p' a)gkurw=n o(rmi/zontes, sc. au)ta/s).
o)li/gon ou)de\n e)s ou)de/n: cf. c. 87. 23; ii.8.1; viii.15.21. See Introd. to Book I. p. 48, note 77.

Encompassed by the greatest danger, the Athenians determine, if possible, to cut their way through with their ships; they abandon all the fortifications except a walled space near the ships for the sick and for the baggage of the army, and put all the available troops on board.

2. o(rw=si: pres., as the work was
still going on.—ai)sqome/nois: aor., since they had received information.
bouleute/a: from bouleu/esqai. With regard to the pl. form of the verbal, common in Thuc., see on i.7.2.
kai\ oi( taci/arxoi: Schol. nu=n dia\ to\ a)/poron kai\ tou\s tacia/rxous (see on iv.4.2) oi( strathgoi\ sunh/gagon, kaq' au(tou\s pro/teron bouleuo/menoi. Cf. c. 48. § 1; 50. § 3.
pro\s th\n parou=san a)pori/an: to be connected with e)bouleu/santo in 8. Cf. c. 47. 2.—tw=n te a)/llwn: as if kai\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn followed.
kai\ o(/ti kte(.: for change of const., see Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 4.

a)pei=pon mh\ e)pa/gein: they had directed them not to bring any more provisions. e)pa/gein, bring (of the Catanaeans); e)pa/gesqai (vi.99.21), fetch (of the Athenians themselves). This had been done when their departure (w(s e)kpleuso/menoi, cf. c. 50. § 3, 4) had been determined on before the eclipse of the moon.

ta\ tei/xh ta\ a)/nw: the part of the lower wall (c. 2. 17 ff.) that was furthest from the coast. Grote understands it of points on Epipolae still in possession of the Athenians; but hardly rightly. If any part of Epipolae was still occupied by the Athenians, it is strange that no mention was made of it at the time of the night attack, c. 42. § 4 ff.—pro\s au)tai=s tai=s nausi/n: “as near as possible to their ships.”

a)polabo/ntes diateixi/smati: so with Vat. for diatei/xisma/ ti of the rest of the Mss.; for it seems clearly meant that they cut off by a crosswall a space between the double wall of the smallest extent that would suffice for the reception of the baggage, the sick, and the garrison necessary for the protection of these. diatei/xisma also in iii.34.9.

a)sqenou=sin: the reading of Vat., the rest a)sqene/si, which, acc. to c. 75. 12, is perhaps admissible. But the older and better writers, acc. to Bl., use always the partic. for the sick, and in c. 75. 12 a)sqene/si means rather the weak than simply the sick.
a)po\ tou= a)/llou pezou=: from the rest of the infantry, i.e. those not required to guard the camp.

a(pa/sas: the reading of Vat. for pa/sas of the other Mss., esp. appropriate before kai\ dunatai\ kai\ a)plow/terai, i.e. the whole number, whether they were in good condition or even somewhat unseaworthy. —o(/sai h)=san: for the impf. indic. in
stead of opt. in dependent clause, see GMT. 77, 1, N. 2; Kühn. 595, 3.— dunatai/: really personal, and used only here of ships (just as ponei=n is used of them in c. 38. 11; vi.104.20). —a)plow/terai: see on c. 34. 20.— 13. pa/nta tina/: as comprehensive as possible. Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 11. Cf. c. 70. 21; 84. 10.
h(=| a)\n...me/llwsin : by whatever way they were likely quickest.
a)ntilh/yesqai: reach, as in c. 77. 29.—w(s e)/docen...kai\ e)poi/hsan : of the immediate execution of the plan agreed on. See on ii.93.17.
20. kai\ o(pwsou=n: found also in i.77.9; viii.91.21. It is to be connected with e)pith/deios.

h(liki/as mete/xwn : “as being not yet too old,” i.e. for such service. h(liki/a is used not in a military, but general sense, which the Schol. indicates by neo/thtos. Cf. ii.44.20, e)n tw=| a)xrei/w| th=s h(liki/as, and vi.24.11. (St. strikes out the words, following Philippi, Jahrbb. 1881, p. 99.)

21. kai/: and so, as in i.67.12; vi.73.1.—ai( pa=sai: in all. See on c. 1. 31.—de/ka ma/lista kai\ e(kato/n: Diod. xiii. 14 gives 115 triremes; Plut., as Thuc., 110, adding: ai( ga\r a)/llai tarsw=n e)ndeei=s h)=san. That the original number, namely, 134 triremes first sent out (vi.43.3) and 73 afterwards (vii.42.3), i.e. 207 altogether, had been greatly reduced, is a matter of course after the conflicts of the whole year, but the loss cannot be accurately estimated.
e)p' au)ta/s: for which Kr. proposed e)s au)ta/s, is appropriate for those lightarmed troops whose duty was constant watching and fighting with light arms on the deck.

e)c a)nagkai/ou: adv., in such desperate circumstances, which made the unusual equipment necessary. The e)k with the neut. of the adj. as in e)c i)/sou, i.120.4; e)k tou= a)kindu/nou, iii.40.23; e)k tou= profanou=s, vi.73.7. te, kai/ forbids connecting a)nagkai/ou with dianoi/as. If so connected, toiau/ths would have to be taken in a materially different sense from a)nagkai/ou. Besides, toiau/ths dianoi/as cannot attain its full effect except by being construed separately. The
sense is then, “in so critical a situation and in consequence of such a (desperate) resolution.”
26. o(rw=n tou\s stratiw/tas: on the reading, see App.
polu\ tai=s nausi\ krathqh=nai: in the battle deseribed in c. 52, 53.

div2.head: SPEECH OF NICIAS TO THE TROOPS BEFORE THE GREAT SEA-FIGHT.
div2.p: “Before all alike, Athenians and allies, is the decisive struggle. You should go into it with courage, because you know how changeable is the fortune of war, and because, considering your numbers, you have a right to hope that it will decide for you.”
1. a)/llwn: see on c. 4. 12.
o(moi/ws: to be connected with a(/pasin. Cf. c. 28. 4; i.93.8; vi.24.8.
[e(ka/stois ou)x h(=sson h)\ toi=s polemi/ois]: Cl. and St. bracket these words as a gloss to o(moi/ws a(/pasin. See App.

e)/sti tw|...e)pidei=n : “it is possible for every one to see again his fatherland.” On tw| in the sense many a one, or every one, see Kr. Spr. 51, 16, 10. With th\n u(pa/rxousa/n pou oi)kei/an po/lin e)pidei=n cf. vi.69.21, th\n u(pa/rxousan sfi/si patri/da nikh/santes pa/lin e)pidei=n.
e)pidei=n : see again, also in c. 77. 37.
6. a)qumei=n de/: opp. to o( me\n a)gw/n: “the battle is to be decisive, but there is no ground for despondency.”

th\n e)lpi/da tou= fo/bou kte(.: the expectation of their fear, i.e. the expectation which in their fear they entertain takes the colour of the misfortunes which they have suffered. Schol. prosdokw=sin o(moi/ws tai=s gegenhme/nais cumforai=s ta\ me/llonta. e)lpi/s in this sense occurs also in vi.87.18. Cf. peni/as e)lpi/s, ii.42.15; Luc. in Tyrannic. 11, ti/s e)lpi\s tou= fo/bou.
11. tw=n e)n toi=s pole/mois paralo/gwn: see on c. 28. 17.

kai\...paraskeua/zesqe : and make yourselves ready with the expectation that fortune may even yet be with us, and with the purpose to retrieve your defeat in a manner worthy of this vast number of your own army that you see before you. On gen. with neut. art. (to\ th=s tu/xhs, fortune), see H. 730 c; Kr. Spr. 47, 5, 10. Cf. c. 62. 8; iv.18.9. meq' h(mw=n sth=nai as in c. 57. 4. u(mw=n au)tw=n belongs really to tou=de tou= plh/qous, but is grammatically dependent as part. gen. on o(/son. Kr. Spr. 47, 9, 5.

“On our side every precaution has been taken to protect our ships against the contrivances devised by the enemy before the last battle; and our crews have been strengthened, so as to render our attacks on their ships more effective.”

1. a)rwga/: used oftener in poetry. Cf. also Plat. Prot. 334 b.—e)nei/domen: see on c. 36. 6.—e)pi\ th=|...steno/thti : in the matter of the narrowness of the harbour. e)pi/ with the dat. as in i.70.10; ii.17.15; iv.22.13.

pro\s to\n me/llonta o)/xlon...e)/sesqai : e)/sesqai depends on me/llonta, and o)/xlos means, not the great number (for this was present from the beginning), but the press of the ships, as in i.49.8, u(po/ te plh/qous kai\ o)/xlou.
pro\s th\n...paraskeuh/n : cf. c. 36. § 3-5.
oi(=s pro/teron e)blapto/meqa: cf. c. 40. § 5. oi(=s is neut. and refers to o)/xlos as well as paraskeuh/. Kr. Spr. 58, 3, 5.
meta\ tw=n kubernhtw=n: belongs with e)skemme/na: “after careful consideration in company with the pilots.”

6. e)pibh/sontai: will serve as epibatae. The epibatae were as a rule hoplites, or men armed as such (see on vi.43.9).—kai\ o)/xlos: Cl. puts a comma before kai/ and renders, and so a crowd (sc. e)pibh/setai, will come together on board). But rather it seems that the whole is added to a part, viz. the archers and javelin-men, o)/xlos signifying here the whole multitude of men by whom the ships were filled.
dia\ to\ bla/ptein: the subj. is to\n o)/xlon.
to\ th=s e)pisth/mhs : see on c. 61. 12.

e)n de\...pro/sforos
e)/stai: understand o(/s from the preceding w(=|. Cf. i.10.20, h(
 ei)ko\s . . . poihth
 o)/nta kosmh=sai, o(/mws de\ fai/netai e)ndeeste/ra. G. 156; H. 1005; Kühn. 561, 1. With this view pro/sforos, the reading of a single Ms. (the rest, pro/sfora), is necessary. Most other editt. read pro/sfora, sc. e)pibh=nai au)to/n(to
 o)/xlon). For a state of affairs similar to that here described (e)n th=| . . . pezomaxi/a|), cf. i. 49. § 2, and ii. 89. § 8.

11. xrh\ a)ntinauphgh=sai: the reading of Vat., for the unintelligible mh\ a)ntinauphgei=sqai of the other Mss. The aor. inf. is preferable for the single case. The fact that Thuc. in i.31.3 and vi.90.12 used the mid., both times after pers. subjs., does not exclude the act. form in an impers. const.—tw=n e)pwti/dwn: see on c. 34. 22; 36. 8.—au)toi=s: in the sense of a loose gen. See on c. 34. 7.
paxu/thtas: attracted into the number of e)pwti/dwn, as e)pibolai/ (13) into that of xeirw=n.

w(=|per : on the neut. of the rel. referring to preceding clause, see Kr. Spr. 58, 3, 6.—xeirw=n sidhrw=n e)pibolai/: the laying on of grapplingirons. e)pibolh/ here and in c. 65. 5 signifies the device to be employed in battle, not the application of it, as is shown by iv.25.14, xeiri\ sidhra=| e)piblhqei/sh| mi/an nau=n a)pw/lesan.
sxh/sousi : = kwlu/sousi. See on i.73.22.—pa/lin: back, here pleonastically added to a)na/krousis for emphasis. Cf. c. 44. 42.
th=s new/s: in the sense of e(ka/sths new/s, as also in c. 65. 7. Kr. Spr. 50, 2, 4.
ta\ e)pi\ tou/tois: what is necessary under these circumstances (or next in order), i.e. to board the hostile ships, and fight hand to hand. Cf. i.65.7; vi.45.3.
15. pezomaxei=n a)po\ tw=n new=n: as in iv.14.20.
kai\ to\ mh/te...w)fe/limon fai/netai : independent const. where we should expect the inf. dependent on w(/ste.
e)a=n : sc. a)nakrou/esqai. Cf. i.70.33.
e)pe/xh|: will have possession of. Cf. i.48.7; 50. 7.

“So I admonish you all to hold out bravely in the combat which is before us, the hoplites in the consciousness of their superiority, the seamen in dependence on our preparations and on the ancient glory of Athens, to sustain which is now our duty. Show your adversaries that you do not bow before misfortunes.”

1. w(=n: the rel. serves as an em
phatic connective. Cf. i.9.19; 42. 1, etc.—diama/xesqai: to fight to the last (utmost).
e)s au)th/n: sc. th\n gh=n polemi/an ou)=san.

a)ciou=n : to be resolved.—a)polu/esqai: cf. c. 44. 40. —pro/teron h)/: with the subjv. without a)/n, as pri/n in vi.10.19; me/xri, i.137.13. GMT. 66, 2, N. 3; 67, 2, N. 3; H. 921 a; Kühn. 398, note 2 c; Kr. Dial. 54, 17, 9.
a)para/chte: cf. Hdt. viii.90.10, tou\s e)piba/tas a)po\ th=s katadusa/shs neo\s ba/llontes a)ph/racan. See on c. 6. 15.
5. tw=n nautw=n: i.e. h)\ toi=s nau/tais. H. 643 b; Kühn. 543, 1 b.
tw=n a)/nwqen: i.e. tw=n e)pi\ tw=n katastrwma/twn, tw=n e)pibatw=n.
ta\ plei/w : cognate acc. with e)pikratei=n, as in iv.19.9.
8. e)n tw=| au)tw=| tw=|de: Schol. e)n tw=| parainei=n.
ti : to be connected with mh/: “not to be in any way too much dismayed.”
a)po/: as in c. 70. 20, instead of e)pi/ (c. 62. 3) because the deck is thought of as the point from which they are to fight. Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 17.
belti/w nu=n: sc. h)\ e)n th=| prote/ra| naumaxi/a|.

e)kei/nhn te th\n h(donh/n : that proud feeling. The proleptic const. as in ii.67.23; vi.88.5. From here to the end of the chap. the exhortation is directed esp. to the metoeci, who served principally in the fleet. They are more particularly designated in 12 by oi(\ te/ws *)aqhnai=oi nomizo/menoi kte(. (Schol. tou\s metoi/kous le/gei).—a)ci/a e)sti\ diasw/sasqai: pers. const. GMT. 93, 1, N. 2 b; H. 944 a. Cf. i.40.13; iii.11.1.
oi(\ te/ws kte(.: in the rel. clause the speaker passes from the feeling to the subjects of it, and the sent. proceeds in the second person because toi=s nau/tais (7) = u(mi=n toi=s nau/tais.
h(mw=n : Cl. and St. adopt this reading of a few Mss., for u(mw=n, because the directreference to the Athenians throughout the whole passage is more natural than the vague u(mw=n.

th=s fwnh=s th=| e)pisth/mh|...*(ella/da : remarkable testimony to the recognized superiority of Att. over all other Hellenic cul
ture, and to its power of propagation.
