kata\ to\ w)felei=sqai kte(.: the sense is, “and you have become sharers in our empire not less than we in point of advantage, both in inspiring fear in our subjects (i.e. securing respect from them), and in freedom from injury.” But it is hardly possible that both ou)k e)/lasson (15) and polu\ plei=on (16) can be correct. Cl. rejects the former, but St., Kr., and Lamb. more prop. consider the latter a gloss to ou)k e)/lasson. See App.
17. e)leuqe/rws: in a free manner, i.e. without limitation of your freedom. Cf. vi.85.9, pa/nu e)leuqe/rws cummaxou=ntes.

dikai/ws [a)/n ]: Cl. brackets both words on the ground that no satisfactory explanation has been found. Most editt. omit a)/n (with a few Mss.). The sense would then be, “act justly, and do not betray it.” “dikai/ws is synonymous with w(s to\ di/kaion bou/letai” (Arn.). Kühn. 497, 5. See App.
h(mi=n: to be taken with a)ntisth=nai as well as with h)/kmaze.
h)ci/wsen : presumed. Cf. i.42.2; 74. 12.
e)pisth/mh: freq. used of technical knowledge and skill, esp. in seamanship. Cf. c. 62. 8; i.49.12; 121. 15.

e(te/ras eu)tuxou/shs r(w/mhs: than confidence on the part of others resulting from lucky events. With e(te/ras, for which Bauer proposed e(te/rwn, cf. sfete/ran in c. 17. 17; par' a)mfote/rois toi=s pra/gmasi, v.26.27. On r(w/mh, see App. to vi.31.3.

“The Athenians especially I remind that in this fleet are collected the last resources of the state, and that after its destruction Syracuse and Sparta will divide between them the supremacy over Hellas. Put forth, therefore, the greatest skill and bravery in this critical struggle.”

1. tou\s de\ *)aqhnai/ous u(mw=n: whoever of you are Athenians; the const. as in iv.126.14; vi.61.15. Cl. changes te of the Mss. to de/ on account of the evident reference to c. 63. 12, but the change seems quite unnecessary.—pa/lin au)=: see on c. 46. 2.—kai\ ta/de: the acc. neut. of the pron. with u(pomimnh/skein as vi.68.14, tou)nanti/on u(pomimnh/skw u(ma=s. Substs. stand in the gen. as in c. 69. 14. Kühn. 411, 6.

h(liki/an: in
personal sense, iuventutem, as in iii.67.11.
ti a)/llo h)\ to\ kratei=n: Schol. eu)fhmo/tata h)|ni/cato th\n h(=ttan.

e)p) e)kei=na, e)kei= : refer to Athens. Cf. vi.77.4, tw=n t' e)kei= *(ellh/nwn. On the other hand, tou\s au)tou= refers to the enemies of Athens in Hellas, and tou\s e)pelqo/ntas to those who will have been added from Sicily.

kai/: and so. See on c. 60. 21.—oi( me/n...oi( de/ : this division covers the whole military strength of Athens, oi( me\n the army before Syracuse, oi( d' e)kei= those at home. Hence a)\n u(po\ *surakosi/ois eu)qu\s gi/gnoisqe points to impending captivity, u(po\ *lakedaimoni/ois to the fall of Athens itself.
oi(=s...e)ph/lqete : and you yourselves know with what intentions you came against them. Cf. vi. 31. § 6, and esp. (the hopes of Alcibiades) vi. 15. § 2.

10. u(pe\r a)mfote/rwn: sc. tw=n t' au)tou= kai\ tw=n e)kei=. a)mfote/rwn not e(kate/rwn, because the two interests are identical. a)mfote/rwn could be, as Kr. explains, neut., both things, your freedom and the independence of Athens, i.e. the idea of the preceding clauses.
kaq' e(ka/stous: severally. For this formula, in the place of the nom., see Kr. Spr. 60, 8, 4.

oi( e)n tai=s nausi\n u(mw=n nu=n e)so/menoi: Nicias speaks immediately before the embarkation of the troops: the sick and invalids and the garrison of the diatei/xisma (c. 60. 9), who will remain behind, are also present; therefore the part. gen. u(mw=n, as in 1, above. See App.

peri\ w(=n: the rel. is neut., referring to the four preceding substs., and is to be connected with a)podeica/menos, with which supply as obj. tou=to from ei)/ ti profe/rei. “And if any one should display whatever superiority he has over others, either in skill or courage, in behalf of these things (peri\ w(=n), he could at no other time contribute more to his own advantage and to the safety of all.”— ei)/ ti/s ti...profe/rei kte(.: cf. i.123.6.
Immediately after this speech, Nicias gives orders to embark. Gylippus and the Syracusans meet the Athenian improvements with counter-improvements.
3. parh=n: it was possible, in the sense well known from the abs. partic. (iv.19.11; v.103.7). The explanatory o(rw=si should not be separated by a comma from ai)sqa/nesqai.
kai\ au)th\n th\n paraskeuh/n : i.e. all arrangements and occurrences which were connected with the embarkation.
prohgge/lqh...xeirw=n : the (device of) laying on the grapplingirons had been reported to them (i.e. by spies). For e)pibolh/, see on c. 62. 12.
6. w(s e(/kasta: = kaq' e(/kasta, singula deinceps. See on i.3.19. —kai\ pro\s tou=to: and especially against this, i.e. ta\s tw=n sidhrw=n xeirw=n e)pibola/s. Kühn. 521, 2.

th=s new\s a)/nw e)pi\ polu/: the whole forms the second obj. = me/ga me/ros th=s new\s a)/nw, “and besides a considerable portion of the ship above (i.e. in its upper parts).” Kühn. 351, 3. See on c. 11. 18.—katebu/rswsan: Poll. (i. 130) well explains, pro\s ta\s e)pibola\s au)tw=n a)ntesofi/zonto bu/rsas proshlou=ntes pro\s ta\ teixi/smata tw=n new=n, o(/pws o( si/dhros o)lisqai/nh| pro\s to\ a)nti/tupon a)ntilabh\n ou)k e)/xwn.
o(/pws a)\n a)polisqa/noi : the opt. after o(/pws a)/n, though common in Hdt., is rare in Att. prose. GMT. 44, 1, N. 3 b; H. 882; Kühn. 553, 5.
e)piballome/nh: “when thrown upon the hostile ships.” Cf. iv.25.14.

oi(/ te strathgoi\ kai\ *gu/lippos...e)/lecan : the Schol. observes pa/ntes u(po\ qa/rsous e)n tou/tois parakeleu/ontai, and mentions then the motives of the leaders of the different Greek states. But Thuc. means (as c. 69. 1 proves) only oi( tw=n *surakosi/wn strathgoi/, i.e. the native generals, as opp. to the Spartan Gylippus. A like case occurs ii.86.26, expressed in exactly the same words, parekeleu/santo kai\ e)/lecan toia/de.
ADDRESS OF GYLIPPUS AND THE OTHER COMMANDERS TO THEIR TROOPS. Chaps. 66-68.

“The glorious victories which you have already won over the mightiest state in Hellas are the sure pledge to you of
further successes, and have deeply depressed the courage and hope of the Athenians.”
1. u(pe\r kalw=n tw=n mello/ntwn: the position of the pred. adj. before the art. produces the same effect as kala\ ta\ me/llonta, u(pe\r w(=n o( a)gw\n e)/stai.
ou)de\ ga\r a)/n : for otherwise you would not. Cf. c. 51. 4.
au)tw=n: sc. tw=n proeirgasme/nwn kai\ tw=n mello/ntwn. See on c. 55. 11.—mh\ e)pi\ o(/son dei=: not sufficiently.
5. *)aqhnai/ous: to be connected with u(posta/ntes nenikh/kate (11) and nikh/sete (12). Kr. Spr. 60, 5, 2.
e)/peita de/: the reading of Vat., for e)/peit) of the other Mss. is more forcible.

a)rxh
 th
 h)/dh megi/sthn: by the position,—subst., art., adj.,—the emphasis is put on the attribute. The arrangement is common in Thuc. See on i.1.6.—kai\ a)rxh
...kekthme/nous : we should expect h)/dh with kekthme/nous. But the sense is, “the most extensive rule already among the ancient and the present Hellenes.” tw=n pri
 *(ellh/nwn is part. gen., though the sup. does not really belong to the sphere of the gen. Kr. Spr. 47, 28, 10; Kühn. 349^{b}, 4.
u(posta/ntes: cf. i.144.22.

kate/sxon: potiti sunt. Cf. ii.62.25; iv.2.13.—ta\s me
 nenikh/kate h)/dh naumaxi/as: cf. ii.85.14, peri\ th=s naumaxi/as h)
 e)ni/khsan. The double acc. (since *)aqhnai/ous belongs also to nenikh/kate) similar to i.32.18, th
 . . . naumaxi/an . . . a)pewsa/meqa *korinqi/ous. G. 159, N. 4; H. 725.—e)k tou= ei)ko/tos: also in c. 68. 14, a strengthened ei)ko/tws, in all probability. Cf. e)c a)nagkai/ou, c. 60. 24; e)k tou= fanerou=, iv.79.10; e)k tou= a)sfalou=s, i.39.2; e)k tou= a)fanou=s, i.51.4.
12. a)/ndres: in the sense of the impers. pron.—w(=| a)ciou=si prou/xein: “wherein they claim to be the first.”
kolouqw=si: is, it seems, more Att. than kolousqw=si. Schol. e)lattwqw=si.

to/ g) u(po/loipon au)tw=n th=s do/chs : “the rest of their good opinion of themselves.” By its close connexion with the preceding w(=| a)ciou=si prou/xein, do/ca au)tw=n gets the
meaning which the Schol. expresses by fro/nhma, self-confidence.

a)sqene/steron au)to\ e(autou= e)stin h)\ ei)—: “has sunk lower (is weaker) than if,” etc. The comp. with au)to\ e(autou= measuring the difference between different conditions of the subj. itself. H. 644; Kühn. 543, 6. Both the refl. gen. and h)/ here as in Hdt. ii.25.23, au)to\s e(wutou= r(e/ei pollw=| u(podee/steros h)\ tou= qe/reos; viii.86.8.— w)|h/qhsan: sc. prou/xein.
to\ prw=ton : from the beginning, and so strengthening the negation, as th\n a)rxh/n in iv.98.4; vi.56.5.

kai\ tw=| par) e)lpi/da...e)ndido/asin : Cl. thinks that the evident parallelism of the sent. requires that tou= au)xh/matos should depend on par' e)lpi/da, as th=s duna/mews depends on para\ i)sxu/n; the former in the sense “at variance with” (i.e. contrary to the expectation of) “their proud self-confidence”; the latter, “contrary to the strength of their real power,” i.e. more than was necessary in proportion to the real measure of their strength. But it seems better, with Kr., St., and others, to take tw=| par' e)lpi/da = insperato, and const. tou= au)xh/matos with sfallo/menoi, “deceived in their self-confidence.” Cf. iv.62.12, tw=| par' e)lpi/da mh\ xalepw=s sfalle/sqw. With para\ i)sxu\n th=s duna/mews, cf. Soph. Phil. 594, i)sxu/os kra/tos; Paul. ad Eph. 1. 19, to\ kra/tos th=s i)sxu/os.
e)ndido/asin : give up, lose courage. Cf. viii.1.23.

“We, on the contrary, have more than ever cause to hope for the best; for the measures which they have taken against us will themselves be ruinous to them. Besides, not confidence but despair drives them to battle.”

1. to\ u(pa/rxon pro/teron kte(.: to\ u(pa/rxon is not to be understood, with Kr., of material power, as diplasi/a e(ka/stou h( e)lpi/s proves, but only of moral strength; here, “courage,” “self-confidence.” “The feeling which before animated us, in which we, when we were still inexperienced, dared to risk all, rests now on a firm basis; and since the conviction of superiority has been added, the hope of every one is doubled.”—a)nepisth/mones: as e)pisth/mh (c. 62. 8; 64. 15), referring esp. to skill in seamanship.
a)petolmh/samen: found only here. Cf. a)popeira=sai, c. 36. 2; a)pokinduneu/ein, c. 81. 26.
au)tw=|: sc. tw=| pro/teron u(pa/rxonti.
to\ krati/stous ei)=nai : Cl. explains to/ with the inf. as introducing the explanation of th=s dokh/sews. Most editt. omit to/. See App.

ei)...e)nikh/samen : the real case in cond. form, as in i.33.8; 76. 8; 86. 4; iv.85.4; vi.10.20. The repetition of krati/stous (hence
the omission of the comma before ei)) gives to the explanatory clause something of an axiomatic character.
ta\ polla/: for the most part, generally. Cf. i.13.3; iv.80.10.
6. ta\ th=s a)ntimimh/sews...h(mw=n : “everything in our arrangements which they on their side (a)nti-) seek to imitate.”
ou)k a)na/rmostoi: “not unprepared.” This adj. in pers. const. is not found elsewhere.— 10. para\ to\ kaqesthko/s: contrary to the usual manner. Cf. i.98.9.

xersai=oi: “living on terra firma,” used esp. of animals, and hence softened by w(s ei)pei=n. It is to be connected with e)pi\ nau=s a)naba/ntes, and *)akarna=ne/s te kai\ a)/lloi is added as furnishing significant examples.
o(/pws...xrh/ : cf. c. 44. 15; iii.11.18; and see on i.91.4.
kaqezome/nous: sitting; for they will not be able to stand on board the ships.
pw=s ou)...ta\s nau=s : how will they not imperil their ships?—e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s...tara/contai : see on c. 23. 16.
e)n tw=|...tro/pw| : cf. i.130.5, e)n tw=| kaqesthko/ti tro/pw|.
16. tw=| plh/qei: “by the greater number.”
e)n o)li/gw|: in a narrow space. Cf. c. 70. 22; ii.84.14; 86. 20; iv.55.17; 96. 13.
a)rgo/terai e)s to\ dra=n: “slower in accomplishing.” Cf. vi.12.10, new/teros e)s to\ a)/rxein.

e)s to\ bla/ptesqai : unusual for the simple inf. after r(a=|stai. It is caused by the parallelism with the preceding e)s to\ dra=n. For the usual const., see on c. 14. 5.—a)f' w(=n h(mi=n pareskeu/astai: by the arrangements which have been made by us; unusual assimilation of the nom. of the rel. clause (a)po\ tou/twn a(/). G. 153, N. 2; H. 996 a. Kühn. 555, note 4. For a)po/, cf. c. 29. 6.
21. u(perballo/ntwn: abundare, superare. Cf. vi.23.3. For the coordination of the gen. abs. with the circumstantial nom., both causal, see Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2; Kühn. 492, 3.

a)pokinduneu=sai: this is Duker's conjecture for a)pokinduneu/sei (dat.) of the Mss. and most editt. In this way the idea e)s a)po/noian kaqesth/kasi is carried out naturally, and ou(/tws o(/pws du/nantai is brought into the necessary connexion with a verb. The Schol. says: ou) th=| paraskeuh=| dhlono/ti pisteu/ontes, a)lla\ diakinduneu=sai speu/dontes e)pi\ th=| tu/xh| to\ me/llon poiou=ntai, which supports the conjecture. “They are come into the desperate strait of risking a battle in such manner as they can, trusting more to fortune than to their own strength.” For government of a)pokinduneu=sai, see Kr. Spr. 55, 3, 16.— 26. w(s...ou)k a)\n pra/cantes xei=ron : the aor. (as in vi.20.8, prosdecame/nas) in the uncertainty of the Mss. is to be preferred to the fut. part. pra/contes. tw=n paro/ntwn xei=ron short for xei=ron h)\ e)n tw=| paro/nti pra/ssousi. Kr. Spr. 47, 27, 2. Cf. vi.89.19, th=s u(parxou/shs a)kolasi/as . . . metriw/teroi. For the causal partic. with a)/n representing aor. opt., see GMT. 41, 3; H. 987 a.

“We, however, are without doubt justified, while warding off a most unjust attack, in taking full revenge on our bitterest foes; and by this means we shall at the same time secure freedom for all Sicily.”
1. pro\s ou)=n a)taci/an...prosmi/cwmen : the acc. with pro/s for the simple dat. is unusual, but after the analogy of ma/xesqai pro/s tina.

tu/xhn a)ndrw=n e(auth
 paradedwkui=an : the idea of a fate overruling the individual human being, as well as whole states, is not found elsewhere in Thuc., but often in Dem.; e.g. 11. 22, th
 th=s h(mete/ras po/lews tu/xhn a)
 e(loi/mhn h)\ th
 e)kei/nou.
o)rgh=| : with fury, as in v.70.2.

nomimw/taton...oi(\ a)/n : against enemies it is quite lawful (i.e. they act quite lawfully) who, etc. On the free connexion of the pl. of the pers. rel. pron. with the neut. adj., see Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 11; Kühn. 563, 3 d. Cf. ii.44.4; vi.14.7.
w(s e)pi\ timwri/a| tou= prospeso/ntos: on the ground of punishing the aggressor. Cf. i.126.14.

a)poplh=sai th=s gnw/mhs to\ qumou/menon: to satiate their heart's animosity. So in iii. 82.
64, e)kpimpla/nai. to\ qumou/menon (also Eur. Hec. 299) as to\ dedio/s, i.36.3; to\ o)rgizo/menon, ii.59.12; to\ e)piqumou=n, vi.24.4.

e)kgenhso/menon: (Vat.) will fall to our lot, become ours; more appropriate than e)ggenhso/menon (cf. Ar. Eq. 851), will be possible. Cf. Hdt. i.78.7; vii.4.5. The partic. e)kgenhso/menon depends on nomi/swmen (with force of ei)dw=men). Kühn. 484, 8; Kr. Dial. 56, 4, 4.—to\ lego/meno/n pou h(/diston ei)=nai: evidently appos. to e)xqrou\s a)mu/nasqai, “that which is proverbially the sweetest thing”; and hence kai/, which is omitted by one Ms. and Valla, is incorrect. Kr. Spr. 57, 10, 12.
7. e)xqroi\ kai\ e)/xqistoi: enemies, and indeed the worst of all enemies. See on c. 48. 24.
e)n w(=|: whereby, referring in a general sense to the idea of the preceding clause, as in iv.18.7. Schol. e)n tw=| doulw/sasqai h(ma=s.
ta)/lgista prose/qesan : as in iii.42.25, timh/n; iv.20.12, xa/rin.
th\n ai)sxi/sthn e)pi/klhsin : Schol. th\n doulei/an (in the sense of political dependence).
12. a)kindu/nws: i.e. for the Syracusans and all Sicily.

h(mw=n: adopted by Cl. from Vat., on the ground that it is almost indispensable after the foregoing, which treated of the Athenians. But, as St. says, h(mw=n is easily understood from boulo/meqa. Kr. is certainly wrong in proposing au)tw=n. For the const. pra/ttein ti, see Kr. Spr. 46, 5, 11.—e)k tou= ei)ko/tos: as is probable.
kolasqh=nai, paradou=nai: the sent. is constructed as if kalo\s a)gw/n were to follow. With the latter inf. supply h(ma=s. The subj. is changed as in vi.68.12.
e)leuqeri/an: belongs to karpoume/nh| as well as to paradou=nai. Kühn. 597, 2 f.
e)k tou= sfalh=nai: in consequence of failure. For gen. of inf. with prep. thus used adv., see Kühn. 478, 4 c.—plei=sta: cognate acc. See on c. 24. 12.

After this speech, the Syracusan leaders also embark their troops. Nicias, howerer, overwhelmed by the thought of the impending crisis, turns once more with prayers and exhortations to the indiridual trierarchs. After this he arranges the troops with whom he remains on land in as long a line as possible along the shore; and Demosthenes, Menander, and Euthydemus, who hare charge of the fleet, sail immediately with their ships against the closed entrance of the harbour.
3. kai\ tou\s *)aqhnai/ous: sc. plhrou=ntas ta\s au(tw=n nau=s. Kr. Spr. 56, 16, 1. Cf. i.78.10; ii.86.14.
u(po\ tw=n paro/ntwn: found only here. It is equiv. to the usual e)k tw=n paro/ntwn, e)pi\ toi=s parou=si, pro\s ta\ paro/nta, a)po\ tw=n paro/ntwn. See on c. 56. 6.
5. w(s e)ggu\s h)/dh: the reading of Vat.; the h)=n after h)/dh which the other Mss. have weakens the force of the expression.
o(/per pa/sxousin: sc. oi( a)/nqrwpoi nomi/zontes.

pa/nta...ei)rh=sqai : the number of sfi/sin and au)toi=s shows that both refer to the subj. of pa/sxousin. After sfi/sin has made clear the reference to the subj. of pa/sxousin, there is no need of the refl. in the second case. The contrasted e)/rgw| and lo/gw| make it clear that both dats, refer to the same subj. But Pp. and Bm. explain au)toi=s = toi=s stratiw/tais tou= *niki/ou; St., following L. Dindorf, strikes out au)toi=s, which however seems necessary with lo/gw| ei)rh=sqai. ou)/pw i(kana/ is opp. to pa/nta, hence the position of te.
e(/na e(/kaston : cf. c. 75. 15; vi.41.6.
a)neka/lei: called by name, as in c. 70. 49. See on i.3.16.—patro/qen te e)ponoma/zwn: the Schol. refers to Hom. K. 68, patro/qen e)k geneh=s o)noma/zwn a)/ndra e(/kaston, pa/ntas kudai/nwn.

au)tou/s : i.e. toi=s oi)kei/ois au)tw=n o)no/masin, as opp. to fulh/n, both for the sake of greater honour. St. claims, however, that e)ponoma/zwn is nowhere equiv. simply to o)noma/zwn, but here and in Plat. Lys. 204 a (e)/ti patro/qen e)ponoma/zetai) means e)pi\ tw=| o)no/mati o)noma/zein, i.e. praeter ipsorum nomen nominare. He omits, therefore, kai\ au)tou\s o)nomasti/, as a marginal explanation indicating this force of the verb.

a)ciw=n:
admonishing, with the infs. mh\ prodido/nai and mh\ a)fani/zein, of which the former has as subj. tina (preceded by its limiting rel. clause), the latter tou/tous(w(=n = tou/tous w(=n).—to\ kaq' e(auto/n: gets through w(=| u(ph=rxe lampro/thto/s ti the signification of individual merit and worth. Schol. th\n oi)kei/an a)reth/n.
lampro/thto/s ti : see on c. 48. 9.
th=s e)n au)th=| a)nepita/ktou...e)cousi/as : i.e. o(/ti e(ka/stw| e)n au)th=| a)nepita/ktws diaita=sqai e)/cesti. See the beautiful expression of this thought in the Funeral Oration, ii. 37. § 2.
a)/lla te le/gwn: te introducing the third partic.
e)n tw=| toiou/tw| tou= kairou=: in such a crisis. See on c. 2. 16.

ou) pro\s to\ dokei=n tini a)rxaiologei=n fulaca/menoi: not minding lest they might seem to any to say something old. fula/ssesqai pro/s ti is rare. It occurs in Plut. Mor. 976 d. pro/s, as to, with regard to, as in ii.22.1; vi.40.13, and often.

kai\ u(pe\r a(pa/ntwn...profero/mena : = a(\ kai\ u(pe\r a(pa/ntwn paraplh/sia profe/retai. The whole clause is in appos. to o(/sa . . . ei)/poien a)/n. kai/, even, is to be taken with a(pa/ntwn, and paraplh/sia is pred. to profero/mena. “Commonplace appeals such as are brought forward even for everything (on all occasions).”
a)ll)...e)pibow=ntai : the force of o(/sa continues. The clause is opp. to ou) pro\s to\ dokei=n . . . fulaca/menoi ei)/poien a)/n.
21. ou)x i(kana\ ma=llon h)\ a)nagkai=a: Schol. a)nagkai=a ma=llon h)/per i(kana/. Cf. ii.70.5, brw=sis a)nagkai/a; vi.37.17, a)nagkai/a paraskeuh/.
to\n pezo/n : i.e. the part of the land force that remained on shore to guard the diatei/xisma (c. 60. 11).
o(/pws...gi/gnoito : i.e. in order that the sight of the greater crowd might increase their courage.
25. *me/nandros kai\ *eu)qu/dhmos: cf. c. 16. 5.

strathgoi\ e)pe/bhsan:
had embarked as strategi (pred.).
to\ zeu=gma: the barrier of the harbour, described in c. 59. § 2. So the Greeks named a bridge of boats of any kind.

die/kploun: signifies usually the manœuvre of breaking through a line of hostile ships (c. 36. 22; 70. 26), but here the space left for sailing through (cf. Plut. Nic. 24, a)pe/kleisan to\n die/kploun). For it seems necessary to assume, even though it is not mentioned, that the Syracusans in closing their harbour must have left an opening for their own use. The Schol., who seems to have read paraleifqe/nta, explains, tou/testi parele/leipto w(/ste mh\ e)zeu=xqai. In c. 70. 3 e)/kplous refers to the same point in the zeu=gma. Hence kataleifqe/nta of Vat. is to be preferred to katalhfqe/nta, paralhfqe/nta, or paraleifqe/nta. Cf. Hdt. vii.36.12, die/kploon u(po/fausin kate/lipon tw=n penthkonte/rwn kai\ trihre/wn, “they left an opening to sail through” (referring to the bridge over the Hellespont).—bia/sasqai: abs. break through, as in i.63.5; different from c. 70. 43.

The Syracusan fleet has possession not only of the outlet but of all parts of the harbour, and the battle soon becomes general. On both sides the greatest effort and skill are put forth by the leaders as well as by the crews.

1. proecanagago/menoi: this form, which Dion. Hal. gives in quoting the passage, is here necessary. The aor. is required before e)fu/lasson, and the simple e)ca/gesqai does not occur in the sense of the sailing out of ships, while several different compounds of a)na/gesqai have this force: e)cana/gesqai, ii.25.25; u(pecana/gesqai, iii.74.14; a)ntepana/gesqai, iv.25.4. The comparison with the isolated e)cagwgh/, Hdt. iv.179.9, which is used not of the sailing out, but of rescue from danger, is not sufficient. St., however, reads proecagago/menoi = provecti, priores vela dantes, and compares besides e)cagwgh/ in Hdt. iv.179.9, also e)peca/gonta, c. 52. 8. On the freq. errors in the transcription of this and like forms, see the App. on i.29.18.

kai\ pro/teron: cf. c. 52. 3. There were at that time 76.— 5. pareboh/qei: Arn.'s reading, following Dion. Hal., for parabohqei=, parabohqh=| or parabohqoi= of the Mss. “It is absurd to say that they stationed their ships all round the harbour in order that their land forces might aid them, when nothing had been said about the land forces.” With kai\ a(/ma
therefore a second precaution is introduced independently. There is an exact parallel to this passage in ii.90.14: (o( *formi/wn)e)/plei para\ th\n gh=n: kai\ o( pezo\s a(/ma tw=n *messhni/wn pareboh/qei. The land troops stood on the shore ready to attack the ships of the Athenians wherever they might be driven to land.
toi=s *surakosi/ois: the dat. with a)/rxein as in i.93.11; ii.2.6; vi.54.27. G. 184, 3; H. 767; Kr. Spr. 47, 20, 2.—*sikano/s: cf. c. 50. 1. —*)aga/qarxos: c. 25. 2.

oi( *)aqhnai=oi: most Mss. and Dion. de Thuc. Iud. p. 875 read oi( a)/lloi *)aqhnai=oi. St. prefixes, with a few Mss., also kai/. But there is ground here neither for a)/lloi (as in c. 61. 1) nor for kai/ (cf. c. 69. § 4), both of which Vat. omits.
10. tw=n tetagme/nwn new=n pro\s au)tw=|: as to the position of pro\s au)tw=|, cf. v.112.6, th=| me/xri tou=de sw|zou/sh| tu/xh| e)k tou= qei/ou au)th/n. Kr. Spr. 50, 10, 2.

lu/ein ta\s klh/|seis: i.e. to break the zeugma, for the passage that had been left open (c. 69. 29) would have to be enlarged to allow the whole fleet to escape. See on c. 69. 29, and cf. c. 59. § 2.
sfi/si: for au)toi=s, written under the influence of the preceding sent.

h)=n: so Vat. correctly; the rest omit. e)gi/gneto cannot prop. be used of the naumaxi/a pro\s tw=| zeu/gmati, the beginning of which had been already mentioned in 10.—kata\ to\n lime/na e)gi/gneto: i.e. the sea-fight which had already begun now broke out over the whole harbour.
oi(/a ou)x e(te/ra: cf. i.23.5; viii.1.12.
16. pollh/, pollh/: cf. pollou/s, pollou/s in i.49.2, 3.—a)po\ tw=n nautw=n: on the part of the sailors, stronger than the simple gen. See on i.37.5.

keleusqei/h: i.e. by the keleustai/ (40) appointed to this duty.—h( a)ntite/xnhsis: the art. is used since this is a recognized feature in any sea-fight. This word and a)gwnismo/s found only here in Att.

oi(/ te e)piba/tai: te introduces the third member after
nautw=n and kubernhtw=n.
e)qera/peuon : curabant.
ta\ a)po\ tou= katastrw/matos: the service on deck. It is subj. of lei/pesqai. For a)po/, see on c. 63. 9.—th=s a)/llhs te/xnhs: i.e. th=s tw=n nautw=n kai\ kubernhtw=n.

pa=s te/ tis : the resumptive te, as with to\ cu/mpan, c. 49. 18; a(plw=s, iii.82.34; pa/nti tro/pw|, iv.48.15. For pa=s tis, see on c. 60. 13.—e)n w(=|: i.e. e)n tou/tw| w(=|; e)n belonging only with the implied tou/tw| and to be connected with prw=tos fai/nesqai. For prosta/ssesqai with the simple dat., cf. ii.87.31; vi.31.31; 42. 8.
24. braxu\ a)pe/lipon: = o)li/gou e)de/hsan. With simple inf. Kühn. 516, note 9 a. Cf. Hdt. vii.9.18, o)li/gon a)polipo/nti . . . a)fike/sqai.
diako/siai : acc. to c. 60. 21 and 2 above, the number would be 186.

ai( e)mbolai/: most Mss. have e)kbolai/, which does not suit the context. The e)mbolai/ are intentional attacks, prosbolai/ accidental collisions (as shown by w(s tu/xoi . . . e)piple/ousa) of the ships.— dia\ to\ mh\ ei)=nai...die/kplous : i.e. on account of the impossibility of the regular manœuvres, a)nakrou/seis (see on c. 36. 28) and die/kploi. The die/kplous was the favourite Att. manœuvre of breaking through the hostile line, and then attacking the separated portions in flank or rear. See on i.49.11. The art. is not repeated with die/kplous, as in c. 71. 3.
h(\ dia\ to\ feu/gein h)\ a)/llh| (nhi\) e)piple/ousa: co-ordination of different consts. Cf. vi.17.12, h)\ e)k tou= le/gwn pei/qein h)\ stasia/zwn. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.

31. oi( e)piba/tai: wrongly suspected by Pluygers (Mnem. 11, p. 96). After the slingers and archers had sought to ward off the approaching ship, the regular e)piba/tai, the hoplites on board, took up the battle close at hand. Cf. c. 62. 14.
e)pibai/nein: with the dat. only here in Thuc., elsewhere with gen. or e)pi/ ti.

cunetu/gxane/ te pollaxou=: and so it happened in many places. cuntugxa/nein of the coincidence of several circum
stances, as cumbai/nein in c. 75. 7.

ta\ me/n,...ta\ de/ : “on the one side, on the other side.”—e)mbeblhke/nai: some general subj., like tina or e)ni/ous is to be supplied, to which in the second clause, before e)mbeblh=sqai, the pred. au)tou/s, themselves, is added.— 34. e)mbeblh=sqai: from the act. e)mba/llein tini/, as in c. 34. 20.

kat' a)na/gkhn: of necessity, because they could not help it. Cf. c. 57. 24.— cunhrth=sqai: Schol. sumpeple/xqai.— 36. toi=s kubernh/tais...fulakh
...e)piboulh
...periesta/nai: = tou\s kubernh/tas a)nagka/zesqai a(/ma fula/cai ta\s e)piferome/nas nau=s, a(/ma e)pibouleu=sai a)/llais kte(. The sense is, “so that upon the pilots devolved the necessity of guarding against the one party and of attacking the other, not one by one, but on all sides at the same time.” With fulakh
(e)piboulh
)periesta/nai, cf. iii.54.17, perie/sth fo/bos; vi.61.18, periesth/kei u(poyi/a.
me/gan...cumpiptousw=n : placed after ktu/pon (sc. o)/nta) in pred. sense.
a)poste/rhsin pare/xein: = a)posterei=n.
40. pollh/: “much and loud.”

a)f' e(kate/rwn: cf. 16, above.—toi=s keleustai=s: i.e. para\ tw=n keleustw=n.— 42. kata/ te th\n te/xnhn kai\ pro\s th\n au)ti/ka filoniki/an: “as their calling demanded, and from the rivalry of the moment.”
toi=s me\n *)aqhnai/ois: obj. of e)pibow=ntes, which is understood also with toi=s de\ *surakosi/ois (45).

e)pibow=ntes: after toi=s keleustai=s, as if oi( keleustai\ parekeleu/onto preceded. See on c. 42. 9.— peri\ th=s...swthri/as : Cl. takes with a)ntilabe/sqai as an emphatic circumlocution for the gen., comparing c. 66. 1; but St. rightly takes a)ntilabe/sqai abs., as in ii.8.3; viii.106.23. th=s e)s th\n patri/da swthri/as is after the analogy of the common const., e)s th\n patri/da sw/|zesqai.

nu=n, ei)/ pote kai\ au)=qis, proqu/mws a)ntilabe/sqai : Cl. explains: “since the admonitory ei)/
pote, if ever, refers to the past (cf. c. 64. 10; iv.55.12), kai\ au)=qis can be connected only with nu=n. The admonition to the Athenians is: ‘if ever before, now once again they must do everything to obtain a safe return home.’ Cf. Dem. 1. 6, tw=| pole/mw| prose/xein, ei)/per pote/, kai\ nu=n. Quite different is the connexion in ii.48.14, where pote refers to the fut., ‘if the sickness should ever break out again.’” The other editt. all punctuate nu=n, ei)/ pote kai\ au)=qis, proqu/mws, i.e. now, if ever again (in the fut.), which is doubtless better.
e(ka/stous: refers to the allies from the different Sicilian states. For position, see on c. 57. 46.

49. mh\ di) a)na/gkhn: unnecessarily. See App.—pru/mnan krouo/menon: here “retiring from the battle.”—a)nakalou=ntes o)nomasti/: see on c. 69. 10.— 51. oi)keiote/ran: more friendly, more their own.—th=s ou) di) o)li/gou po/nou kekthme/nhs qala/sshs: spoken in the full confidence of Athenian superiority at sea. po/nou, which is added from Vat., strengthens this effect materially. kekthme/nhs is pass., as in ii.62.22. Kr. Spr. 40, s.v.; Kühn. 377, 4 a.

u(poxwrou=sin: the correct reading from Vat. for a)poxwrou=sin of the other Mss. It is the prop. word for retreat before a superior force, and corresponds exactly to the pru/mnan krouo/menon above. Cf. pru/mnan krouo/menon u(poxwrei=n also in i.54.16; iii.78.12.
[*)aqhnai/ous]: Cl. (Attica, p. 194, 1862) considers this a gloss, contending that it weakens the effect of a contrast which is itself quite clear. Pluygers (Mnem. 11, p. 96) and St. agree.
feu/gontas feu/gousin: repeated to heighten the contrast.

The infantry on both sides follow the changing erents of the battle with most painful interest, their bodily movements keeping time with the excitement of their minds. The Athenians, especially, for a long time greet the occurrences before their eyes with loud exclamations of hope or of anxiety; but when victory at last decides for the Syracusans, and the Athenians, fleeing in wild confusion, seek refuge on shore, the land troops are seized with despair like that of the Lacedaemonians when their people, after the destruction of their ships, were hopelessly cut off at Pylus (iv. 14).

1. o(/ te e)k th=s gh=s pezo\s a)mfote/rwn kte(.: cf. c. 70. 29, oi( a)po\ tw=n katastrwma/twn. te introduces significantly a new feature of the whole consideration. At the bottom of the entire description as far as 24 lies the idea,
that so long as the real struggle is undecided, so long continues in the minds of the spectators a reflexion of this struggle. To i)sorro/pou th=s naumaxi/as kaqesthkui/as answers polu
 to
 a)gw=na kai\ cu/stasin th=s gnw/mhs ei)=xe. cu/stasis, used in Hdt. vi.117.6 and vii.167.5, of the greatest heat of battle, expresses here excitement of mind (stronger than even a)gw/n). It occurs also in same sense in Eur. Hipp. 983, me/nos me
 cu/stasi/s te sw=n frenw=n deinh/. And Dio C., who in his account of the battle of Mylae (xlix. 9) had this passage in mind, says, a)ntipa/lou e)pi\ polu\ th=s ma/xhs genome/nhs i)sorro/pw| kai\ au)toi\ susta/sei th=s gnw/mhs sune/sxonto.
polu/n : pred. Kühn. 465, 11 c.

o( au)to/qen: Schol. o( *surako/sios strato/s. This and oi( e)pelqo/ntes (sc. oi( *)aqhnai=oi kai\ oi( cu/mmaxoi) are the parts in appos. to o(/ te e)k th=s gh=s pezo/s. Cf. iv.6.3. Kr. Spr. 56, 9, 1.—peri\ tou= plei/onos h)/dh kalou=: “to make greater the glory that was already great.”— 5. mh\ tw=n paro/ntwn e)/ti xei/rw pra/cwsi: cf. c. 67. 26.

6. a)nakeime/nwn: takes, as pf. pass. to a)nati/qhmi (viii.82.3), e)s instead of e)n. Cf. Hdt. i.97.3, o( *dhi+o/khs e)s e(wuto\n pa=n a)nakei/menon. The Schol. renders the sense correctly, pa/shs th=s e)lpi/dos au)toi=s e)n tai=s nausi\ ou)/shs.

ou)deni\ e)oikw/s : sc. oi(=os ou)dei\s a)/llos = me/gistos. — dia\ to\ <a)nw/malon th=s ta/cews> a)nw/malon kai\ th\n e)/poyin th=s naumaxi/as e)k th=s gh=s h)nagka/zonto e)/xein : so Cl. reads, not claiming certainty for his addition, but seeking only to give, instead of the incomprehensible original, the sense which is gathered from the context: “and because their position on the shore was unlike (in consequence of the widely extended line, c. 69. 23), so necessarily was their view of the conflict (from different points) unlike.” This explanation is hardly satisfactory. See App.
9. di) o)li/gou: at a little distance, as in ii.89.41; iii.43.14.

a)neqa/rshsan a)/n: use of a)/n with aor. indic. to express a repeated occurrence, corresponding to ei)/ tines i)/doien in the prot. GMT. 30, 2; H. 835, a; Kühn. 392^{a}, 5. Cf. Plat. Apol. 22 b, a)nalamba/nwn au)tw=n ta\ poih/mata . . . dihrw/twn a)\n au)tou/s.

pro\s a)na/klhsin : to calling
by name. Cf. a)nakalei=n, c. 69. 10; 70. 49.
oi( d' e)pi\ to\ h(ssw/menon ble/yantes: = ei) d' a)/lloi . . . ble/yeian. to\ h(ssw/memon, the neut. partic. used subst., has a collective force. Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 17.
o)lofurmw=| meta\ boh=s: “loud lamentation.” a(/ma connects o)lofurmw=| meta\ boh=s e)xrw=nto with th\n gnw/mhn e)doulou=nto.
tw=n drwme/nwn : obj. gen. with o)/yews. Cf. c. 42. 30, tw=n *)epipolw=n th=s a)naba/sews.
th\n gnw/mhn...e)doulou=nto : of extreme hopelessness, which robs the mind of freedom. Cf. ii.61.13, douloi= ga\r fro/nhma to\ ai)fni/dion; iv.34.9, th=| gnw/mh| dedoulwme/noi.
tw=n e)n tw=| e)/rgw| : = tw=n maxome/nwn.
a)nti/palon : = i)so/rropon.
dia\ to\ a)kri/tws cunexe/s : on account of the long continuance in uncertainty, i.e. the long continuance of the uncertainty.

toi=s sw/masin...cunaponeu/ontes : i.e. in the movement of the body the mood of the mind was reflected. Schol. sunecomoiou=ntes ta\ sw/mata th=| peri\ tw=n gignome/nwn prosdoki/a| a)pe/neuon tw=| sw/mati th=|de ka\kei=se. i)/sa is cognate acc. See on c. 34. 23. The passage is imitated by Sall. Jug. 60: niti corporibus et ea huc et illuc . . . agitare.
e)n toi=s xalepw/tata dih=gon: were in the most painful state. For e)n toi=s, see on c. 19. 19.
20. a)ei\ ga\r par) o)li/gon...a)pw/llunto : for now they were all but sared, now all but lost. para/ as in c. 2. 23.— 21. te: and so. The inferential te as in i.4.5 and often.

a)gxw/mala: cognate acc. See on c. 34. 23. The word is found only in Thuc. and late writers. 22. pa/nta o(mou= a)kou=sai, o)lofurmo\s...kratou/menoi : the pers. const. with ei)=nai(pa/nta being subj. of h)=n) instead of the more usual impers. Cf. Aesch. Pers. 419, qa/lassa d' ou)ke/t) h)=n i)dei=n nauagi/wn plh/qousa. See the imitation of this passage in Charit. p. 66, 10, pa/nta h)=n o(mou=, da/krua, xara/, qa/mbos, e)/leos.

nikw=ntes, kratou/menoi : i.e. the cries of the excited soldiers, we conquer, we are beaten. —a)/lla o(/sa...fqe/ggesqai : = pa/nta ta\ a)/lla ei)/dh fqegma/twn, o(/sa me/ga strato/pedon fqe/ggesqai a)nagka/zoito. a)/lla ends the asyndeton as the Lat. alia. On the asyndeton, see Kr. Spr.
59, 1, 1. On the general rel. cond., see GMT. 62; H. 914, B 2.
25. au)toi=s: sc. toi=s e)n th=| gh=|, dependent on paraplh/sia.
pri/n ge dh/ : until at last. See on c. 39. 5.— e)pi\ polu/: long, with a)ntisxou/shs, as in c. 22. 15; 79. 24, etc.
e)/treyan: the aor. signifies the moment of the crisis, the impf. katedi/wkon (29) the results that followed.
lamprw=s: = fanerw=s, as in i.49.29, h( troph\ e)gi/gneto lamprw=s kai\ e)ne/keinto oi( *kori/nqioi. It belongs to katedi/wkon. Cl. would connect it with e)/treyan, which its position forbids.
30. mete/wroi: i.e. while still afloat in the harbour. Cf. i.48.4, etc.
katenexqe/ntes: Schol. pro\s th\n gh=n. Cf. c. 53. 3.—e)ce/peson e)s to\ strato/pedon: i.e. rushed from the ships into the camp.

ou)ke/ti diafo/rws: no longer with the various emotions described above 8-18, but driven by one impulse (a)po\ mia=s o(rmh=s, for the more usual mia=| o(rmh=|), i.e. despair.— 33. dusanasxetou=ntes: acc. to Poll. iii. 130, first used by Thuc. (and only here); common in later writers. This verb takes the acc. (ta\ gigno/mena), just as dusxerai/nein, a)ganaktei=n. Kr. Spr. 48, 8, 1. Cf. Dion. Hal. p. 596, 22, dusanasxetou=ntes th\n parrhsi/an au)th=s.
oi( me\n...oi( de/ : part. appos. to o( pezo/s as in 4.
to\ loipo\n tou= tei/xous: the diatei/xisma mentioned in c. 60. 9.

peri\ sfa=s au)tou/s: the most thought at this moment (h)/dh) only of themselves. peri/ with the acc. for the more usual gen. Cf. iv.51.5, mhde
 peri\ sfa=s new/teron bouleu/sein; viii.11.19, ta\ peri\ th
 katafugh
 h)gge/lqh.
o(/ph| swqh/sontai : o(/ph| with fut. indic. as o(/tw| tro/pw| in i.107.19, and freq.
37. ou)demia=s e)la/sswn: i.e. megi/sth. So dh/ here as with the sup. In formulas like this the gen. is always used, never h)/. Kühn. 543, note 5; Kr. Spr. 47, 27, 3.

kai/: after paraplh/sia as in c. 70. 2. After kai/
(= w(s) the aor. has the force of the plpf.
diafqareisw=n tw=n new=n kte(.: cf. iv. 14 ff.

prosapw/llunto au)toi=s: (impf.) “were as good as lost for them.” For au)toi=s a few of the minor Mss. have au)tai=s(tai=s nausi/); but the repeated reference to the Lacedaemonians is more foreible than the unnecessary allusion to the ships.—oi( e)n th=| nh/sw| diabebhko/tes: for e)n after verb of motion, see Kühn. 447, A a; Kr. Spr. 68, 12, 2. Cf. iv.14.7, tai=s . . . e)n th=| gh=| katapefeugui/ais; also c. 87. 13. For position of the partic., see on c. 23. 14.
kai\ to/te: so then. See on c. 29. 25.
para\ lo/gon: not para/logon, which Thuc. prob. never used as adj. See on i.65.3.

After the battle the Syracusans erect a trophy. The generals of the Athenians wish to make another attempt during the succeeding night to cut their way through with the rest of their ships; but the troops refuse to go on board again. And so they determine to retreat by land.

1. genome/nhs d) i)sxura=s th=s naumaxi/as kte(.: refers to oi( d' *)aqhnai=oi . . . a)naxwrei=n much more than to oi( *surako/sioi . . . e)/sthsan: “since the battle had been so dreadful and the losses so great, the Athenians thought only of getting away.” Hence only a comma, not a colon, should be placed after e)/sthsan (5).

pollw=n new=n : acc. to 12, the Athenians had lost (110-60) about 50 ships; acc. to 13, the Syracusans (76-50) about 25. See on c. 60. 21 and 70. 24. Diod. xiii. 17 gives the loss on the Athenian side at 60, on the Syracusan at 8 destroyed and 16 rendered useless.
5. u(po\ mege/qous tw=n paro/ntwn kakw=n: u(po/, by reason of. Cf. vi.103.20, u(poyi/an u(po\ tw=n paro/ntwn kakw=n e)s a)llh/lous ei)=xon.
ai)th=sai a)nai/resin : explanatory of the proleptic nekrw=n pe/ri h)\ nauagi/wn. Kr. Spr. 61, 6, 8. Cf. v.63.6, e)peidh\ peri\ *)orxome/nou h)gge/lleto e(alwke/nai.
e)bou/lonto : Vat.; e)bouleu/onto of the rest of the Mss. is appropriate neither with ou)de\ e)peno/oun nor with eu)qu/s.

8. gnw/mhn e)poiei=to: made a pro-
posal. Cf. i.128.27; ii.2.24.
plhrw/santas e)/ti: having manned once more. Cf. c. 59. 8. Kühn. 464, 2, takes e)/ti ta\s loipa/s as equiv. to ta\s e)/ti loipa/s. Cl. omits e)/ti without good reason.
nh=es xrh/simai: the more usual mase. form occurs viii.76.26. The two words are treated as one and therefore placed together after ai( loipai/, while plei/ous is pred.
15. au)tw=n: i.e. Nicias and Demosthenes.

te: added from Vat. and contrasting appropriately the double reason, what had happened and what was to be feared.—mh\...krath=sai : a)/n to be connected with krath=sai; mh\ e)/ti oi)/esqai dependent on dia\ to/.
w(s kata\ gh=n a)naxwrh/sontes : cf. Plat. Legg. 755 b, mhke/ti th\n thlikau/thn a)rxh\n w(s a)/rcwn dianohqh/tw.

Hermocrates advises the Syracusans to wall off all the roads leading into the interior, and occupy them with troops. But the next day being a festival of Hercules, they are indisposed to make new efforts. Hermocrates, thereupon, warns the Athenians through messengers whom they suppose friendly not to set out in the night, saying that they will find the roads guarded by troops.
2. ei)...boulh/setai...to\n po/lemon poiei=sqai : cf. c. 51. 5.
e)shgei=tai: represents. Cf. iii.20.7; iv.76.8; vi.99.7.—toi=s e)n te/lei ou)=si: cf. i.90.29; vi.88.61. For the dat. with e)lqw/n, see on i.13.12.

a)poxwrh=sai au)tou\s periidei=n: to let them quietly withdraw. Kr. and Cl. think that periidei=n with the inf. represents the possibility of anything taking place, with the partic. the fact. Kr. Spr. 56, 6, 3. But in GMT. 24, N. 2, the inf. and partic. are shown to refer to exactly the same thing. Cf. ii.18.21, periidei=n tmhqei=san; ii.20.6, periidei=n tmhqh=nai. See also Kühn. 484, 24.—le/gwn tau=ta a(\ kai\ au)tw=|
e)do/kei: so Vat. and most of the Mss. The sense seems to be, “saying just what he actually (kai/) thought.” Cl. explains, “saying that which seemed to him from his own conjecture (kai\ au)tw=|) probable.” Certain intelligence he did not claim to have. The reference is to u(ponoh/sas au)tw=n th\n dia/noian and the consideration connected therewith, kai\ nomi/sas . . . to\n po/lemon poiei=sqai. e)shgei=tai expresses the advice, le/gwn the ground for it. Neither explanation, though perhaps as good as can be given, is entirely satisfactory, and St. may be right in bracketing the words.
a)lla\ e)celqo/ntas...a)poikodomh=sai...fula/ssein : supply xre/wn e)sti/ from above.—h)/dh: immediately.
ta\s o(dou\s a)poikodomh=sai: Schol. a)pofra/cai dia/ tinos oi)kodomh=s. Cf. i.134.12.

dialabo/ntas: Cl. and Bm. follow Bk. in adopting this reading from Vat. for profqa/santas of the remaining Mss. and editt. dialabei=n, which occurs only here in Thuc., is warranted and explained by the imitation of Polyb. i. 18, oi( strathgoi\ tw=n *(rwmai/wn ta\ metacu\ tw=n ta/frwn kai\ tw=n stratope/dwn diasth/mata fulakai=s die/labon; iv. 67, o( *fi/lippos klei/sas ta\s pu/las tou= *kori/nqou kai\ dialabw\n ta\s o(dou\s fulakai=s. Cf. Diod. xiv. 75, kai\ *dionu/sios ta\s o(dou\s dialabw\n fulakai=s. Suidas, citing our passage, explains: dialabw/n, prokatasxw/n. See App.— oi( de/: sc. e)n te/lei o)/ntes.
10. cunegi/gnwskon: were of the same opinion; cun- with adv. force. Cf. ii.60.15.

a)/rti...a)napepaume/nous : “the men having just gladly taken a little repose after the great sea-fight.” On account of a)sme/nous and the prep. a)po/, a)napepaume/nous is to be preferred to pepaume/nous of Vat. For the simple partic. and gen. abs. co-ord., see Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.— 14. ou) dokei=n: depends loosely on e)gi/gnwskon (or e)/legon) to be supplied from cunegi/gnwskon above.—a)/n: belongs with e)qelh=sai.
u(po\ tou= perixarou=s : “by reason of their great joy.” u(po/ as in c. 72. 5. to\ perixare/s occurs also in ii.51.28.

sfw=n: the gen. with pei/qesqai not elsewhere found in Att. prose. Kühn. 417, note
6; Kr. Spr. 48, 7, 8. Kr. compares Eur. I. A. 726, pei/qesqai ga\r ei)/qismai se/qen. The gen. is common in Hdt. Cf. i.59.13, and Stein's note. The gen. sfw=n is here partly induced by the preceding pa/nta: “anything else from them they would be more ready to listen to than an order to take up arms,” etc.
19. ou)ke/ti e)/peiqen au)tou/s: i.e. when his arguments no longer produced any effect.

e)pi\ tou/tois: under these circumstances. See on c. 62. 14. —ta/de mhxana=tai: he contrived the following plan, which is set forth without connective (ga/r) after ta/de, as often after toio/nde. See on i.89.2.— 24. cunesko/tazen: as in i.51.7.

e)c o(/sou: i.e. e)s tosou=ton e)c o(/sou. Kr. Spr. 51, 13, 9.—tis: i.e. in the camp of the Athenians, for a)kou/sesqai is act.—a)nakalesa/menoi: (mid.) calling forth by name (to themselves). See on c. 69. 10; 70. 49. By this very act they made themselves appear to be, as they claimed, e)pith/deioi.

dia/ggeloi tw=n e)/ndoqen : Schol. mhnutai\ kai\ e)cagge/llontes ta\ *surakosi/wn. dia/ggelos is found elsewhere only in the later writers (e.g. Dio C. xl. 8), but corresponds to the verb diagge/llein in 31. Since it was known on both sides that Nicias had spies in Syracuse (cf. c. 48. § 2), Hermocrates was able without difficulty to get access to the Athenians. But these messengers, of course, did not belong to the spies of Nicias.

kai\ oi( a)kou/santes: Kr.'s proposal kai\ oi(/, opp. to oi( me/n, would be admissible after the analogy of iv.33.11; 68. 25. But the correlative of oi( me/n is rather oi( de/ in c. 74. 1, and kai\ oi( a)kou/santes . . . *)aqhnai/wn is logically subord. to the preceding clause, as if the sent. ran, kai\ oi( me\n a)ph=lqon ei)po/ntes tau=ta, a(\ oi( a)kou/santes kte(.

p.hi: The commanders of the Athenians, deceived into remaining during the coming night, spend also the following

day in preparations for the departure. The Syracusans, however, make use of the time to shut off the roads, and to place guards at the crossings of the rivers. At the same time they draw from the shore and bring to their harbour the ships which had been abandoned and left unburnt by the Athenians.

div2.p: 1. pro\s to\ a)/ggelma: in view of the message. pro/s as in iii.43.12; iv.126.4.—e)pe/sxon: with acc. of time, as in i.137.32; iv.31.1, etc.
ou)k: belongs to a)pa/thn only, opp. to an implied contrast, a)ll) a)lh/qeian.
kai\ w(/s : even thus, i.e. after the fatal delay of the first night. Bm. explains, “even thus, notwithstanding the necessity for immediate departure.”
cuskeua/sainto: convasare, in Thuc. only here.—w(s e)k tw=n dunatw=n: nearly equiv. to w(s e)k tw=n paro/ntwn (vi.70.18), as well as they could. On w(s with such phrases, see Kr. Spr. 69, 63, 4.
o(/ti xrhsimw/tata: has the emphasis of the sent., “in the most convenient form” (Jow.).

a)nalabo/ntas: (Vat.) preferable to the nom. of the vulgate, a)nalabo/ntes, as it removes the anacoluthon. Cf. i.31.10; 53. 1; 72. 5, where after e)/docen au)toi=s a pred. acc. with inf. follows. But in iii.36.8 we have the nom. as in the vulgate.—au)ta\ o(/sa: only that which. Kr. Spr. 51, 5, 5.—peri\ to\ sw=ma e)s di/aitan: for support of life.
10. a)pefra/gnusan: the unusual form fragnu/nai, for fra/ssein, found also in Soph. Ant. 241.
e)s u(podoxh/n: unusual in hostile sense; for its use in a friendly sense, see on i.139.11.
ta\s nau=s tw=n *)aqhnai/wn: which, acc. to c. 71. 31, had been run ashore.

e)ne/prhsan...*)aqhnai=oi : a parenthetical clause stating what had already been done by the Athenians. The aor. has the force of the plpf. between the impfs. a)fei=lkon, e)ko/mizon, which indicate the continued activity of the Syracusans. w(/sper dienoh/qhsan refers to c. 60. 15.
w(s e(ka/sthn poi e)kpeptwkui=an: “as they severally had run aground anywhere.” The clause is really elliptical, the leading verb being understood. See on i.3.19.

Under such sad circumstances the Athenian army sets out on the third day after the battle. Everything combines to render the situation desperate: the leaving behind of the dead, as well as the wounded and the sick, who break forth into the bitterest complaints; the despondency and helplessness with which about 40,000 men face a perfectly dark future; the lack of servants, most of whom had recently run away; the remembrance of the brilliant hopes with which they had set out, and which had now been utterly destroyed.

2. pareskeua/sqai: impers. inf. from the impers. indic. Cf. i.46.1; iii.107.21; iv.67.2.—kai/: introducing the immediate performance of the resolution taken, as in ii.93.18; iv.8.40; viii.27.24, w(s e)/peise, kai\ e)/drase tau=ta.
a)na/stasis : departure, as in i.133.14; ii.14.7.

4. deino
 h)=n: with general subj. Cf. ii.51.11; v.64.17.—ou) kaq' e(
 mo/non tw=n pragma/twn: explained by o(/ti ta/s te nau=s . . . kinduneu/ontes, and opp. to a)lla\ kai\ e)n th=| a)polei/yei . . . ai)/sqesqai (7), i.e. the general result is contrasted with the personal experiences of the individual. The general sense of the whole sent. is: “it was terrible not only with regard to the one chief aspect of their situation (the loss of the fleet and consequent danger for themselves and the state), but also in that each one on leaving the camp had the most painful impressions.” a)lla\ . . . ai)/sqesqai, though grammatically independent, is logically subord. to deino
 h)=n. See App.— 6. a)nti\ mega/lhs e)lpi/dos: short for “instead of accomplishing the great things for which they had hoped.”— 8. ai)/sqesqai: with the accentuation of the pres. in the good Mss. here and in v.26.29, corresponding to the sense of the passage, which refers to repeated and wide-spread impressions.

10. kei/menon: i.e. lying dead. Cf. iv.38.8; Xen. An. i.8.27.—meta\
fo/bou: thinking of the sacred duty of the burial of the dead.

zw=ntes kataleipo/menoi: closely connected with and attrib. to traumati/ai te kai\ a)sqenei=s: the wounded and sick (c. 60. 10) who were left behind alive.— 12. toi=s zw=si: Cl. thinks the epithet zw=ntes, applied to the departing Athenians, out of place, esp. as the same expression has just been used very appropriately for the kataleipo/menoi. toi=s zw=si, he explains, must have been written by a glossator to make the meaning of lnphro/n eroi (painful, act.) clear, or perhaps toi=s o(rw=si must be substituted. The latter is more probable since kaqi/stasan (sc. au)tou/s) seems to require some preceding noun. But it may be questioned whether toi=s zw=si, although not necessary to the sense, does not after all make the contrast even stronger: “and the wounded and sick who were left behind alive were far more grievous to the living than the dead, and more wretched than those who had perished.”
14. a)ntiboli/an: Schol. de/hsis, i(kesi/a.
kaqi/stasan : sc. au)tou/s, tou\s u(poxwrou=ntas.
e)/na e(/kaston : cf. c. 69. 9; 70. 37.—e)pibow/menoi: calling aloud. Cf. c. 69. 20; iii.59.11; 67. 9; viii.92.50.
h)/dh a)pio/ntwn: i.e. when they were just on the point of starting.
e)s o(/son: Vat. and Valla (quousque) for o(/son.
proli/poi : Vat. for prolei/poi, aor. of the single case. It is intr., like e)llei/pein, and rare. Cf. Eur. Or. 817, fo/nos . . . ou) prolei/pei dissoi=sin *)atrei/dais.
h( r(w/mh kai\ to\ sw=ma : not equiv. to r(w/mh tou= sw/matos (Pp.). but “their (last) powers of spirit and body.” See App. to vi.31.3.
ou)k a)/neu [o)li/gwn] e)piqeiasmw=n : the sense required here is evidently not without many imprecations, and Valla translates, non sine multis obtestationibus ac ploratibus. See App.

u(poleipomenoi: dropping behind. Vat. for a)poleipo/menoi. It is intr. rather than pass. For the pl. after tw|, see Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 5.—da/krusi: rare dat. with plhsqe/n for dakru/wn. Cf. Eur. Or. 1363, dakru/oisin . . . *(ella/da . . . e)/plhse; Aesch. Pers. 133, pi/mplatai dakru/masin.
a)pori/a| : co-ord. with plhsqe/n.

kai/per e)k polemi/as : sc. a)for-
mwme/nous. Though kai/per belongs also to the following partics., peponqo/tas, dedio/tas (connected kata\ su/nesin with stra/teuma), the restrictive signification is not prominent.
mei/zw h)\ kata/: quam pro. Kühn. 543, 8; Kr. Spr. 49, 4. Cf. ii.50.2.
ta\ de/: connected by prolepsis with dedio/tas, but in sense belonging to pa/qwsi.
peri\ tw=n e)n a)fanei= : Schol. peri\ tw=n mello/ntwn.
24. kath/feia: dejection; in Thuc. only here. It means originally a looking down (from modesty or shame). —kata/memyis sfw=n au)tw=n: self-condemnation.

ou)de\n a)/llo h)/: really elliptical; some general word like e)gi/gneto or e)poi/ei must be supplied from the following verb, as with Lat. nihil aliud quam. See on ii.16.10. Kühn. 597, 20; Kr. Spr. 62, 3, 7. —po/lei e)kpepoliorkhme/nh|: i.e. the inhabitants of a city captured after a siege.

ou) smikra=|: this form occurs also in iv.13.19; viii.81.11. —muria/des kte(.: Boeckh (P. E. p. 367) estimates that over 60,000 men had come to Sicily. To these must be added the Sicilian allies. By loss in battle and esp. by desertion (below, 32, and c. 13. 12) they had been reduced to this number.
tis e(/kastos: cf. vi.31.31.

para\ to\ ei)wqo\s au)toi/: as a rule every hoplite and cavalryman was attended by a servant.—e)pi\ toi=s o(/plois: in addition to their arms, Pluygers's emendation (Mmem. 11, 96) for u(po\ toi=s o(/plois. Cf. c. 86. 8, e)pi\ toi=s a)/llois, in addition to everything else.

a)kolou/qwn: elsewhere called qera/pontes (c. 13. 9; iv.16.9) or u(phre/tai (iii.17.10; vi.102.10).—a)pisti/a|: i.e. fearing that those who were still present would follow the example of those who had run away.
paraxrh=ma: lately, i.e. since the sea-fight. Schol. e)n tw=| to/te paro/nti.
ou)de\ tau=ta : i.e. ta\ siti/a.

34. h( a)/llh ai)ki/a kai\ i)somoiri/a tw=n kakw=n: we should have expected “nor, moreover, was the rest of their
misery and sufferings easy to bear” (ai)ki/a referring to their inward wretchedness, ta\ kaka/ to the outward ills that came upon them). But by the addition of i)somoiri/a a shift in the thought is effected; for this idea,— not simply the evils, but the equal sharing of them,—dominates all the rest of the sent. And so we have: “and, moreover, the rest of their misery, and the equal sharing of their sufferings, although having in this very ‘along with the many’ some alleviation,” etc. to/ introduces the proverbial meta\ pollw=n. Cf. to\ krati/stous ei)=nai kte(., c. 67. 3. Kr. Spr. 50, 5, 12. to\ meta\ pollw=n is obj. of e)/xousa, and tina kou/fisin is pred. See App.

ou)d' w(/s: refers to e)/xousa . . . kou/fisin, but resumes esp. the idea of o(/mws, which though joined to the partic. belongs in sense to the main verb. —a)/llws te kai/: supply e)nqumoume/nois from e)doca/zeto. Kühn. 551, 9 does not supply e)nqumoume/nois, but explains = o(/ti a)po\ toiau/ths kte(.

a)po\ oi(/as lampro/thtos...e)s oi(/an teleuth/n : the same emphatic connexion of two rel. clauses with strong effect as in v.7.4.—au)xh/matos: self-confidence. Cf. c. 66. 15; ii.62.28.—tou= prw/tou: placed after its noun for emphasis, “as it was at first,” and opp to teleuth/n, as lampro/thtos kai\ au)xh/matos is to tapeino/thta.
a)fi=kto : it had come, without expressed subj. as pareskeua/sqai in 2 above and i.46.1. St. has adopted Badham's conjecture, a)fi/kato.

me/giston ga\r kte(.: for the form of the sent., see on c. 29. 29; i.1.8.— 39. to\ dia/foron: reverse, i.e. change in circumstances. See on c. 55. 9.— *(ellhnikw=|: the art. tw=| which the Mss. have is not appropriate, since there is an implied contrast with ba/rbaros, as in v.60.14; vi.31.7. Of the Persians at Marathon and Salamis the like could perhaps be said. —oi(=s: referring to stra/teuma, as in 22, peponqo/tas. See on c. 1. 9. For the acc. following, see on c. 74. 6.— 40. a)nti\ tou=...h(/kein kte(.: cf. i.69.24.—tou=to: proleptic, as ta\ de/ in 23.
meq' w(=n e)ce/pleon: cf. vi. 32.— pa/lin tou/twn: the first belongs to a)forma=sqai; the second to e)nanti/ois. For position of tou/twn, cf. vi.64.24, tau=ta tou\s cundra/sontas.

pezou/s te : te (Vat.; the rest of the Mss. de/) is co-ord. with kai/ before o(plitikw=|.— 44. naubatw=n: this rather unusual
word includes, as the Schol. correctly observes, the nau=tai and e)piba/tai.
prose/xontas : Vat. for vulgate prossxo/ntas, “turning their minds to, trusting.”
u(po\ mege/qous: cf. c. 72. 5.
oi)sta/: as in i.122.9.
Nicias tries by an address to raise the sinking courage of his troops.
1. e)n mega/lh| metabolh=| o)/n: in consequence of the me/giston dia/foron of c. 75. 38.

e)pipariw/n: i.e. coming up to and going along the ranks, which were already setting off. Cf. iv.94.11; vi.67.19.—w(s e)k tw=n u(parxo/ntwn: as well as possible under the circumstances. See on c. 74. 4, w(s e)k tw=n dunatw=n.
e)/ti ma=llon : i.e. than before the last battle, c. 69. 9 ff.
e(ka/stois: dat. governed by boh=| xrw/menos = e)pibow=n, c. 70. 44.

w(s e)pi\ plei=ston gegwni/skwn: “raising his voice so as to be heard as far as possible.” gegwni/skein only here in Thuc., otherwise poetic. Cf. Aesch. Prom. 627; Eur. El. 809. Cf. ii.34.24, o(/pws a)kou/oito w(s e)pi\ plei=ston.

w)felei=n ti : so Vat., the rest of the Mss. simply w)felei=n, beginning the following chap. with e)/ti. w)felei=n ti is very appropriate here where the utmost effort to effect some good is described. The const. is the same as in w)felei=n me/ga, plei=sta, ou)de/n.

div2.head: SPEECH OF NICIAS TO THE ATHENI- ANS ON LEAVING SYRACUSE.
div2.p: However difficult our situation is, we need not give up hope. In the consciousness of having done my duty toward gods and men, I shall set you a good example. Should the anger of the gods be the cause of our misfortune, we may hope that this will change and a better future be granted us. We are still numerous and strong enough to establish for ourselves a new commonwealth. Our whole effort must be directed to keeping good order on our march, and we must, if necessary, even by hard fighting, cut our way through to the territory of the friendly Sicels. If we succeed in that, the others of you may hope to see your homes again; we Athenians, however, to raise up our city again from its great fall. For men make the state, not walls nor ships.
1. kai\ e)k tw=n paro/ntwn: this reading of Vat. (without e)/ti) has, prop. emphasized, the strongest effect. For kai/ with similar emphasis at the beginning of a speech, cf. vi.16.1.

h)/dh tine\s...e)sw/qhsan : some have been rescued from even worse straits than these. h)/dh with the aor. refers to well known experiences. Cf. 15 below, h)=lqon . . . kai\ a)/lloi tine\s h)/dh; also ii.
77. 15; iv.62.13. On the asyndeton, which is somewhat softened by the emphatic position of h)/dh, see Kr. Spr. 59, 1, 5.—h)\ toiw=nde: Cl. explains as = h)\ e)k toiw=nde, the prep. not being repeated, as in c. 47. 16; vi.78.4. It might equally well be considered an attraction of case (from h)\ toia/de). So Kühn. 543, 2 b.

mhde\ katame/mfesqai kte(.: the pres., from Vat., is more comprehensive than the vulgate katame/yasqai: “and not to reproach yourselves too heavily, either for the misfortunes which have befallen you (esp. in the last battles) or for your present unmerited sufferings.” With katame/mfesqai u(ma=s, cf. kata/memyis sfw=n au)tw=n of c. 75. 24. cumforai/ are the single occurrences; kakopa/qeiai, the enduring conditions. For the causal dat., see H. 778; Kr. Spr. 48, 15, 6.
6. profe/rwn: intr. as in c. 64. 15; ii.89.11.—w(s dia/keimai u(po\ th=s no/sou: how I am afflicted by my disease. Cf. c. 15. 9; vi.102.8.
eu)tuxi/a|: cf. v.16.12; vi.17.5.
kai\ e)s ta)=lla: i.e. in official and public life.—toi=s faulota/tois: not in a moral, but political sense, with the humblest (in the army).
ai)wrou=mai: suspensus sum. Cf. Hdt. viii.100.9, to\n bi/on u(pe\r mega/lwn ai)wrhqe/nta.

kai/toi...a)nepi/fqona : “yet my days have been passed in the performance of many a religious duty, and of many a just and blameless action” (Jow.). dedih/|thmai has the cognate acc. as in i.6.23, polla\ to\ . . . *(ellhniko\n o(moio/tropa diaitw/menon. G. 159; H. 715. a)nepi/fqona has reference to the timidity of Nicias about giving offence in any way. Cf. Plut. Nic. 2.
o(/mws: i.e. in spite of our desperate situation.

ai( de\ cumforai\...fobou=si : Cl. understands h(ma=s as obj. of fobou=si, but it is more natural to take e)me/ (Nicias) as the obj. Our calamities frighten me not so much as they might otherwise well do. The argument of the sent. is: “in consequence of my good conscience I have hope, and so dangers do not frighten me as much as they might otherwise properly do. If I feel so, why may not you all?” See App.

13. ta/xa d) a)\n kte(.: quite in accordance with the religious manner of thinking of Nicias (h)=n ti kai\ a)/gan qeiasmw=| te kai\ tw=| toiou/tw| proskei/menos,
c. 50. 30). The sense is that even if the jealousy of the gods has hitherto been roused against the Athenians, this has been appeased by the good fortune of the enemy and their own ill fortune, and they may now look for a change.

eu)tu/xhtai: pass., the cognate acc. of the act. becoming subj. Kr. Spr. 52, 3, 4; Kühn. 378, 10.—ei)/ tw| qew=n e)pi/fqonoi e)strateu/samen: = ei) th=| e)s *sikeli/an stratei/a| to\n fqo/non tw=n qew=n tinos e)kinh/samen. Nicias expressed his sense of the arrogance of the expedition in his first speech, vi. 9 ff.
tetimwrh/meqa: pass. as in vi.60.28. Kr. Spr. 52, 10, 11.
16. a)nqrw/peia: i.e. what belongs to human nature, here referring to warlike hostility. Cf. v.68.6; viii.24.29.

a)po\ tou= qei/ou: Kr.'s emendation for qeou= of the Mss., which is necessary in order to bring the passage into accord with the usage of Thuc. See Introd. to Book I., p. 29. o( qeo/s refers everywhere in Thuc. to some special god, e.g. Apollo; the numen divinum is to\ qei=on. Cf. v.70.4; 104. 4; 105. 1, 5, 11; 112. 7.

a)p' au)tw=n: sc. tw=n qew=n, referring kata\ su/nesin to the collective qei/ou, which includes all the gods.— 19. kai\ o(rw=ntes: kai/ co-ord. with te in 17, as if we had o(rw=ntas . . . katapeplh=xqai depending on ei)ko/s.
oi(=oi : Vat., the rest of the Mss. oi(/.
katape/plhxqe : Vat. katapeplh=xqai, vitio itacismi. The context makes the imv. necessary.
eu)qu/s: already, i.e. by reason of your number and importance.
ou)/t' a)\n e)pio/ntas de/caito: could neither resist your attack. Cf. c. 40. 15; 44. 20.
25. mh\ a)/llo ti h(ghsa/menos h)/: common introduction to hyperbolical ex pressions. Cf. i.70.29; iii.30.12; 56. 25.
krath/sas: if he conquer.

28. e)/stai: the fut. with the force
of the imv. “You will not lag day or night,” i.e. you dare not. Kühn. 387, 5.
a)ntilabw/meqa: cf. c. 60. 17.
h)/dh: then only.

prope/pemptai...komi/zein : we hare sent to them, directing them to meet us, and at the same time to bring food. For the acc. abs., see on c. 18. 14. kai/, kai/ correlative. a(/ma, Reiske's emendation for a)/lla, is necessary since no subst. precedes. Valla translates pariter et commeatum.
33. to/ te cu/mpan: so Vat. for to\ de/. Cf. c. 49. 18; iii.92.17; iv.63.8; vi.37.18.
swqei=te: on the form, see App.
oi(/ te a)/lloi teuco/menoi...kai\ oi( *aqhnai=oi...e)panorqw/sontes : dependent on gnw=te. For the co-ordination of neut. acc. (o)/n, 34) and nom., see Kr. Spr. 56, 14, 2.
w(=n: neut., fatherland, etc. —e)pidei=n: see again, cf. 61. 5.

a)/ndres ga\r...kenai/ : a sentiment occurring in manifold forms in Greek. Cf. Soph. O. T. 56, w(s ou)de/n e)stin ou)/te pu/rgos ou)/te nau=s e)/rhmos a)ndrw=n mh\ cunoikou/ntwn e)/sw; Aesch. Pers. 349; Alcae. frg. 23; Eur. frg. 825 (Nauck); Dio C. lvi.5.3; Plut. Lycurg. 19; Demad. frg. § 2; Dem. XVIII. 299; Luc. Anach. 20; Appian, Pun. viii. 29; Cic. ad Att. vii. 11; Sir W. Jones, “What constitutes a state?” etc.

Thereupon the Athenian army sets off into the interior of the island, marching in a double hollow square with the baggage in the middle. They cross the Anapus after putting the Syracusans stationed there to flight, and make on the first day 40, on the second, 20 stades. On the third, however, being hard pressed by the cavalry and light troops of the enemy, they are forced to turn back and pass the night at their former campingplace.
With the account of the retreat of the Athenians, compare map, and Holm II. p. 397-401; also the App. to c. 78. 14.

1. e)ph/|ei to\ stra/teuma: “went along
the ranks.” Cf. e)pipariw/n, c. 76. 2, which implies approaching in order to speak to. a(/ma belongs to parakeleuo/menos.
kaqista/s : i.e. putting them in line.
ou)de\n h(=sson: sc. e)ph/|ei.
toi=s kaq) e(auto/n : to the troops under his command.

5. e)n plaisi/w|: Schol. (on vi.67.6) e)n sxh/mati tetragw/nw|. A hollow square called tetra/gwnos ta/cis in iv.125.16. Cl. is doubtless right in adopting plaisi/w| from Vat., instead of diplasi/w| of the other Mss., but his view that the two divisions of the army formed together a hollow square seems not to agree so well with the context, as Kr.'s and St.'s, that each division formed its own plai/sion.
prw=ton me\n h(gou/menon : these words, found only in Vat., are indispensable to the sense. There is the same redundancy of expression as in prw=ton h)/rcato, i.103.17; ii.53.1.
tou\s de\ skeuofo/rous...e)nto\s ei)=xon : cf. vi.67.9; Xen. An. iii.2.36.
8. [te]: rightly omitted by Bm. as having no prop. connexion.
tw=n *surakosi/wn kai\ cumma/xwn: part. gens. Cf. c. 26. 14; iv.80.7.— 13. e)sakonti/zontes oi( yiloi/: part. appos. to oi( *surako/sioi. Cf. c. 71. 1, 4.
14. stadi/ous w(s tessara/konta: see App.
prw/|: see on c. 19. 1.— 17. a)/pedon: level, a rare word. Cf. Hdt. ix.102.3, a)/pedos xw=ros. Schol. o(/malon, o(mo/pedon, w(s kai\ a)/loxos h)\ o(mo/loxos.

sta/dia : the neut. form in Thuc. only here.—h(=| e)/mellon i)e/nai:
i.e. westward to the high plateau, which, however, they did not reach.
22. a)petei/xizon: were walling off (impf.).

*)akrai=on le/pas: the situation of this bare cliff, which marks the beginning of the plateau, can still be determined by means of the ravine leading thither, now called Cava di Culatrello. See Holm, II. p. 64 and 399, and Karlsr. Philol. Wochenschr. 1882.
26. au)tou/s: emphatic position, as u(ma=s in i.68.1; sfa=s, v.82.23.—e(kate/rwqen: this reading of Vat. for e(ka/teroi best suits the context. Cf. Valla, utrimque.
29. e)s to\ au)to\ strato/pedon: i.e. in which they had passed the night before.—ou)ke/ti o(moi/ws: i.e. as before, when real want had not yet been felt.
a)poxwrei=n: Schol. a)poski/dnasqai a)po\ tou= strateu/matos, i.e. for foraging.—u(po\ tw=n i(ppe/wn: cf. vi.37.18.

The two following days also pass in vain attempts to force their way through the narrow pass up to the plateau. They are frightened, moreover, by a storm which breaks upon them, and suffer heary losses in their constant fighting with the enemy, who attack them on all sides.
1. prw/|: on the fourth day of the march.

[e)lqei=n]: St. is prob. right, following Valla's translation, vi pervadunt ad tumulum, in considering this an interpolation. It seems clear from the context (esp. 6, 7), that they forced their way to the hill, but were not able to carry it. Nowhere else in Thuc. does bia/zesqai take an inf., but always a prep. (e)s, c. 69. 29; i.63.5; kata/, iv.48.8; dia/, c. 83. 19). See Holm, H. p. 399. Cl. defends e)lqei=n, rendering “they did their best to reach the fortified hill.” —to\n a)poteteixisme/non: cf. c. 78. 22.

ou)k e)p' o)li/gwn a)spi/dwn: referring to the depth of the line. Cf. iv.93.22, e)p' a)spi/das pe/nte kai\ ei)/kosi; Xen. Hell. ii.4.11, e)pi\ penth/konta
a)spi/dwn; An. iv.8.11. The order ou)k e)p' o)li/gwn as ou)k e)n pollw=|, c. 36. 17.
6. e)teixoma/xoun: they tried to storm the wall.
diiknou=nto r(a=|on: they reached them more easily, i.e. hit them better. Schol. e)ciknou=nto ba/llontes. Found only here in Thuc.
bia/sasqai: to break through.—a)pexw/roun: (Vat.) not less used of retreat than a)naxwrei=n, esp. with pa/lin. Cf. i.107.11.
9. brontai/: in Thuc. always in pl. Cf. ii.77.23; vi.70.2.—geno/menai: often used of such phenomena of nature, u(/dwr, brontai\ kai\ a)strapai/, seismo/s. See on i.54.6.
pro\s meto/pwron: toward autumn. Cf. viii.108.9.
kai\ tau=ta pa/nta gi/gnesqai: i.e. that all this was happening acc. to the divine will.
14. a)poteixiou=ntas: with the collective me/ros ti. G. 138, N. 3; Kr. Spr. 58, 4, 1. Cf. iii.2.2.
au)= e)k tou= o)/pisqen: i.e. as they had already done in front.
17. meta\ tou=to: so Vat., more definite than meta\ tau=ta.
pro\s to\ pedi/on ma=llon : more toward the plain. Cf. c. 52. 8; vi.88.20.
th=| u(sterai/a|: on the fifth day.
ei) me\n e)pi/oien...e)pe/keinto : for similar tactics (and const.), cf. ii.79.23; iii.97.16.

ei)/ pws...fobh/seian : the elliptical cond. expresses purpose. GMT. 53, N. 2. The same const. occurs also
in i.58.2; ii.67.5; iii.4.14; iv.11.12.
kata\ braxu/: a few at a time. Cf. iv.96.19.
pe/nte h)\ e(\c stadi/ous: their strength, exhausted in resisting ceaseless pressure from all sides, did not allow them to get further.

Finally they break up in the middle of the night, in order to escape the pursuit of the enemy, and take their journey in the opposite direction, first to the coast and then toward Gamarina and Gela. But the army, driven by fear, pushes hastily on and falls into confusion. The division of Nicias goes before and keeps together; the greater part under Demosthenes follows in disorder. In the morning, however, Nicias reaches the coast, drives away a Syracusan guard at the river Cacyparis, crosses, and gets as far as the Erineus.
1. th=s nukto/s: during the night preceding the sixth day after departure.

te: wanting in Vat. and omitted by Cl. on the ground that it has no correlative, kai\ . . . gegenhme/nais being merely parenthetical; but it would seem better with the other editt. to take te as co-ord. with kai/, the two clauses giving the grounds of kakw=s ei)=xe. For the omission of o(/ti before kai\ katatetraumatisme/noi h)=san, cf. v.61.17, boulo/menoi a)/llws te prosgene/sqai sfi/si, kai\ o(/mhroi . . . h)=san au)to/qi.

pura\ kau/santas : the reading of Vat. for kau/santes is preferable after tw=| *niki/a| kai\ *dhmosqe/nei e)do/kei. See on c. 74. 6. pura/, the pl. of the second deel., watch-fires. The object was to deceive the enemy with regard to their departure.
tou)nanti/on h)/: as in vi.68.14.

7. h)=n de\ h( cu/mpasa o(do\s au(/th kte(.: this parenthetical remark, introduced by the epexegetical de/, refers, as the expression h( cu/mpasa o(do/s clearly shows, to the goal of the whole march after the departure from Syracuse, not simply to the direction taken in the night after the fifth day. Thuc. says expressly, and prob. in contradiction of varying reports about it: “from the beginning the plan of the march was not toward Catana (northward),
but in the direction of Camarina and Gela (south-westward).” When, therefore, Diod. xiii. 18 says, proh/|esan e)pi\ *kata/nhs, he has either misunderstood Thuc., or he follows another account not approved by Thuc. See App.
11. kau/santes ou)=n: resumptive after the digression. See on c. 6. 7; 42. 24.
oi(=on filei=: quod solet. Cf. iv.125.7, o(/per filei= mega/la strato/peda a)safw=s e)kplh/gnusqai.

fo/boi kai\ dei/mata : in explanatory appos. to oi(=on. Bloomf. compares Eur. Hel. 312, fo/bos ei)s to\ dei=ma m' a)/gei, to prove that dei=ma is stronger than fo/bos, the former referring esp. to panic terrors. fo/bos and de/os are distinguished by Prodicus, Plat. Prot. 358 d. For the pl. of words expressing emotion or passion, see Kr. Spr. 44, 3, 4.

[a)po/]: bracketed by Cl., with the majority of the editt., as admitting no intelligible explanation. Ullrich (Beitr. III. p. 28) explains, “going away from enemies not far distant.” So Kr., Arn., Bm.
i)ou=si: belongs to au)toi=s, not to stratope/dois.
16. w(/sper h(gei=to: referring to the advantage which Nicias had, and giving the ground of prou)/labe, rather than of cune/mene.

prou/labe pollw=| : sc. th=s o(dou=. Cf. iv.33.12, prolamba/nontes r(a|di/ws th=s fugh=s; Hdt. iii.105.6, prolamba/nein th=s o(dou=; Liv. xxxvi. 19, aliquantum viae praeceperat. (Arn.) pollw=| is dat. of degree of difference. Kr. Spr. 48, 15, 9.
kai\ ple/on: cf. c. 48. 24.

a(/ma de\ th=| e(/w|: sixth day. From here to the end of the chap. the events related refer to the division of Nicias alone, as Holm (H. p. 401) has shown by the most careful investigation, coming to the same result that Grote had reached by another way.
o(do\n th\n *)elwri/nhn: cf. vi.66.17.

e)pi\ *kakupa/rei: now Fiume di Cassibile. For the usual order of
words, see Kr. Spr. 50, 7, 1; Kühn. 462, note 1. Cf. c. 82. 15.
ou(\s metepe/myanto: for the facts, cf. c. 77. 32, and on the mid. (Vat.), see App. to i.112.6. For aor. indic. instead of opt. after secondary tense, see GMT. 74, 2.

27. e)xw/roun pro\s...to\n *)erineo/n : advanced towards the Erineus. In c. 82. 15 they are said to have arrived there. The Erineus cannot be identified with certainty. Leake considers it the present Falconara; Holm (II. p. 401), the Cavallata.
tau/th|: sc. xwrei=n. Why the guides directed them to take this course can only be conjectured.

In the meantime the Syracusans, learning that the Athenians had withdrawn during the night, pursue them eagerly. They overtake Demosthenes first, who had been left considerably behind with his division, and compel him to halt. He takes shelter in a walled enclosure, where he resists their continual attacks until his men are completely exhausted.
1. h( h(me/ra: i.e. that following the nocturnal occurrences just described and referred to c. 80. 13, a(/ma th=| e(w|; hence the art.
e)n ai)ti/a|...ei)=xon : = e)ph|tiw=nto. See on i.35.10. With following inf. also in v.65.24. Kr. Spr. 50, 6, 6.
ou) xalepw=s: with h)|sqa/nonto.
8. th=s nukto\s to/te: refers back to c. 80. 18. See on c. 31. 12.
di/xa dh\ o)/ntas: Schol. kexwrisme/nous a)po\ tw=n meta\ tou= *niki/ou. dh/ referring to r(a=|on and giving with the partic. the reason. Cf. iv.59.14; vi.80.14.
cunh=gon e)s tau)to/: they drove them together. See on c. 36. 31.

12. kai\ penth/konta stadi/ous: Vat. has e(kato\n kai\ penth/konta, and so Valla read, centum quinquaginta. But such a gain in so short a time is impossible. St. proposes trei=s kai\ pe/nte(g/ for r/) but so exact a statement is hardly admissible under the circumstances. kai/ = vel. The Schol. says, peritto\s o( kai\ su/ndesmos.
qa=sso/n te ga/r : te correlative to de/ before *dhmosqe/nhs, as in iii.52.13; v.9.35; viii.16.12. te ga/r = kai\ ga/r (etenim) does not occur before Aristotle. Kühn. 544, note 3.
e(ko/ntas ei)=nai: this seemingly pleonastic expression occurs generally only in neg. sents. GMT. 100, N. 2; H. 956 a. Cf. ii.89.29; iv.98.14; vi.14.8.—swthri/an: cf. vi.60.17.
tosau=ta o(/sa: in restrictive signification (see on ii.12.1; Kr. Spr. 46, 5, 4), only so much as. Cf. c. 49. 1. The acc. is cognate.
16. ta\ plei/w e)n po/nw| cunexeste/rw| w)/n: for the most part under more continual pressure, i.e. than Nicias.
kai\ to/te: and now also, opp. to ta\ plei/w.
ou) prouxw/rei...e)s ma/xhn cuneta/sseto : “he was trying to keep his troops ready for battle, rather than to press forward.”

[*)aqhnai=oi]: considered a gloss by Kr., St., and Cl., as not all were Athenians. Cf. c. 82. 6, tines po/leis ou) pollai/. But in c. 86. 17 *surakosi/wn includes also the allies; why may not *)aqhnai=oi here?

a)neilhqe/ntes: Schol. sustrafe/ntes. “Driven back into a small space.” Lobeck proposed cuneilhqe/ntes; but later writers have a)neilei=n in the same sense. Cf. Arr. An. iv.5.8, oi( de\ tou\s diabai/nontas a)ntime/twpoi taxqe/ntes a)nei/loun e)s to\n potamo/n.

e)/nqen te kai\ e)/nqen : on both sides. Supply h)=n from perih=n. Kr. Spr. 62, 4, 1. Grote explains (VII. c. 60, p. 180, note), “a road which passed through the walled ground, entering at one side and coming out at the other.” But the Greek does not mean this.—e)la/as de\ ei)=xen: free continuation of the rel. sent. without repetition of the pron. See on c. 29. 27. Plut. Nic. 27 calls this place *poluzh/leion au)lh/n. He adds from Philistus, that Demosthe
nes had before this made an attempt to take his own life; so too Paus. i.29.12.

peristado/n, custado/n: both adv. forms found only here in Thuc. The latter is connected, even without the art., with ma/xais, = stadi/ais ma/xais. Kr. Spr. 50, 8, 19. Cf. iv.38.30, h( ma/xh ou) stadi/a h)=n.

26. a)pokinduneu/ein pro\s a)nqrw/pous a)ponenohme/nous: “to risk their lives against despairing men.” Cf. Xen. Hell. vii.5.12, toi=s a)ponenohme/nois ou)dei\s a)\n u(postai/h; Zon. Ann. vii. 25, mh\ diakinduneu/ein pro\s a)nqrw/pous a)ponoi/a| xrwme/nous.
feidw/ tis e)gi/gneto : = feidw/ tina(sfw=n au)tw=n)e)poiou=nto, or e)fei/donto sfw=n a(u)tw=n.
e)p) eu)pragi/a| h)/dh safei= : on the ground that success was now assured. Cf. e. 59. 2; 62. 1.

mh\ proanalwqh=nai/ tw|: dependent on feidw\ e)gi/gneto, with which tw| (i.e. tini *surakosi/w|) is to be construed. The inf. with mh/ comes under the const. after verbs of hindrance or freedom. GMT. 95, 2; H. 1029. The Schol. gives in free connexion the proper sense, e)fei/deto au)to/s tis e(autou=, w(/ste mh\ proanalwqh=nai.
kai\ w(/s : Schol. xwri\s tou= au)toi\ proanalwqh=nai kai\ kinduneu=sai.
tau/th| th=| i)de/a| : Schol. h)/goun tou/tw| tw=| tro/pw| th=s ma/xhs, i.e. by surrounding and shooting them down from a distance, not engaging in a custado\n ma/xh.

In answer to the first summons of the Syracusans, in which freedom is promised to any allies of the Athenians who will come over to them, those from a few cities surrender. A capitulation is then concluded also with the others, about 6000 in number, on condition that their lives shall be spared. All then surrender, and give up their arms and property, and are led away to Syracuse. Nicias, however, crosses with his division the Erineus, and encamps on a high place.

1. d' ou)=n: for gou=n of the Mss., seems necessary, in order to resume, after the digression, the account broken off at c. 81. 24. See on c. 59. 1; i.3.19. For ou)=n resumptive, see on c. 6. 7.—di) h(me/ras: all day long.

tw=n nhsiwtw=n: reference is made esp. to those enumerated in c. 57. § 4 (u(ph/kooi o)/ntes kai\ a)na/gkh| o(/mws h)kolou/qoun),
and whose desertion was first to be expected. The gen. depends on ei)/ tis.
e)p) e)leuqeri/a| : on condition of personal liberty, i.e. that they should not be made slaves. For e)pi/ with dat. of condition or determining circumstances, see Kr. Spr. 68, 41, 7. Cf. i.13.4, etc.
w(s sfa=s a)pie/nai: belonging both to kh/rugma poiou=ntai and ei)/ tis bou/letai.
7. e)/peita u(/steron: as in ii.9.7, and often. The sent. is independent, where we should expect e)/peita ei) kte(. answering to prw=ton me\n ei) kte(.
w(/ste : on condition that. GMT. 98, 2; H. 953 b.
oi( pa/ntes: with e(cakisxi/lioi, 6000 in all. See on c. i. 31.
kate/qesan: deposited, as in i.27.6.
tou/tous me/n: sc. tou\s meta\ *dhmosqe/nous.
tau/th| th=| h(me/ra| : the sixth day.
kaqi=se: cf. vi.66.2.

Nicias is overtaken by the Syracusans; and learning the fate of Demosthenes, he offers a large indemnity in money with the hope of getting more favourable conditions. But the proposal is rejected, and a last attempt to steal away during the night fails, only 300 succeeding in breaking through the guards.
1. th=| u(sterai/a|: the seventh day.— 4. spe/ndetai...pe/myai : rare const. Cf. iii.109.12, spe/ndontai . . . a)poxwrei=n. The verb has generally the acc., ii.73.5; iii.24.18; 109. 10; 114. 11.
oi)xo/menos: indicates the immediate departure of the messenger. See on c. 7. 6.
a)ph/ggeile paradedwko/tas: sc. tou\s meta\ *dhmosqe/nous sfa=s au)tou/s.
u(pe\r *)aqhnai/wn: i.e. in the name of the people of Athens.
w(/ste: on condition that. See on c. 82. 8.— 9. me/xri d' ou(= a)/n: Vat. for me/xri ou(= d' a)/n of the rest of the Mss. The closer connexion of the rel. pron. with a)/n is more forcible.
e(/na kata\ ta/lanton: “because about a talent was the ransom of a free man.” (Kr.)

perista/ntes e)/ballon kai\ tou/tous: referring to c. 81. 24, e)ba/llonto peristado/n (of the soldiers of Demosthenes). 13. me/xri o)ye/: for connexion of prep. with adv., see Kühn. 446, b; Kr. Spr. 66, 1, 4.

13. ponh/rws: for accent and meaning, see App. on c. 48. 2. Cf. Xen. Cyr. vii.5.75, ponh/rws . . . e)/xei.— 14. si/tou te kai\ tw=n e)pithdei/wn: the part co-ord. with the whole. Kr. Spr. 69, 32, 2. See on c. 62. 6.

th=s nukto\s to\ h(suxa/zon: Schol. kaq' o)\ ma/lista th=s nukto\s i)/mellon oi( pole/mioi h(suxa/zein. Cf. Liv. xxv. 9, nox concubia; Tac. Ann. i. 39. The use of the neut. sing. of the pres. partic. as an abstract noun is esp. freq. in Thuc. GMT. 108, 2, N. 4; Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 28.
