kai\ oi( *surako/sioi...e)paia/nisan : see on c. 44. 32. kai/ is not strictly co-ord. with the preceding te, but introduces the main clause vividly in paratactic const. “as soon as the Athenians take up their arms, the Syracusans observe it and raise the battle-cry.” Kühn. 518, 8.— 17. gno/ntes de/: after the irregularity just mentioned, the sent. is continued not by kai/, but by the stronger de/ (see on c. 81. 12); though both principal verbs, a)nalamba/nousi and kate/qento, are so closely connected that one obj. (o(/pla) suffices for both.
dia\ tw=n fula/kwn biasa/menoi: see on c. 79. 2. The fate of these 300 is related in c. 85. 11.

p.hi: Nevertheless, on the following morning Nicias sets out with his ex-

hausted army, and reaches, under constant attacks of the enemy, the river Assinarus. In their attempt to cross, and while slaking their thirst in the river, a large number perish, partly by the weapons of the enemy, partly by drowning.

div2.p: 1. h(me/ra: the eighth day.
h)=ge th\n stratia/n: i.e. continued his march.

5. *)assi/naron: now Falconara, acc. to Holm, H. p. 401 (or Fiume di Noto, Holm, Karlsr. Vortr., which see for particulars).—a)/ma me/n, biazo/menoi kte(.: the Athenians press on to the river for two reasons: (1) because they hoped, when they should have crossed the river, to suffer less from the enemy; (2) on account of their thirst. Hence a(/ma me/n, which introduces the first ground, is to be taken with oi)o/menoi, and the partic. biazo/menoi is explanatory of this: “being hard pressed on all sides, they hoped to get some relief by crossing the river.” The second reason is added without a partic, by means of the gen. with u(po/ and the simple dat. e)piqumi/a|. Kr. Spr. 59, 2, 3.
9. ou)deni\ ko/smw| e)/ti: no longer in any order. Cf. e)/ti nukto/s, iv.26.20. ou)deni\ ko/smw|, as in c. 23. 16; 40. 10; ii.52.5; iii.108.16.
pa=s te/ tis: see on c. 60. 13. te connects pa=s with kai\ oi( pole/mioi, both of which are subjs. of xaleph\n . . . e)poi/oun.

peri\ toi=s dorati/ois kai\ skeu/esin kte(.: “some perished at once, pierced by their own spears; others, becoming entangled (e)mpalasso/menoi = e)mpleko/menoi, Schol.) in their trappings, were carried away by the current.” As there had been rain four days before (cf. c. 79. 9), we may suppose that the stream was not at its lowest point. oi( me\n . . . diefqei/ronto goes with peri\ toi=s dorati/ois and oi( de\ . . . kate/rreon with skeu/esi. Cf. Plut. Sull. 18, kata\ pranou=s fero/menoi toi=s do/rasi perie/pipton au)toi\ toi=s e(autw=n. The skeu/h are, as in vi.31.29, to be understood of the military equipment outside of the real arms (breastplate, helmet, etc.). On e)mpalasso/menoi, cf. Hdt.
vii.85.11, e)n e(/rkesi e)mpalasso/menoi diafqei/rontai.
15. e)s ta\ e)pi\ qa/tera/ te: the particle is so placed because the preceding phrase is regarded as one word. On the use of such phrases, see Kr. Spr. 43, 4, 3.

h)=n krhmnw=des: without def. subj., ta\ e)pi\ qa/tera, perhaps, being understood. Cf. i.63.10, e)/sti katafane/s; vi.101.15, phlw=des h)=n.— 18. a)sme/nous: “greedily.” Vat. has a)sme/nws, but the adv. is not used by Thuc. See Herbst, Gegen Cobet, p. 22. —e)n koi/lw| o)/nti tw=| potamw=|: i.e. with a deep bed. The reference is to a river which has cut a deep channel, and hence, when the water is low, flows between high and steep banks. So is to be explained Polyb. xxii.20.4. e)gefu/rwse to\n *sagga/rion potamo\n tele/ws koi=lon o)/nta kai\ du/sbaton. Cf. also Plut. Cam. 3, oi( de\ potamoi\ pa/ntes w(/sper a)ei\ koi=loi kai\ tapeinoi\ dia\ qe/rous e)rru/hsa(n.
e)n sfi/sin au)toi=s tarassome/nous : cf. c. 67. 14.
19. e)pikataba/ntes: i.e. going down to the very edge of the water. Cf. c. 23. 2; 35. 9; iv.11.2.

eu)qu\s die/fqarto: on the plpf. with eu)qu/s to express instantaneous effect, see Kr. Spr. 53, 4, 2.—o(mou= tw=| phlw=| h(|matwme/non: although, in addition to the mud, it was bloody. o(mou= with the dat. as in c. 19. 25.

perima/xhton: le/getai to\ periti/mion, peri\ ou(= tines a)llh/lois diama/xontai, i(/na tou/tou kratw=si kai\ tou=to ktw=ntai. Schol. on Ar. Thesm. 326. Cf. Plat. Legg. 678 e, perima/xhtos h)=n au)toi=s h( trofh/.

Finally Nicias surrenders to Gylippus, expecting better treatment from him than from the Syracusans. Gylippus now orders the slaughter to be stopped. Of the survivors, however, the smaller part only become state prisoners, for very many are hidden away secretly and scattered as slares over all Sicily. A very large number, too, had been killed, partly in the fighting on the march, partly in the last struggle. Of those who are sold into slavery, many escape later to Catana.
1. nekrw=n te pollw=n: Diod. xiii. 19 puts the loss at the river at 18,000, and the captured at 7,000; but it is evident that he includes the army of Demosthenes.

tou= strateu/matos tou= me\n...tou= de/ : part. appos. See
on c. 31. 4.
pisteu/sas ma=llon: more fully explained, c. 86. § 4.
xrh/sasqai: the same formula also in ii.4.32; iv.69.22.
8. zwgrei=n: (from zw=os and a)/gra, a)greu/ein) the opposite of foneu/ein, meaning not so much take captive as give quarter.

tou/s teloipou/s: answers to kai\ e)pi\ tou\s triakosi/ous (10). —o(/sous mh\ a)pekru/yanto: sc. oi( *surako/sioi, i.e. so many as had not been hidden away by the Syracusan soldiers, to be kept or sold as slaves.— 10. e)pi\ tou\s triakosi/ous: cf. c. 83. § 5.
diech=lqon: const., like diafugei=n, with the acc. Cf. Xen. Mem. iii.9.7, ta\s pu/las tou= tei/xous dieciw/n.
tou\s diwcome/nous : the art. with the fut. partic. equiv. to rel. with indef. antec. (Lat. qui with subjv.). Kr. Spr. 50, 4, 3. Cf. ii.51.19; iv.93.13; vi.20.15.
to\ a)qroisqe\n tou= strateu/matos, to\...diaklape/n : as to the collective use of the neut. partic., see on c. 43. 44.

e)s to\ koino/n: i.e. as state prisoners. The passage is imitated by Plut. Timol. 29: tw=n ai)xmalw/twn oi( me\n polloi\ diekla/phsan u(po\ tw=n stratiwtw=n, ei)s de\ koino\n a)pedei/xqhsan pentakisxi/lioi.

ou) polu/ : “only about 1000; for the sum total of the captives was about 7000 (c. 87. 19), and of these about 6000 had belonged to the division of Demosthenes (c. 82. 11).” Bm. But the full magnitude of the catastrophe is seen in the fact that eight days before there were still 40,000 men (c. 75. 26).

16. me/ros de/ ti ou)k o)li/gon: still to be connected with tou= strateu/matos, the three parts of which are to\ a)qroisqe\n e)s to\ koino/n, to\ diaklape/n, and me/ros ti ou)k o)li/gon a)pe/qane. This last refers, therefore, to those of the division of Nicias who perished on the eighth day at and in the Assinarus. The losses of the preceding days are expressly distinguished from this in 18: kai\ e)n tai=s a)/llais prosbolai=s . . . ou)k o)li/goi e)teqnh/kesan (the plpf. indicating the events lying further back, opp. to a)pe/qane in 16). With this view, the expression tw=n e)n tw=|
*sikelikw=| pole/mw| tou/tw| (18) appears in the prop. light. Thuc. here compares only the horrible butchery at the Assinarus (fo/nos ou(=tos) with the various battles in this Sicilian campaign, including, besides those of the last seven days, the battle about Plemmyrium, c. 22 ff., the night battle on Epipolae, c. 43, the repeated seafights, c. 52, 69 ff. Certainly he had a right to emphasize this as the bloodiest of all (fo/nos ou)deno\s e)la/sswn). We must, therefore, neither read with the Schol. *(ellhnikw=| for *sikelikw=|, nor with Dobree and St. omit it. It is also to be observed in connexion with this passage that Thuc. only very seldom uses o( po/lemos ou(=tos of the Peloponnesian War, but far oftener o(/de (as the subject of his own history). Cf. c. 87. 20.
douleu/santes: after they had become slares (aor.). Kr. Spr. 53, 5. 2.— kai\ diadidra/skontes u(/steron: running away afterwards (pres.).
e)s *kata/nhn: to this refers Lys. xx. 24, where Polystratus says a)nesw/qhn e)s *kata/nhn.

The Syracusans bring into the city all captives that fall into their hands, together with the booty taken from them, and place them in the neighbouring stone-quarries. But Nicias and Demosthenes are immediately executed, against the wish of Gylippus, who would have liked to carry them captive to Sparta.

3. a)nalabo/ntes: see on c. 33. 23. Elsewhere used of levying troops or calling them to arms (c. 1. 27; 4. 7; 43. 18); here, of the captives and the booty which were brought along with them in triumphal procession.

5. e)s ta\s liqotomi/as: cf. Cic. in Verr. H. v. 27, latomias Syracusanas omnes audistis: plerique nostis. Opus est ingens, magnificum, regum et tyrannorum: totum est ex saxo in mirandam altitudinem depresso et multorum operis penitus exciso: nihil tam clausum ad exitum, nihil tam saeptum undique, nihil tam tutum ad custodiam nec fieri nec cogitari potest. In has latomias, si qui publice cus
todiendi sunt, etiam ex caeteris oppidis Siciliae deduci imperantur. For their situation on the southern slope of the plateau of Achradina, and for their present condition, see Holm, I. p. 127, and Karlsr. Vortr. (fin.).—a)sfalesta/thn ei)=nai nomi/santes th/rhsin: sc. to\ katabiba/sai au)tou\s e)s ta\s liqotomi/as. For const., see App. to c. 42. 33.
kalo\n to\ a)gw/nisma: cf. c. 56. 9; 59. 2.
e)pi\ toi=s a)/llois: from ta\ a)/lla, besides his other (successes). e)pi\ with the dat. as in c. 75. 30.
9. cune/baine: it happened. Cf. c. 75. 7; v.10.33.—*dhmosqe/nhn: the name added in explanation, as in c. 57. 28. Kühn. 527, 3, note 3; Kr. Spr. 50, 1, 11.
ta\ e)n th=| nh/sw| kai\ *pu/lw|: cf. iv. 3 ff.
tou\s...a)/ndras : subj. of a)feqh=nai.
pei/sas tou\s *)aqhnai/ous : cf. v. 16 ff.
w(/ste a)feqh=nai: dependent on prouqumh/qh. GMT. 98, N. 2. Jow. puts a comma before pei/sas and after *)aqhnai/ous, making poih/sasqai depend on prouqumh/qh, w(/ste a)feqh=nai denoting the result.
16. dia\ tou=to pisteu/sas: cf. c. 85. 4. All Mss. except Vat. omit the indispensable dia\ tou=to.
w(s e)le/geto : with reference to the different reports current about it in Syracuse, concerning which Thuc. had informed himself.
o(/ti...e)kekoinolo/ghnto : cf. c. 48. 13; 73. 27.— basanizo/menos: of examination by torture also in viii.92.10; with acc. of the thing, vi.53.12.
kai\ ou)x h(/kista oi( *kori/nqioi: from this it would appear that tw=n *surakosi/wn above is meant to include also the allies.—dh/: in partic. subord. clause; as in c. 18. 5; 81. 10.

plou/sios
h)=n: he was worth 100 talents, acc. to Lys. XIX 47.—sfi/si: with reference to the whole Syracusan alliance, not the Corinthians alone.
new/tero/n ti: “some further mischief.” Cf. iv.55.7; viii.92.14.—a)p' au)tou=: see on c. 70. 16.
23. o(/ti e)ggu/tata: used as adj. with ai)ti/a| as in c. 81. 25, custado/n with ma/xais.

h(/kista...e)pith/deusin : in this closing remark about Nicias, the historian expresses unmistakably both his warm sympathy for him in his untoward fate and his high personal esteem. It is, it is true, not admiration of the intellectual greatness and far-reaching activity of the man, as in the case of Pericles, ii. 65, but rather respect for honest effort always made cautiously, but with a consciousness of noble purposes.— 26. dia\ th
 pa=san...e)pith/deusin : = dia\ th
 e)pith/deusin h)\ pa=sa e)s a)reth
 e)neno/misto, “on account of his course of life which had been wholly directed toward what was worthy.” See App.

Of the captives shut up in the stone-quarries, about 7000 in number, a great part perish from cruel treatment amid fearful torments; of the survivors, those who are not Athenians are sold into slavery. Thus ends the expedition against Sicily.

2. tou\s prw/tous xro/nous: explained by h(me/ras e(bdomh/konta/ tinas in 15. After these 70 days there was some relief at least, from the removal of a part of the captives.—metexei/risan: in Thuc. used only in act. See on i.13.7; found only here with pers. obj.; with acc. of the thing in vi.12.17; 16. 31.—koi/lw| xwri/w|: signifies a deep place with steep walls, as in c. 84. 18, koi=los potamo/s.
oi( h(/lioi : the pl. (as qa/lph, yu/xh, mege/qh) with intensive force. Kühn. 348, note 2; Kr. Spr. 44, 3, 6.

pni=gos: the smothering heat resulting from the crowded mass of human beings.— dia\ to\ a)ste/gaston: “because there was no shelter.” The neut. of the adj. instead of an abstract noun, as in i.69.14; ii.51.12, and freq.— e)pigigno/menai tou)nanti/on metopwrinai\ kai\ yuxrai/: “and the nights, on the contrary, following autumnal and cold.”

th=| metabolh=|: cf. Hdt. ii.77.10, e)n ga\r th=|si metabolh=|si toi=si a)nqrw/poisi ai( nou=soi ma/lista gi/nontai tw=n te a)/llwn pa/ntwn kai\ dh\ kai\ tw=n
w(re/wn ma/lista.

e)s a)sqe/neian e)newte/rizon : “engendered violent disorders.” Cf. Arr. An. iv.8.2, e)s to\ barbarikw/teron nenewte/risto; id. vii.13.3, mh/ ti newterisqei/h e)s u(/brin. e)s a)sqe/neian indicates the consequence. newteri/zein is used of every departure from the general order, esp. of hard and violent changes. See on i.58.3.
pa/nta poiou/ntwn...e)n tw=| au)tw=| : Schol. dia\ to\ du/sfhmon a)pesiw/phsen au)ta\ o)nomasti\ ei)pei=n. See on iv.97.13, kai\ o(/sa a)/nqrwpoi e)n bebh/lw| drw=si pa/nta gi/gnesqai au)to/qi.
e)p) a)llh/lois cunnenhme/nwn : cf. ii.52.6.
kai\ to\ toiou=ton: cf. c. 50. 30.
a)nektoi/: as adj. of two terminations; so e)sbato/n in ii.41.16.
di/yei: third decl., as in iv.35.13 di/yous; but in ii.49.23 di/yh|, acc. to most of the Mss. St. has adopted everywhere the forms of the first decl.

kotu/lhn u(/datos kte(.: the scantiness of this measure, which was only half of the food given to slaves, is best seen by a comparison with that which was allowed to the Lacedaemonians taken on Sphacteria: du/o xoi/nikas e(ka/stw| *)attika\s a)lfi/twn kai\ du/o kotu/las oi)/nou kai\ kre/as, iv.16.8. The kotu/lh is the fourth part of the xoi=nic. See Boeckh, P. E. p. 125.—a)/lla o(/sa: as in ii.96.13, for o(/sa a)/lla. Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 10. With it Cl. connects ou)de\n o(/ ti ou)k, tou/twn being understood; rather, it seems, a)/lla has been attracted from the gen. into the case of the rel. Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 9.
e)n tw=| toiou/tw|: the art., added from Vat., refers back expressly to the description of 2 ff. For e)n after verbs of motion, esp. the pf., see on c. 71. 40.
ou)de\n o(/ ti ou): on this formula see Kr. Spr. 51, 10, 11.—e)pege/neto: used esp. of sicknesses and great ills. Cf. ii.49.9; 58. 8.
15. tinas: with a numeral. See on c. 33. 17.—dih|th/qhsan: complexive aor., which recapitulates the foregoing. Cf. i.6.3. GMT. 19, N. 2.— 17. a)pe/donto: Schol. e)pw/lhsan.
18. a)kribei/a| me\n...e)ceipei=n, o(/mws de/ : the parenthetical subord. clause is treated as if co-ord. with the leading clause.—ou)k e)la/ssous e(ptakisxili/wn: see on c. 85. 13.

19. cune/bh te: and so it happened. For the inferential te, see on c. 71. 21.—e)/rgon tou=to...me/giston : the same manner of expression and order of words as in i.1.8. The form of the sent., which is often used by Thuc., does not admit of an explanatory adj. with the simple dem. The restrictive *(ellhniko/n is inconsistent also with the general idea of the sent., which emphasizes, out of the whole course of the Peloponnesian War (kata\ to\n po/lemon to/nde), the greatest and most important event (e)/rgon here = a completed occurrence, not a single fact). In the next clause *(ellhnikw=n is prop., since the view is extended beyond this war, and the historian naturally limits himself to the events of Greek history. Kr., Pluygers, and St. also omit *(ellhniko/n.
dokei=n d) e)/moige : the elliptical inf. without w(s. See on c. 49. 18; i.138.17.
23. kata\ pa/nta: i.e. on sea and on land, in their fortifications and in the open field. The paronomasia in pa/nta pa/ntws as in viii.1.9, pa/nta pantaxo/qen.
ou)de\n o)li/gon e)s ou)de/n : see on c. 59. 9.

panwleqri/a|: not found elsewhere except in later writers, but the adj. panw/leqron is much used in tragedy with a)po/llusqai (Aesch. Sept. 71; Ag. 518; Eum. 522; Pers. 563; Soph. El. 1009). On to\ lego/menon, “as the saying is,” see Kr. Spr. 57, 10, 12.—dh/: emphasizes esp. the pan-, as it does sups. and similar consts. Cf. ii.77.7, pa=san dh\ i)de/an e)peno/oun.
ou)de\n o(/ ti ou) : see on 14.

o)li/goi a)po\ pollw=n: as in i.110.2; iii.112.30.—a)peno/sthsan: acc. to Plut. Nic. 29, many of the Athenians obtained their freedom, others, who had already escaped, got food and shelter, by repeating verses from Euripides, who was more popular with the Sicilians than any other foreign author. The thanks of these survivors, many of whom on their return expressed their gratitude to him, were no doubt the sweetest praise the poet ever heard.—tau=ta me/n: co-ord. with e)s de\ ta\s *)aqh/nas of viii.1.1.— 27. ta\ geno/mena: sc. h)=n. For other forms of conclusion, see on c. 30. 19.
